By DEBORAH WESER 
Atty. Gen. .John Hill Wednesday filed suit against the Texas Water Quality 
Board for arbitrarily, capriciously and unreasonably breaking up pollution control over the Edwards acpiifer. 
That TWQB move. Hill contends in his suit in 12Hth District Court in 
Travis County (Austin), could increase the possibility of irreversible conta­ mination of the water in that under­ ground reservoir. 
For that reason. Hill wants the court to wipe out the TWQB action and restore a single pollution control order for the entire seven-county an'a under which the Underground limestone re­ sen oir flows. 
Hill s action will be joined by Bexar 
County, .Judge Blair Reeves indicated

ASSOCIATED PRESS 
WASHINGTON - In bizarre sequence, terrorist gunmen in­ vaded the headquarters of a 
.Jewish organization, a Moslem religious center and Washing­ ton’s City Hall on Wednesday, killing a radio newsman and seizing scores of hostages. 

A handful of black men, nine to ll by police reckoning, captured their hos­ tages during the day and still held at least HO people at three different loca­ tions early Thursday. 
The gunm en, arm ed with rifle s, shotguns, some autom atic weapons arid a m achete, were thought to be members of the predominantly black 
Hanafi Moslem sect, victimized by a mass murder in Washington four years ago. a gun 

ASSOCIATED PRESS 
WASHINGTON - “ Man with a gun!” 
That shout from a woman running through the halls sounded the alert in Washing­ ton’s city hall. 
Gunm en had invaded the council chambers Wednesday afternoon. 
City hall was one of three buildings throughout tin* city invaded by bands ol riflemen described as black M us­ lims. 
Barricaded 
Many city hall workers barricaded themselves iii their offiees and hid behind d e s k s One. Sandy Brown, ex­ ecutiv e a ss istan t to Councilman Julius 
Hobson, spoke with an A ssociated 
I*cess rep o rter by telephone while awaiting rescue. 
“ When I just got into the office, I heard one of the staff people ran buck and said there w as a man with a gun 
"At thai. we all ran back to the office and other people ran buck to theirs. closed tin* door, locked it. and b a r ­ ricaded it.

Their apparent ringleader said he wanted revenge for the 1973 killing of the seven Hanafi Moslems, six of them his children. 
He dem anded that the people he holds responsible — leaders of the rival Black M uslim sect — be delivered to the te rro ris ts holding nearly HO hostages at the headquarters of B’nai B rith, the Jewish service or-, gunization. 

Khalifa Ilamaas Abdul Khaalis also dem anded, and got, cancellation of 
A m erican show ings of. the film 
“ M oham m ad, M essenger o f a n d . " which he said was an affront to his religion. His w ere the only public demands.

W illiam s, 24, a black r e p o r te r for 
WHUR, a statio n a ffilia te d with 
Howard U niversity. W illia m s was 

“ Right after that, within lh minutes or so, I heard three shots. Then, it was fairly quiet. Then I heard a number of shots since that time. Rifle shots. A semi-automatic. In quick succession. I heard glass breaking and that sort of thing. 
"I went into Julius’office, locked the door and put the desk in front of it. and that’s where I sit right now.” 
A nother w om an e m p lo y e , also reached by telephone, said she hid iii another office alter also hearing shots. 
She declined to identify herself. 
Sin* said at one point during the or­ deal that she heard a woman scream. from somewhere nearby. “ Let me out of here.” Sin* said she never saw the gunmen, only heard shots and glass breaking. 

Wounded 

By early evening, police said one person had been killed at the city building and that three others, includ­ ing Lily Councilman Marion Barry, were wounded.

Tucker was among the hostages iii the building.

Row. Federal agents said three gun­ men there were armed with two shot­ guns and a rifle.

Group to push tourism 

By SARA MARTINEZ 
About 25 San Antonians are prepar­ ing for a week-long tour of Mexico to encourage Mexican tourists to visit one of the most unique anil closest major cities to them. 
The delegation will leave Sunday for 
Guadalajara, Mexico City and Monter­ rey promoting the theme, "Como San 
Antonio no hay dos” — like San An­ tonio there is no other. 
“ We are delighted in having a dis­ tinguished group of local citizens to accompany us this scar.” San Antonio 
Convention and V isitors Bureau Dir 
H enry N u ssb au m said W ednesday night. 
The delegate* represent the Conven­ tion and V isitors B ureau, visitor attractions, hotel and motel properties arid other businesses 
” 1 think it is a compliment to San 
Antonio thai ifs citizens are willing to travel on their own time and money to promote their city," Nussbaum said.

Hill sues over aquifer 

EXCLUSIVE WIRE SERVICES: ASSOCIATED PRISS, N EW Y O R K TIMES SERVICE, W A SH IN G TO N POST SERVICE, LOS ANGELES TIMES 
SERVICE, N EW SD A Y SERVICE, AGEN CE FRANCE PRESSE, M ANCHESTER GU AR D IAN SERVICE, LO N D O N TIMES SERVICE 

'I cannot stand by and let this order stand 

 later in the day. 
County Commissioners Court earlier took steps to sue TWQB themselves hut have since decided to intervene in the attorney general's case. Reeves said. 
Reeves also plans to ask the City of 
San Antonio, se v eral a re a w a te r ag en cies and se v era l n e ig h b o rin g counties to join Hill's suit. 
At issue is last week's TWQB action issuing s e p a ra te pollution control orders with different sta n d a rd s for each of the seven counties affected. 
Urban counties have stiffer s ta n ­ d ard s to m eet th an do the ru ra l counties. Hill is particularly upset, according to his petition, by the spe­ 

 cial treatment given rural Uvalde and 
Kinney Counties. 
” 1 cannot stand by and let this order stand.” he told newsmen in San An­ tonio d u rin g a special W ednesday briefing following the Austin filing. 
Hill brought the issue to San Antonio because of the local importance of the suit. The aquifer currently is the sole source of drinking water for San An­ tonio and Bexar County. 
His action. Hill pointed out, is not wihtout precedent although it is unu­ sual for the state—through Hill’s office 
— to sue one of its own agencies. 
Hill has in the past sued the Texas 
Water Rights Commission after dis­ 

 puting the legality of a w ater sale authorized by that agency. The case is still in litigation, he pointed out, noting also: 
“ This isn’t something John Hill has been interested in just recently. It has nothing to do with politics. It is my job to represent the people of the state.” 
By d isq u a lify in g h im se lf in the 
TWQB representation situation, how­ ever, Hill has cleared the way for that agency to seek outside legal a ssis ­ tance, he pointed out. 
The seven counties affected in this case are Bexar. Comal, Medina, Hays, 
Kendall, Kinney and Uvalde. 
Hill’s petition describes the recharge zone of the aquifer as that area where the b a re lim e sto n e s u rfa c e s and

Israeli border pullback 

WASHINGTON POST SERVICE 
WASHINGTON — President Carter forecast Wednesday that a Middle East peace settlement is likely to involve israeli withdrawal from all but “ min­ or” portions of the Arab territory it captured iii 1o457. but suggested that 
Israel’s pullback may be phased over eight years or more, 
Speaking to reporters at his third televised press conference. Carter ap- 
| iou red to be aligning bis statements toward the policy and thinking of previous U S ad m in istratio n s aud bucking away from his surprise en­ dorsement Monday (if the Israeli de­ mand for “ defensible borders.” As if bas been used in Israel, "defensible borders” has implied the retention of large amounts of occupied Arab land. 
Listening posts 

C arter declared that demilitarized zones—Arab land occupied bv “ inter­ national forces" and electronic listen­ ing posls—couId “ very well be part ol 

 a (Middle E a s t) agreement. 
Ile said be will discuss this possibi­ lity with Arab leaders soon to visit 
Washington, implying he had already taken it up with the Israelis 
Two hours after Curter spoke, Israeli 
Prime M inister Yitzhak Rabin said that while his country will take advice from anyone, “ the borders of peace 
(and) the security arrangem ents will 
Im> decided only by the participants to the conflict." 
Rabin’s statement to presidents of 
American 
Jewish organizations, shortly before ending his three-day stay in Washington, appeared to put 
Carter on notice thai Israel rather than 
(he United States will make the crucial decisions. 
Following a practice begun at his first press conference four weeks ago, 
C arter disclosed several new a rm s control proposals that he has made to the Soviet Union in recent weeks 
He reported tor the tirst time that he has asked Moscow to head Oil a p o s se 

 bit* military buildup iii outer space by agreeing with the United States not to arm space satellites and not to develop weapons to destroy other nations’ sa­ tellites. 
A recent resumption of Soviet tests of hunter-killer satellites has prompt­ ed increased U.S. military concern and 
Pentagon work on U S. arm ed satel­ lites, it was reported in January 
C a rte r also revealed that he has asked Russia to agree that the Indian 
Ocean Im* "completely demilitarized 
The U S military has opposed such proposals in the past. and government officials who have worked in this area expressed surprise at Carter s revela­ tion Iii recent weeks a I S naval task force iii the Indian Ocean — which presumably would be banned under 
Carter's plan — was used as a show of tom* in deterring any action against 
American citizens by Uganda Prest* dent ldi Amin. 
Tile President was able to give no

The local delegation was honored at a get-aqua in ted reception sponsored by the Convention and Visitors Bureau and Holiday Inns, Inc 
At the reception, the delegates and 
(•tiler contributors to the trip viewed a new audio-visual presentation which will be furnished the media anet tour and travel agents iii three Mexican cities. 
“ We arc trying to tell Mexican tour­ ists that San Antonio is not just a big shopping c e n t e r ,” said P a tr ic ia 
O ’C onnell, in te rn a tio n a l re la tio n s manager for the bureau. 
“ We want to promote the myriad of activities San Antonio has to offer, sin h as the fine restaurants, the zoo, the river and historical sites “ 
The presentation, “ Como San An­ tonio no hay d os,” is in Spanish. It highlights Sun Antonio's variety of tourist sites, restauran ts, e n te rta in ­ ment spots, sports facilities, recrea­ tion areas and moods 
It stresses the beauty of San Anton­ io’s ability to combine a rich Mexican heritage with modern North American technology

 w a s h i n g t o n PO ST SERVICE 

W A SH IN G TO N - At the W hite 
House, Hamilton Jordan snapped his remote TV' control buttons searching for new s of the te r r o r is m in 
Washington. 
A clerk in the Mayor's command center began a log of the day’s events on a huge wall chart: 
“ 11:4o a.m . P olice action on the scene.” 
At 2:o3 p.m ., officials gave up trying to keep their log. Events were moving too fast. 
Capitol Hill Police, U.S. Park Police and General Services Administration guards watched as reports flashed back and forth by telephone, on tele­ vision and radio. 
The Pentagon, the Secret Service and the State Department were all paying careful attention, but none took special action Wednesday, according to spokesmen. 
Reserves called 
W ash in g to n p o lice c a lle d up all a v ailable re serv e s to deal with the three Muslim incidents and in mid-af­ ternoon the White House ordered the 
F B I into the case, although officials were unclear what. if any, federal law had been violated. 
The F B I said it had been “ instructed by President (a r t e r to com m ence an immediate and vigorous investigation of all v io la tio n s of fe d era l law in ­ volved.” But the W ashington police remained in charge. 
White House press secreta ry Jody 
Powell, who had planned to take the 

 day off to rest an injured knee, said late W ednesday afterno on that the 
White House and Ju stice Department were in touch concerning the d ay ’s events. 
“ What can be done by the federal government can be done by the Ju stice 
D e p a r tm e n t,’ ’ P ow ell said . He d e ­ clined to describe Carter's reaction to the incidents. 

Down the hall, presidential assistant 
Jo r d a n e x p r e s s e d d is b e lie f as he watched television reports of events unfolding in the city. 
About 4.p.m., he convened a meeting in his office attended by National Se­ curity Adviser Zbigniew Brezezinski 
Powell, appointments secretary Tim 
K raft. W hite House counsel R obert 
Lipshutz and deputy press secretary 
Rex Gran urn. 
For the White House, Washington’s c ris is overlapped with C a r te r ’s pro­ mise to speak to Cory Moore in Cleve­ land after Moore released a hostage he was holding there. 
F B I D ire cto r C la re n ce K elley r e ­ ceived a call a few minutes after ll a.m ., about the time the Hanafi Mus­ lims were moving toward their first target, the B ’nai B ’rith center. 
K elley, told the Ohio hostage was safe, pushed the button on his direct line to Atty. Gen. Griffin Bell to relay the message to the White House. 
C a r te r honored his p ro m ise by speaking with Moore at 4:13 p.m. 
Jordan said the White House knew of no connection between the Ohio inci­ dent and the Hanafi Muslim takeovers here.

TERRORISTS 

Continued from Page I X their hostages in an unfinished ca fe ­ teria on the eighth floor. 
“ They are negotiating very serious­ ly,” said Deputy Police Chief Arthur 
DiGennaro. 
Two other deputy police chiels were conducting negotiations with the in­ truders at the District Building and at the mosque. 
Police said the episodes at the mos­ que and at B ’nai B ’rith were a coor­ dinated operation They said there was no proof that the city hall takeover was linked to the other two. But it appeared to be. 
For hours, police had thought a n ­ other man lay dead in a fifth floor hallway at the District Building, w ithin range of the intruders’ guns. When the gunmen permitted them to go to the victim, they found him alive and took him to a hospital. He was identified only as a building guard. 

Hours apart 
The three attacks came hours apart, all within two m ile s of the W h ite 
House. The District Building is within sight of the White House grounds. The 
B 'n a i B ’rith o ffice is seven b lo ck s north of the W hite H ouse and the 
Is la m ic C e n te r on M a s s a c h u s e tts 
Avenue is in the E m b assy Row d is ­ trict. 
Police sealed off the areas involved, including Pennsylvania Avenue, in the heart of the city, and M assachusetts

Hanafi Moslems have no history of violence 

WASHINGTON (A P ) - The tiny, black-dominated Hanafi Moslem group whose followers were believed respon­ sible for Wednesday’s attacks is a litt­ 

 le k n own s e c t w hich lost seven members in a 1973 mass-assassination at the hand s of 
B la c k 
M u slim opponents. 
Senate okays 
Warlike 

W ASH IN GTON (A P ) 
— Paul C. Warlike won 
S e n a te c o n fir m a tio n 
W ednesday as the n a ­ tion's chief arm s limita­ tion negotiator and d ir­ ector of the U.S. Arm s 
Control and 
D is a r ­ mament Agency. 
A fter a four-hour debate, the Senate voted 
58 to 4o to confirm the form er assistant s e c r e ­ tary of defense as head the U .S. d ele g a tio n to stategic arm s limitation ta lk s with the S o v iet 
Union. 
Later, a 7o to 29 vote co n firm ed 
W a rn k e ’s ap p o in tm en t by 
P r e ­ sident Carter to head the 
AUDA. 

Byrd 

In final a r g u m e n ts . 
S e n a te 
D e m o c r a tic 
Leader Robert C. Byrd of 
West Virginia expressed confidence that W arnke would make a “ tough” n e g o tia to r, and noted that the S e n a te would make the final decision on whether to accept any treaty emerging from the 
SALT talks. 

S e n a te 
R e p u b lica n 
Leader Howard ll. Baker said Warnke could not be a “ cred ib le” negotiator b ecau se of his p ast opposition to “ every new weapons system that has been suggested."

D e m o c ra ts and

R e p u b lica n s voted for

Democrats opposed him. 

The Senate action end­ ed a four-day debate and came hours after Carter told a news conference he had 
“ c o m p le te c o n ­ fidence" in Warnke. 
Criticism 

Warlike has been c r i ­ ticized b e ca u se of his past s ta te m e n ts and writings in which he ad­ vocated defense budget cuts, opposed major U.S. s tra te g ic w eapons s y s ­ te m s , and su g g e ste d temporary U.S. arms re­ s tr a in ts lo e n co u ra g e similar cutbacks by Rus­ sia 

Four y ears of pent-up anger m ay have been a motive for the terrorist sieges at three buildings in the Capital, s ev era l s o u rc e s f a m ilia r with the group suggested. 
Though a recent study of domestic terrorism reveals a 12-year string of 
Black Muslim violence, there are no previou s in c id e n ts of v io le n c e a t ­ tributed to the independent, orthodox 
Hanafi sect. 

Koran 

The Hanafi Moslems follow a literal in te rp re ta tio n of the 
K o ran and con sid er th e m s e lv e s the only tru e folowers of Islam. Their m em bership in the United States is said to be less than I.(KHI, most of them black. 
The so-called Black Muslims, based in Chicago, are a much larger religious and com m ercial organization which follows the beliefs of the late E lija h 
Mohammad. 
A source in the Black Muslim com ­ munity, who asked not to be identified, suggested that W ednesday’s violence may have stemmed from the Hanafi’s strong dislike of a film. “ Mohammad, 
M essenger of G od ," or was in some unclear way related to revenge for the 
1973 murders. 

Murders 

Seven Hanafi m em b ers, including five children, were murdered at a W a­ shington home donated to the sect by professional basketball sta r K areem 
Abdul Ja b b a r. a m em ber of the group. 
One of the intruders, who took over three buildings in W e d n esd a y 's a t­ tacks, identified h im self as k h a lifa llam aas Abdul Khaalis and demanded that those convicted of the H anafi murders be brought to a siege head­ quarters. 

Avenue, site of the m ajor toreign embassies. 
President C arter ordered the F b l into the case, to investigate violations of federal law in “ the terrorist activi­ ties being perpetrated in the W ashing­ ton. D.C., a r e a .” Atty. Gen. G riffin 
Bell visited the police command center himself, and reported by telephone to 
White House aides. 
Rabin departure 
The terrorists staged their raids as 
Israeli Prim e Minister Yitzak Rabin was about to conclude a three-day visit to W ash in g ton . R a b in b y p a ss e d a planned departure cerem on y at the 
Washington Monument. His motorcade swept past, stra ig h t to his w aitin g plane at Andrews Air Force Base, Md. 
Israeli officials said security precau­ tions required the switch. 
Police ringed the three occupied buildings, some in helm ets and flak jackets, armed with high-powered ri­ fles. 
The gunm en and h ostag es in the 
B ’nai B rith office were out of sight, on the top floor of the white brick build­ ing. Police at the District of Columbia 
B u ild in g said they could s e e four women and three men hostages, bound and lying on the floor of a City Council office. There were said to be two gun­ men there. 
Released 2o 
The gunmen at B ’nai B ’rith released about 2o people during the day. An official of the organization said they apparently were holding Jew ish hos­ tages and releasing the rest. 
A policem an at the m o sq u e said there were three gunmen there. They released one of their 15 hostages, a 
19-year-old girl. One of the gunm en told a police negotiator that no one would be harmed unless there was an attempt to storm the building. He was assured that wouldn’t happen. But a man who answered the telephone there said “ heads will roll and people will die unless we get our d e m a n d s .’ ’ 
The key man seemed to be Abdul 
Khaalis. born Ernest McGhee in Gary, 
Iud. 
He was doing the demanding. He got his way on the movie. The projector was turned off in m id-show ing at a 
New York th eater, and p atron s got their $4 tick ets refunded. T h e U .S. distributor said it would be shown no more. 
Early Thursday, police reportedly agreed to Abdul K h aa lis’ in sisten ce that he be given back the $75o he was fined for con tem p t of co u rt at the 
Hanafi murder trial. 
He also wanted police sharpshooters removed from the B ’nai Brith area. 

His other demand: Those he held re­ sponsible for the 1973 Hanafi Moslem murders be turned over to him. Five members of what was then the Black 
M uslim sect were conv icted of the murders and four are still alive. 

Abdul K h a a lis said the m en he wanted also included W a lla c e and 
Herbert Muhammad, and heavyweight boxing ch a m p io n M u h a m m a d A ll, leading figures in what is now called the World Community of Islam in the 
West. 

After demanding delivery of those he b la m ed for the m u r d e r s . 
Abdul 
Khaalis referred questions to his son- in-law. Abdul A/.iz of Washington. 

“ We want them brought to ju stice ,” 
Abdul Aziz said. “ And justice, in this case, is by way of the sword. So if these people aren’t delivered, their stand-ins or someone else has to die for it.” 
Abdul Khaalis talked frequently with newsmen who telephoned, although police said later that irritated him.

Government issues ban on saccharin 

Ja c k Ander*#* s column has been delayed. 

WASHINGTON (A P ) - The Food and Drug Administration announced 
Wednesday it is banning saccharin, the only artificial sweepier approved fur use iii the United States, becau se it causes cancer iii laboratory animals. 
Acting FUA Commissioner Sherwm 
Gardner said it will take at least until 
Ju ly to com plete the ad m in istrativ e requirements before the ban goes into effect But he culled un manufacturers 
“ to discontinue use of sa cc h a rin as soon as possible, even while we are drafting the documents needed to a c­ complish this action." 
The FDA said ll was not ordering a recall of the many soft d rin k s aud foods continuing the sugar substitute, sa.ving tests “ do not indicate an im ­ mediate hazard to public health." 
Canada, too 

A s im ila r ban was a n n o u n ced s im u lta n e o u sly by the C a n a d ia n government whose scien tific studies were the basis for the U.K. action. 
Under the FD A’s order. It will take iu days fur the agency to draft the ban 
The FDA then will allow 8U days fur com m en ts from in te reste d p a rlie s 
Then, the agency will lake another 3U days lo make the rule final, mukluk 

July the earliest month when the ban could take effect 
Am erican consum ers eat or drink more than five million pounds of sac­ charin a veal. about three-quarters ol it in diet soft drinks and (tie rest iii coffee tea and dietetic foods such a? canned fruits, gelatin deserts, jam s ice cream s and puddings. 

It also has been used in sum* m outhw ashes, c o s m e tic s aud over ih e-eo u n te r d ru g s. 

The Canadian study involved feeding 
IIM) rats a diet of 5 per cent pure sac­ charin for their entire lives, from eon ception until death Fourteen of thosi ruts developed c a n c e r o u s Ijladdc tum ors com pared to only two sue I tumors in a group ol KHI anim als eivei no saccharin. 
In order to consume an equivalent amount of saccharin a pen son woui< have to clr ink HOU 12-ounce diet sodas day for a lifetime, the FDX said. 
The FUA order was denounced by a officer of Sweet 'N Low, a large sue charm user 

The fed eral law under which th 
EDA acted prohibits the use in food i any ingredients shown lu cause cam e iii animals or humans.

Page ’ 3-A 
Freed hostages give skimpy clues 

NEW VORK TIMES SERVICE 

WASHINGTON — Faddy Jam es Jr., 
Ins trousers splotched with someone else’s blood, had nearly escaped the 
B’nai B’rith Building here Tuesday afternoon when one of his armed cap­ tors called him back. 
Incredibly, as Jam es recalled later, he went back. He assured one of the gunmen that he already had told the police, as directed, that the arm ed group was to be taken seriously. 
Then, Jam es said, the abductor re­ leased him a second time, saying: 
“ Kiss your wife and baby when you get home.” 

The e x p erien ce, recounted after some of the hostages held in the offices 

 of the Jewish service organization and two other Washington buildings were freed, gave some skimpy clues to the motives and attitudes of the terrorists. 
Jam es, a 28-year-old carpenter who was on a scaffold when gunfire broke out in the building, said that he was released after describing his Irish an­ cestry and stating that he had a family. 
Sim ilarly, Andrew S. Hoffman, a 
2o-year-old university student swept up in the takeover of the building, said that he had been freed after insisting that his family was of Italian extrac­ tion. 
In fact, Hoffman told a rep o rter, 
“ I’m half Jewish but I wasn't about to say I'm half Jewish.” 
Why the in v a d e rs, rep o rte d ly 

 m embers of a mostly black organiza­ tion of Hanafi Moslems, had taken over the Jewish service group's offices was not immediately clear. 
The only tentative connection was an unsuccessful libel action filed against the Anti-Defamation League of B’nai 
B’rith by Bassan Jeru-Aimad, a leader of the Black Men’s Volunteer Libera­ tion Army. 
B assa n a cted as in te rm e d ia ry between officials and one group of gunmen Tuesday. 
In any event, w itnesses to the ta ­ keover said that Jews appeared to have been singled out for capitivity. 
When the episode began at midday, 
Ronald McKenney, another young car­ penter. ran into a boiler room between 

 the first and second floors of the B'nai 
B’rith building. 
P e e rin g out into the hallw ay , 
McKenney said that he and a compan­ ion could sec someone “ swinging a big g u n ” and, a short tim e later, “ We heard a couple shots and saw one man lying on the floor.” 
Movies 
M cKenney re c a lle d having o v e r­ heard one of the intruders say that 
"they wanted them to stop showing movies in New York or some place.” 
The account bolstered reports that the te r r o r is ts w ere try in g to block continued screening of a movie, “ Mo­ hammad, Messenger of God,” depict­ ing the life of the Prophet of Islam. 

M cK enney and his u n id e n tifie d companion crawled through a ceiling trap door and stole out of the building. 
Mayor Walter Washington, who had been barricaded in his office during the shooting and takeover of a section of the District Building, the capital’s equivalent of city hall, somehow made his way to safety. 
Hoffman said that he was passing the site, on his way to a psychology class at George Washington Universi­ ty, when one of the gunmen grabbed him and took him inside the building. 
" T h e lea d e r said so m eo ne had drowned his babies and they shot his wife in the head,” Hoffman recalled. 
"The guy said, ‘i ’m willing to die for this.’ The guy said, ‘If that movie goes 

 on, heads will roll.’” 
The description of the drowning and shootings conformed to details of the slaying in J a n u a r y 1973 of seven members of the Hanafi sect at a house in Washington. 
The killings were ascribed to Black 
Muslims. 
Hoffman said that "the next thing I knew I was in the building, getting shot at and kicked in the face.” There was a welt over one of his eyes. 
He was thrown into an elevator and taken to an upper floor of the building where about 7o other people were being held, Hoffman said. 
He was released but said he was told: 
“ You’d better praise Allah that I ’m letting you go.”

One blast hit 3 

WASHINGTON (AP) - Ap­ parently one blast from the shotgun of a man who invaded the District Building on Wed­ nesday killed a 22-year-old radio news re p o rte r and in ­ jured a city councilman and a security guard

Barricaded doors keep som e from being taken hostage 

ASSOCIATED PRESS 

WASHINTON - “ We’re just sitting here and staring at each other,” a woman barricaded in her fifth floor office at the B'nai 
B’rith building Wednesday said over the telephone. 
The w om an, who asked th a t her name not be used, said there were five women with her, with desks, chairs and bookcases up against the door for protection against gunmen who wen holding hostages in the building. 
Were they scared? 
“ Well, we don’t feel very good about this," she said. 
At about 4:15 p.m. CST she said that everything was quiet and they hadn’t 

 heard any gunshots since before noon. 
She said also they had had no contact with anyone else in the building. 
"W e’re fine. We’re barricaded in,” she said. She added that they had no information about what was going on around them. 
A staff m em ber had gone through the halls before noon telling everyone to barricade them selves in their of­ fices, she said. 
Another woman who answered the telephone in a barricaded office said softly, 
‘‘We d o n ’t have any information. We hear noise. Goodbye,” and hung up. 
The building was one of three sites invaded by bands of rifle m e n , d e ­ scribed as black moslims, in appar­ ently related a ssa u lts.

Logger says neigh to tractors 

SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS— Thursday March IO 1977 
Ex-UAW president due bail hearing 

“ No matter how cold a morning it is, your horse will always start.’’ says 
Alan Kalloch, who favors genuine horsepower over sophisti­ cated tractors for his logging busi­ ness. 
“ A horse has more character than a trac to r,” said Kalloch, 36, of 
Gardiner, Maine. 
Ile said his method for hauling logs is cheaper and less damaging to the en viro nm en t than using skidders or tractors. 
Kalloch and his bro th ers use horses to carry their timber from forests to roads for shipment to mills by truck. A team costs about 
$2,ooo, and the Kallochs build their own sleds and do their own horse­ shoeing. 
Skidders, costing $35,ooo or more, are specially equipped rubber-tired tractors capable of bending in the middle. They're used to gather and haul timber from the woods. 
“There's no way a horse can do everything a skidder can or they’d be no market for $5o,ooo skidders,” 
Kalloch said. 
On the airwaves 
Former Sen. 
James Buckley. 
R-N.Y.. is taking to the airwaves, following the ex a m p le of his brother. William. 
Westinghouse Broadcasting Co. 
Inc. announced Wednesday it has taken on the conservative former senator as a commentator on its 
“ Group W” radio stations. 
Buckley, who was defeated in a re-election bid last year against 
Democrat 
Daniel P. Moynihan. will begin his three-times-a-week commentaries Monday. 

A Delaware County, Pennsylva­ nia, judge has scheduled a bail hearing for Thursday for former 
United Mine Workers President 
W.A. “ Tony” Boyle, who was granted a new trail on charges he ordered the assassination of a union rival. 
Judge 
Francis J. Catania of 
Media said the hearing would at 
1o:3o a.m. at the county courthouse. 
The hearing was requested by 
Boyle's a tto rn e y , 
A. Charles 
Peruto. 
The state Supreme Court, on Jan. 
2«. overturned Boyle's 1974 murder conviction and ordered a new trail for the 75-year-old union leader. 
Boyle was convicted in 1974 of ordering the killing of union rival 
Joseph “ Jock” Yablonski. 
Yab- lonski, his wife and daughter were shot to death in their Washing­ ton County home on New Year’s Eve 
1969. 
Slow getaw ay 

It was anything but a high-speed chase as police pursued and arrest­ ed four suspected burglars. 
St. Croix County Sheriff Charles 
Grant said burglars broke into a greenhouse in Baldwin, Wis., late 
Saturday and took $5. A short time later, he said, they entered an au­ tomatic laundry in nearby Wood­ ville and stole $65. 
Police caught up with the ju­ veniles a short time later as they made their getaway in a tractor pulling a manure spreader. 

Dick Van Dyke and M ary Tyler Moore, who once shared a television series, get together again during the 37th annual anniversary banquet of the International Radio and Television 
Society in New York City. The pair was among a host of CBS stars who appeared at the dinner.

By BILL CUNNINGHAM

A g r ic u ltu r e

President 
Carter's no­ minee for deputy secre­ tary of agriculture. U.S. 
Departm ent of A gricu l­ tu re 's chief said here 
Wednesday.

International Airport by 
Secretary of Agriculture 
Bob Bergland. 
The introduction was m ad e at a p r e s s conference for media co­ vering the 75th national convention of the Nation­ al F arm e rs Union being held here.

Washington

1:oo 3:oo 5:oo 7:oo 9oo 
MANOINGO 
KEN 
ONLY STARTED 
NORTON 

Doug swore off playing in 
San Antonio.” Meyers said. “You can’t blame him for waiting a while before coming back.” 
The pig-tailed m usi­ cian is sketchy concern­ ing the incident’s details, but says it was distasteful enough to make Sahm give up playing in his home town for the last 12 years. 
At the time of the inci­ dent, Sahm and Meyers were members of the Sir 
Douglas Quintet which had just returned to San 
Antonio after a tour to 

 promote its hit record 
“She’s About A Mover." 
The record was a com­ bination of the Latin sounds the group picked up on San Antonio’s West 
Side mixed in with a strong blues beat. 
“ She’s 
About 
A 
Mover” eventually sold more than six million copies. 
“The plan was for us to be the American answer to the Beatles, since we were the only long-haired 
American group around back then,” Meyers says. 
“We started the group 

WITH PAM GRIER! 

STARTS TOMORROW! 

/ (R) 

‘ R id # 
o €fb$ifetow 
Coffy’ 
KOWN IW M 
OUTDOOR THEATER , 
■rut .IWW Whit, i I HO 
HI OM E 

 when we were all in high school and were always dreaming about making it big someday," Meyers adds. 
Alter the group’s ini­ tial success with “ She s 
About A Mover” it went on to record several other national hits. During the 
197os though Sahm and 
Meyers split up to form their own groups. 
At that time Meyers settled in 
Bulverde. where he has occasional­ ly threatened to run for 
Comal County sheriff, and Sahm based his band in Austin. 
But the m usic pro­ duced by Sahm’s Texas 
Tornadoes and Meyer’s 
Western Head Band re­ mains deeply rooted in 
San Antonio. 
In fact Friday night, 
Meyers says, he and 
Sahm will probably treat the audience to a special duet. Meyers would be on accordion and Sahm on

Mexican accordion and since Doug plays bajo, we ii probably get down and play some real San 
Antonio con junto m u­ sic,” he says. 
Joker Moon will open the Texas Theater con­ cert at 7 p.m. 
Sahm and Meyers will appear at 8:3o p.m. Fri­ day at the Texas Theater, 
153 E. Houston St. Tick­ ets arc $4 and $5.

Nueces project due review 

SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS— Thursday March IO 1977 osiong 
H uge ex said intentional 
Shipment 
—Just Arrived— 
4o FT. VAN LOAD 
FROM EUROPE 

WASHINGTON (A P )- 
The Nueces River project iii Live Oak and Mc Mul­ len counties will be re­ viewed before more fe­ deral funds are spent, 
I he Carter administ ra ­ tion announced 
Wednesday. 
The project is one of 27 such projects placed on a list before for review be­ fore any more money is spent. 
One other project on the list is in Texas. That is the Palm etto Bend dam on the Navidad 
River in Jackson County. 

Both Texas projects were placed on the list because their environ­ mental impact state­ ments indicated there would be some adverse' affects if they were built. 

CARLY, Ohio (A P ) - Sheriff Mark 
Kauble said Wednesday he's “ not pointing a finger toward anybody'' in the deliberate explosion of 2o tons of dynamite in a field by a rock quarry where workers are on strike. 
No one was injured in the predawn blast, which was felt IOO miles to the north in Detroit and 7o miles to the south in Columbus, the sheriff said. 
It left a crater IOO feet long by 8o feet wide and 5o feet deep, blew out doors and windows in a five-mile area and left about a dozen families homeless. 
Kauble estimated damage in the thou­ 

 sands of dollars. 
“ Evidence at the scene indicated it was intentionally detonated and vir- tually eliminates the possibility of any accident,” Kauble said 
“ Someone went to a great deal of effort to deton­ ate it.” 

Negotiations on a contract for workers at the quarry were held on 
Tuesday. The strike began Feb. lf). 
Kauble met with representatives of the National Lime and Stone Co. and 
Local 
15o5o-1 of the 
United 
Steelworkers union.

 grabber. And there really w e r e n ’t any Texans at the A lam o,” Wills con­ tinued. 
The Alamo's defenders were officially Mexican c i t i z e n s b e c a u s e th e y pledged their loyalty to the Mexican government when they entered Texas, according to the gravelly voiced character actor. 
Despite the historical i n a c c u r a c i e s in th e movie, Wills said, “ It w as one of th e h es t movies ever made and all of it was made right here in Texas.” 
Wills was n om inate d for an academy award in the film for his role as 
Beekeeper, Crockett’s si­ d e k i c k . C r o c k e t t w as played by John Wayne. 
M utscher inspires new bill 
AUSTIN' 
(AB) 
- 
Rep. Chase Untermeyer, 
R-Houston, said Wednes­ day that convicted House 
S p e ak e r (Jus M u ts c h e r s h o u l d n ’t he a county judge. He introduced a hill to prevent similar si­ tuations in the future. 
U t i t e r m e y e r 's bill would prevent conv icted felons who h av e been released from probation from holding public of­ fice. 
Release from probation expunges an indictment. 
Mutscher was appoint­ ed county judge of W a ­ shington County as soon as he was released from probation last July by an 
Abilene district judge. 
He w as el e c te d to a four-year term in the job in November. 
M u t s c h e r w as convicted in 1973 of con­ spiracy to accept a bribe from p r o m o t e r F r a n k 
Sharp in return for his efforts to pass two bills affecting the Sharpstown 
State Bank.

Wills also said the 
G r e a t e r 
San 
Antonio 
C h a m b e r of C o m m e r c e isn't using the Cradle of 
Texas Liberty to its ful­ lest potential as a tourist attraction. 
“ T h e y ’re m i s s i n g a good bet by not prom ot­ ing the Alamo and- really making it a good d raw ,” he said between sips'o f beer. 
“ The little old ladies who run the Alamo just want their own patch of land and they don’t want an y b o d y to tell t h e m what to do with it.” the native Texan said. 
Prior to the luncheon, 
Wills hushed the group at 
Big J o h n ’s S te a k h o u s e for an announcement— 
“ We just got a message from Dolph Briscoe, he’s still breathing.” 
H o w ev er, Wills the n explained he could make i r r e v e r e n t r e m a r k s about the g o v e r n o r b e ­ cause “ I'm a profession­ al Texan and I joke a r ­ ound a lo t . I just hope people d o n ’t lose t h e i r sense of hum or." 
Wills currently lives in 
California.

* 

At-large challenge dismissed 

A federal judge has dismissed a suit ch al­ lenging San Antonio’s at-large system of elect­ ing 
C ity 
Council members. 
U.S. Dist. Judge D. VV. 
Suttle pointed to the Jan. 
15 city election approving single-member districts in his order. 
Lawyers for the Mexi- can-American Legal De­ fense and Educational 
Fund filed the suit in late 
1973 claim ing the at- large plan discriminated against Mexican-Ameri- ean and black voters. 
In April 197fi the U.S. 

Probers to hear financier 

Eagle Pass financier 
Enrique 
Salinas is scheduled to testify 
Thursday before a feder­ al grand jury probing 
South Texas banking irregularities. 
Salinas owned Citizens 
State Bank in Carrizzo 
Springs before it was closed by state banking officials. 
The collapse of Citizens 
State triggered the mas­ sive state and federal probe of banking prac­ tices. 
Wednesday the grand jury heard from former 
Citizens State officers 
Jim Bob Nance and U r­ ban Farrow and Salinas’ wife, Gretchen. 
A subpoena does not mean the person is a target of the grand jury probe. It only indicates prosecutors believe the person can shed some light on the investigation. 

Justice Department ob­ jected to the at-large plan under the federal Voting 
Hights Act. 
The Department’s Civil 
Hights Division withdrew the objection after the voters adopted the sin­ gle-member district plan in January. 

Dismiss 

Attorneys for the city then moved to have 
Judge Suttle dismiss the suit. 
But M A LD E?’ attorney 
Albert Kaufman opposed dismissal until an elec­ tion under the new plan was held because of threatened court ch al­ lenges to the city charter change. 

But 
Judge 
Suttle 
Tuesday stated, “ The plaintiffs' fears are spe­ culative in the extreme." 
Judge Suttle also den­ ied M A LD EF’s motion to have the city pay attor­ neys' fees in the case. 
He said M ALD E F was not the prevailing side because the case was settled out of court. 

Boy Scout 

 due honors 

An Express-News car­ rier, Patrick Dwyer. 15, will be awarded the Boy 
Scouts of America high­ est award, the Eagle 
Scout, Monday. 

A student at Roosevelt 
High School. Dwver is the sixth m em ber of 
Troop 2H9 to be so hon­ ored and the second E a ­ gle Scout in his family. 

Dwyer is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Mike Dwyer of 
5215 Hound Table. 
Cisneros to be feted 

Councilman Henry Cisneros will be honored at a 
“ Fritanga" from 7-9 p. rn. Friday in the Sacred 
Heart Parish Hall in the 21oo block of West 
Commerce Street. 
Free beer and tacos will be served. 
The function is being hosted by R. E. “ Bob" 
Montalvo, a former Good Government League candidate for the council, and other friends of the councilman, who is running for re-election in 
District I. 
Joe Webb, a candidate for the council from 
District 2, will hold a campaign rally at 6 p. rn. 
Tuesday in the Holy Redeemer Hall, Vargas and 
Nevada Streets. Cost is $5 a person. 
The public is invited to a Meet the Candidate party honoring mayoral candidate John Monfrey at 7:3o p. in. Saturday at Oak Mont Apartments. 39o3 Bar­ rington Dr. Invitations to the function list “ Move­ ment," which calls itself the young adult magazine of San Antonio, as host. 
Candidates invited 

Five mayoral candidates have been invited to participate in a forum sponsored by North Side 
Lu I a cs at 7:3o p. in. Wednesday in the Chapman 
Graduate Center Auditorium, Trinity University.

7-11 p. rn. Friday at Comanche Park No. I. Beer and tamales will be served, and there will be live music.

Hartman denies he would quit 

District 9 City Council candidate Van Henry 
Archer Jr . Wednesday hinted incumbent coun­ cilm an Glen Hartman might take another job soon. a charge Hartman quickly denied. 
Archer said rumors from City Hall indicate 
Hartman, if re-elected, will resign shortly after­ ward to take a job in the 
Carter Administration. 
The empty council post would then be filled by council. 
“ If he is expecting to receive a job with the 
Carter Administration, then fine, but the voters, especially the citizens of 
District 9. have the right to know now," Archer 

Labor union hacks Orliz 

Rudy C. Ortiz, candi­ date for the city council from District H, Wednes- tonal Union of Electrical, 
Radio and 
Machine 
Workers, AFL-CIO, Lo­ cal 7Ktl 

 said, challenging Hart­ man to make his plans known. 
“ The guy (A rcherI is going to In* disappointed if lies banking on that." 
Hartman said from his campaign headquarters 
“ Any hope Archer may have that I will not com­ plete the next term is absolutely nil." Hartman said. adding, “ I intend to win and serve a full two years." 
The councilm an did say, however, he had been approached by 
Carter representatives concerning two high ad­ ministration posts. lie would not say what those positions were be- cause other people are being considered for them, he said. 
“ However, 
I have made the decision that I could tx* more useful to my community by repre­ senting 
D istrict 
9,’’ 
Hartman said. adding he has asked the Carter representatives not to be considered further lur tile jobs

Sprague: I have evidence 

COMPILED FROM WIRE SERVICES 
WASHINGTON — The chief counsel of the House Assassinations Committee said Wednesday he was gathered un­ corroborated 
“ inform ation” suggesting a conspiracy in the murders of bothPresident Kennedy and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King 
Jr. 
Struggling to keep their investiga­ tion alive, committee members con­ vened W ed n esd ay in executive session for a briefing from chief counsel Ri­ chard A Sprague and his aides on the 

 progress of the inquiry so far. 
In a short statement before the press and public were excluded, Sprague told the committee that the informa­ tion compiled to date was a blend of reports from “ witnesses who have advised us directly that they have relevant information” and hearsay about “ witnesses whom we have been told have information.'’ 

As a result, he added in straight- faced understatement, “ We have been unable to do what I would consider a 

 thorough cheek of the information we have been advised of.” 
The former Philadelphia prosecutor continued, “ The sum total of the in­ formation would be in the nature of evidence indicating that others may have had know ledge of or participated in arranging the assassinations of Dr. 
King and President Kennedy.” 

Sprague did not elaborate, but it seemed likely that much of the infor­ mation originated with the many books and articles written in recent years in 

 attempts to debunk the official find­ ings that there was no credible evi­ dence of a conspiracy in either murder. 

Trying to regain its momentum fol­ lowing the resignation of Rep. Henry 
B. Gonzalez (D.-Tex.), who tried to fire 
Sprague for alleged mismanagement and insubordination, the committee met formally Wednesday for the first time under its new chairman. Rep. 
Louis Stokes, D-Ohio. 
Stokes would say only that the infor­ 

 mation was “ highly speculative, “ and that it was too early to know whether it could be verified or where it might lead. 

He said the committtee, which still must prove to the House that its pro­ posed inquiries into the two assassina­ tions are justified, faces the task of sifting through “ many leads” • that already have come to it. and must re­ gain access to F B I and other govern­ ment agency files. 
REP. LOUIS STOKES 
. . . starting at zero 

U.S. blasts 
Chilean rights 

COMPILED FROM WIRE SERVICES 

G EN EV A - Brady Ty­ son, Methodist mission­ ary turned diplomat, cast tin* 
Am erican vote 
Wednesday for an over­ whelming United Nations commission condemna­ tion of Chile for “ flagrant vio latio ns" of human rights. 
Tyson also demanded a 
I'N . inquiry into allega­ tions of torture, kidnap­ ing and other human rights violations in Uru­ guay, Argentina, Pa ra ­ guay and Brazil, drawing sizzling retorts from the four. 
At prev ious sessions of the U.N. human rights body, the United States abstained on resolutions critical of Chile. U.S. delegates have often ac­ cused the commission of concentrating on a hand­ ful of rights violators while overlooking major ones like the Soviet 
Union. 
Earlier in the-day, Ty­ son told reporters at the 
Palais des Nalionas that he had “ exceeded in ­ structio ns" from W a­ shington in making a statement at Tuesday's meeting of the U.N. 
Human Rights Commis­ sion in which he ex­ pressed “ profound re­ grets” on the part of the 
United States for “ the role some government officials, agencies and private groups” played in the overthrow of the pro-Marxist Chilean re­ gime of Salvador Allende 

 iii 1973. 

Disavowed 

Tyson’s statement was promptly disavowed by the Department of State on Tuesday night, a few hours after his remarks to the U.N. commission. 
President Carter then followed this at his press conference Wednesday by declaring the LLS. representative’s com ­ ments to be “ inadmissi­ ble.” Tyson, a political appointee in the No. 2 slot on the American delega­ tion to the annual Human 
Rights Commission deli­ berations here iii Geneva, 
Hies back to New York 
Thursday where he is on the U.N. delegation staff of Ambassador Andrew 
Young. 

CARTER 

Continued from Page IA 

 hint of Soviet agreement to these or other, previously disclosed arms con­ trol suggestions he has made, includ­ ing a comprehensive ban on nuclear tests and prior notification of test missile launchings. 
He also said lit* had no indication that the Russians have withdrawn their op­ posing to a quick SALT II agreeemnt that bypasses the difficult questions of the U.S. cruise missiles and Soviet 
Backfire bombers. 
Carter said he has proposed to the 
Russians “ directly and indirectly . . . publicly and privately'' that the two countries try to reach early agreement on arms control matters on which arc relatively uncontroversial as a sign of good faith. But he added that "none of tuem are very easy.’’ 

Korea withdrawal 
The press conference also brought 
C arter's first public reaffirm ation since becoming President of his long­ standing campaign oposition that U.S. ground troops should be withdrawn from South Korea over a four- or five-year period. “ I am very deter­ mined” to take this action, he de­ clared. 
About two hours after Carter spoke. 
Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance of- 
AQUIFER 

C ontinued from Page LA 

 through which water returns to re­ charge the underground reservoir. 
Controls are supposed to minimize the chance of pollution in that sensitive recharge zone. 
The aquifer itself stretches through the seven counties without regard for political boundaries aud should be treated as a single formation subject to unified pollution control efforts, the suit contends. 
H ill’s petition — apart from the ar­ bitrary. capricious and unreasonable contention — argues that separate order violate the equal protection clauses of both state and federal con­ stitutions. 
In an opening comment. H ill’s peti­ tion warns: 
“ Contamination of the reservoir would be difficult or impossible to re­ verse and would pose a significant ha­ zard to those people dependent on the reservoir for drinking purposes.” 

M anagem ent sem inar due 

The University of Texas at San An­ tonio’s Division of Continuing Educa­ tion will sponsor a seminar Thursday entitled “ The Manager as Coach and 
Counselor." 
Fee for the seminar to be held from 
8:311 a.in. to 4:3(1 p.m. iii the Lutcher 
Conference Center is Sad 
Topics will include Understanding 
Communication and Perception. The 
World of Feelings and Inter and Intru- 

 fit ia I iv notified South Korean Foreign 
Minister Park Tong-jin of the govern­ ment's decision to remove the ground forces on a schedule not yet deter­ mined. 
Vance told the Korean in a State De­ partment meeting that detailed U.S. plans should be ready for discussion with the Seoul government late this spring, informed sources said. 
Park reportedly did not seek to dis­ suade the 
United 
States from withdrawing the troops but expressed concern that there be no mistake in 
North Korea or elsewhere about the continuing U.S. security commitment to Seoul. 
Carter met for 43 minutes late 
Wednesday at the White House with 
Park on both troop withdrawal and human rights questions. 
Carter said at his news confrerenee that lie had previously discussed the withdrawal of ground troops with Gen. 
John VV. Vessev Jr ., the U.S. com­ mander in South Korea. The meeting took place Feb. IS. 

Reclassified 

Officials said studies are under way 
• to determine how many of the 4o,Odd 
U.S. troops in South Korea w ill lie classified as “ ground forces” to he withdrawn. 
About 14.Odd men are in the Second 
Infantry Division, the m ajor U.S. ground combat unit, with many thou­ sands of others in support units. 
Iii previous statements Carter and 
V ance has suggested that LLS Air 
Force personnel — which currently number about 9,ooo — would be left in 
Korea and some proposals have been made that they be augmented to show 
U.S. determination. 
Carter said at his press conference that “ I would envision a continuation of American air cover for South Korea over a long period of time” but he did not specifically say whether the air cover would be based there or outside the country. 
The White House said late Wednes­ day that ' arter told the Korean minis­ ter that U.S. troops will be withdrawn 
• iii a manner that will not upset the military balance on the Korean penin­ sula. 

Deep concern 

The White House statement also said the president had expressed “ deep concern” about human rights in Kor­ ea, where a number of leading citizens including the only liv ing ex-president are imprisoned or under house arrest for their criticism of President Park 
Chung Hc*e. 
Carter reaffirmed at his news con­ ference his “ deepest possible personal commitment” to the cau se of human rights throughout the world. 
As part of the U.S. effort to put its own house iii order, he announced the removal of the ban on travel by U.S. citizens to Cuba, Vietnam, Cambodia and North Korea. 
The president rejected as "inappro­ priate” the statement of Brady Tyson, deputy chief of the U.S. delegation to the U N. Human Rights Commission, apologizing for U.S. involvement iii 
Chile.

San Antonio Express 
EDITORIALS 

W illia m J 
R e d d e ll 

E d i t o r o f E d i t o r i a l P a g e

K ilp a trick 
Editor a n d P u b liih er 

G e o r g e C a rm a c k 

A sso c ia te E d i t o r 

 fa n e I 
Burt 

M a n a g i n g E d i t o r 
Help the candidates walk the districts 

City c a n d id a te are meeting citizens in forums and on the doorsteps in the first elections involving sin g le -m e m b e r d is ­ tricts in modern times The ex­ perience is interesting on all sides. 
Council candidates are walk­ ing their districts We hope citi­ zens will take tim e to get a c ­ quainted and ask questions. To help in the process, we suggest candidates be asked about the 
City C harter (w hether further revision is on c a n d id a te s ' agenda), about their views on the city's needs (bond issues for drainage or other work, for ex­ am ple), their views on w ater resources and what influence the referendum on a superman over the aquifer might have on them. 
M ercifully, not all the KU candidates are serious. Not even all nine in the mayoral race are serious, so householders can re­ ceive the candidates with some sense of security and knowledge that they will not be subjected to an infestation. 
The candidates who are s e r­ ious will re sp o n d to can d id questions. They will bt* brief because they have a long way to go in a short space of time, lf 
Ahey ramble or evade, instead of answer directly, it is a good sign 

 that they a r e n 't re a d y for a council seat. 
But citizens should be r e a ­ sonable, too. City*Council can’t r e g u la te the price of n a tu ra l gas, it can't do anything about 
Social Security or federal taxes. 
Some otherwise well-informed persons d o n 't know that. A caller this week threatened to take a matter up with “ Senator 
•John Tower in Austin.” Tower is in Washington. 
City Council is in San Antonio and its authority is limited to 
San Antonio. Some candidates, even, don't seem to recognize that fact. 
State law covers the reporting of financial support to the can­ didates but legislators, t h e m ­ selves subject to the election p rocess, have left enough loopholes to hide sources of fin­ ancial support until after the election. So questions about fin­ ancial support may not be ac ­ c u ra te by all can d id ate s, but they should be asked, if that makes any difference to a voter. 

District election of council members will be an interesting c h a p t e r in San A n tonio’s a l ­ w ays-interesting politics. We hope it works out well, starting with m ore voter interest than usual. 
Secretary Califano wants public views about welfare 

HEW Secretary .Joseph Cali- fano will conduct a public hear­ ing in Washington Thursday on welfare reform . That hearing will start a national attempt to find a better way to cope with social benefits with a c u rre n t budget of $134 billion a year. 
Califano's hearing may sti­ mulate Americans to offer sug­ gestions. For those who wish to suggest, the lh regional h ead ­ quarters of HEW will collect and forward written comments. 
T exans should respond to 
Dan Heed, AUDIT’, HEW. 12oo 
Main Tower Bldg., Dallas 752o2. 
Comments should be mailed on or before Mardi 22. 
( alifano was principal author of much of the welfare program now in force. President Carter called him back into service and gave him the job of trying to correct what went w rong. 
Main trouble spots to get at­ 

 tention are likely to be benefit levels, re la tio n s h ip betw een welfare and the labor market, appropriate roles for various le­ vels of government, impact of welfare upon families, relation­ ship between welfare and social services, and the m anagem ent of the welfare services. 

Persons with experience with 
I lit* system should have sugges­ tions, based on that experience. 
A knotty problem has been the tendency of welfare families to remain on welfare. The sys­ tem should encourage people to get off welfare and that will be one of the problems addressed iii reform. 

But here s a chance to drop a viewpoint on Washington. The suggestions will be a part of the debate on how to better manage the national system that some say is out of control. 
Fatal cave-ins need a remedy 

Cave-ins during excavation and ditching work in San An­ tonio are not uncommon. 

It is, therefore, puzzling why relatively-si rn pie e q u ip m e n t isn’t a routine part of tile tools of the trade Some sort of steel shields, with jacks to b race them against the sides of exca­ vations, should be relatively 

Texaco denial 

 easy to design and install where workmen are to be in the ditch. 
P o rta b le b ra c e s could be quickly set in place and hoisted out when workmen are back on the surface. Two cave-ins this week m e re ly u n d e r s c o r e the dangerous soil conditions, but there is scarcely a year goes by without one or more fatal inci­ dents. 

Sir: As most people are aware, alle­ gations and accusations hit the head­ lines. Replies and rebuttals seldom catch up with the charges. 
Recently, allegations have been made that Texaco has withheld sub­ stantial amounts of natural gas from two fields in the Gulf of Mexico. Texa­ co categorically denies this charge and m akes the following statem ents in response: 
Texaco is producing at maximum capability from existing wells in these two fields — Tiger Shoal and Light­ house Point — in the Gulf of Mexico. 
During the recent emergency Texaco fully performed its contractual com­ mitments to its pipeline customers from th ese fields, 
T ex as 
G as 
Transmission Corp. and Natural Gas 
Pipeline Company of America. 
Gas in these fields has been com­ mitted either to these interstate pipe­ lines under long-term contracts or reserved for use iii Texaco’s refinery at P o rt A rth u r. The p rices are determined hoth by contract and by 
Federal Power Commission orders. lf Texaco were to accelerate produc­ tion from these fields, we would use up reserves needed to meet future re­ quirements. 'I'liis would be a “ Dram 
America Now" policy which would be disastrous to future consumer needs. 
Allegations have been made that 
Texaco could have drilled additional wells and produced additional gas. lf we had done so, the additional gas production would amount to less than I per cent of Texaco’s total daily gas deliveries in the United States. More importantly, we would have had to divert capital and drilling rigs being used in the search of new reserves. 
With respect to Tiger Shoal and 
Lighthouse Point areas, they are pri­ marily federal leases. The develop­ ment and sale of gas from such leases is under federal jurisdiction. 
It is significant to note that during the past seven years Texaco has in­ vested almost $1.5 billion iii the search for oil and gas in the Gulf of Mexico 
That this search has been successful is shown by the fact that during ibis period Texaco has more than doubled its federal offshore gas production from ibis area. 
In T exaco’s view, false ch arg es simply confuse the American people and delay development of sound po­ licies. 
K. E. Wright, 
Vice President, Texaco. Inc. 
Houston 

Highway fund action backet! 

Sir: Recent editorials in the San 
Antonio Express have questioned tilt* need for early action by the Texas 
Senate on the Texas highway funding crisis. it is a well-documented fact that there is a serious emergency in the state highway program. Gov. Dolph 
Briscoe acted wisely iii proposing emergency legislation to respond to the crisis. 
The legislature has not increased highway funds iii over 2o years.

Present highway revenues are inade­ quate to properly maintain the existing system, much less improve it to meet anticipated growth. Obsolete roads and bridges are a major factor in the Texas traffic death rate which is higher than the national average. 

Further delays in providing addi-’ tional highway funds will only increase the ultimate cost of rehabilitating our stale highway system. 
Euguene VV. Robbins 
President, Good Roads Assn. 
(NOTE: Our argument is that until there is substantial agreement on a division of available funds, major appropriations should be held in check.) 

Let’s dem and help for UTSA 

Sir. When we pass the impressive array of new buildings on the UTSA campus and recall the groat hopes for a great South Texas university, the current faculty cutbacks being pro­ posed seem poignantly disillusioning. 
The UTSA president has responded to budget restraints from Austin by noti­ fying about 4(1 faculty members (tem ­ porary or part-time appointees) not to expect contract renewals next fall. 
How can a new university grow to its full p oten tial w ithout a d e q u a te faculty? Already many classes arc substantially larger than other arca universities will tolerate, and indivi­ dual contacts with students naturally suffer. Lacking sufficient fulltim e permanent appointm ents UTSA su r­ vives partly on its tem porary and part-time teachers. Those are now be­ ing threatened with layoffs. 
Should not this community demand the first-class treatment from Austin that other Texas cities get and insist that the investment in intellectual potential at UTSA at least match its investment in physical plant? 
( harles ll. lleimsath

It’s time 
Meany leaves scene 

WASHINGTON — It) a recent survey of American institutions, our estimable ('(ingress ranked third from (he bottom in public 
■ regard. 
Beneath Congress was Big Business. 
Beneath business, in the stygian darkness below, dwelt Big Labor. 
Labor’s diminished reputation is ea­ sily traceable to the headlines of the decade jiast : 
“ Hospital workers strike; patients left u n a tte n d e d ,’’ “ T e a c h e rs walk out.” “ Transit workers reject offer, traffic tie-ups m ount," "Police, fire­ men in job action." 
Famous telegram 
In his fam ou s te le g ra m to Sam 
G om pers d u ring the Boston police strike, Cal Coolidge wrote, "There is no right to strike against the public safety by anybody, an y w h ere, any time." 
The devil there ain’t, is Big Labor’s attitude in 1977. 
At the tu rn of the c e n tu ry , the leaders of labor were looked upon by the w orking class, not unfairly, as their courageous and battling benefac­ tors. 
The im age of Big Labor changed becau se the m en w ithin it have changed. 
Labor’s clout 
Long ago. Big Labor’s political clout eclipsed that of business. 
When George Meany bangs the table, presidents of the United States sit up and listen. 
Who now pays attention to the press releases of the Business Round Table or the U.S. Chamber of Commerce? 
A century ago the men in Congress were owned by railroad, timber, min­ ing and textile interests. 
Today, a majority depend for survi­ val upon the money, m anpow er and good will of organized labor. 
Several years ago, a grateful Sen. 
Harrison Williams, chairm an of the 
Labor and Public Welfare Committee, poured out his heart to the purring latents of organized labor. 
"I owe everything to you. What you want, you’ve got.’’ 
And what does labor want? 
Agenda 
Consider the agenda drafted by the 
Old Men of the Seashore at their an­ nual conclave at Bal H arbour, Fla., two weeks ago. 
The minimum wage must he raised from $2.3o to $3 ail hour, d em a n d s 
Meany. 
U u s “ reform " would instantly eli­ m inate the jobs of thousands of the le a st-educated, least-skilled of our workers — putting men aud their fa­ milies “ at the bottom of the economic pyramid’’ forever on the public dole. 
T hree dollars an hour m ean s, as well, postponement for years of entry into the labor market by teen-agers — black and white. 
"It has always been a m ystery to m e,” says the Nobel P rize w inner, economist Milton Friedm an, "why a teen-ager is better off unemployed at 
$2.3D an hour rather than employed at. say, $2." 
Tatt-Hartley 
Section 14(h) of Taft-Hartley must he repealed, demands labor. 
This is the section which allows in­ dividual states to decide if unions shall 
Ik* allowed to force workers to join — as a condition of holding a job. 
Twenty states have enacted, demo­ cratically, such “ right-to-work" laws. 
What Meany wants is precisely what the Robber Barons of a century ago demanded: The right to dictate the decision as to whether the individual worker can belong to a union 
A Hurd labor dem an d is for the common situs picketing legislation ve­ toed by President Ford late ut 1975. 
Tilts would give a single tiny union the power — denied it by the Supreme 
Court a quarter century ago — to shut down an entire project, like the Alaska pipeline, over a single grievance. 

Pack court 

 lf Congress falls to deliver, says 
Jerry Wurf of the municipal and state employes union, "The answer may he to do vvhat Roosevelt did — pack the 
S up rem e Court with new a p p o in t­ ments." 
“ Our timetable in this area is infin­ ity," retorts the octogenarian leader of Big Labor, 
This domestic agenda is scandalous aud re a c tio n a ry — e n h a n c in g the powerful at the expense of the weak. 
Like the porcine leaders of the barn­ yard revolution in Orwell’s "Animal 
F arm ," the union chiefs have come to resemble in attitude, power and ap ­ p a ra n c e the very captains of industry and finance whom they have displaced 
During a long lifetime, Meany has done lits m ovem ent and hts nation great se n tee 
Unlike some businessm en, he has never lusted after the quick profits to he made in trade with t ommunist despots 
Bul the time lias come for a grateful nation til say farewell to Mr. Labor, mixing the biblical with the modern 
Welt done thou gtMid and faithful ser­ vant, hut go, man, go.

NEW YORK — Tile final round is over. 
Tw ice-convicted m u rd e re r Rubin 
H urricane” ( arter is back in maxi­ mum security ut Trenton. N.J., State 
Prison. 
He is lur from the bright lights and adulating rock concert crowds at Ma­ dison Square Garden and the Astro­ dome in Houston. 
Gone also are the Hurricane Carter 
T -sh irts, b u m p e r stic k e rs and life-sized posters that proclaimed the image of a proud black man victimized by a white police frame-up in an era of racial strife. 
Iii place of these trappings of a na­ tional cause celebre is a shell of a de­ fense foundation beset by internal strife, possessing little more than the bittersweet memories of the frenetic rallies, marches, benefit concerts and demonstrations that propelled Carter 

Twice-convicted m urderer and one-time prizefighter Rubin ‘‘Hur­ ricane” Carter is back in prison. 

Authorities now are beginning to question the financing of the biggest and most slickly packaged cause- oriented m edia blitz in recent times. 

Two concerts yielded more than half a million dollars in box office receipts, hut only about $65,ooo found its way to the lawyers who defended Carter and another defen­ dant, John Artis. 

This is the first of a two-part series on the concerts to aid Carter. 

 and his co-defendant. John Artis, into the status of folk heroes. 
Also. the authorities are beginning to ask questions about the financing of the biggest and most slickly packaged cause-oriented media blitz in recent times. 
Two star-studded benefit rock con­ certs — in New York and Houston — yielded m ore than half a m illion dollars in box office receipts for the defense of Carter and Artis. 
But only about $65,ooo found its way to the lawyers who defended the two men at their retrial in Paterson, N.J., for first-degree m urder, which ended with new se n te n c e s of life imprisonment for both. 
The rest — a c c o rd in g to the a c ­ counting records of the Freedom for 
Rickover 
’won’t mind his business’ 

Adm. Hyman G. R ick o \e r is known as the “ Father of the Nu­ clear Submarine.” 

Over the years he has become one of the most controversial men in the 
Navy’s history. 

This is the last in a four-part series about the admiral. 

IOS ANGtlES TIMIS StRVICt 
WASHINGTON - A common complaint about Adm. Hyman 
G. Rickover since he ramrodded the nuclear Navy into existence has been that he will not stick to his own business. 
Retired Adm. Arleigh Burke, who was chief of naval operations from 1955 until 1961. said Rickover tried to kill a new aircraft carrier — later named the 
John F. Kennedy — when it was de­ cided not to make it nuclear powered, 
“ I didn’t want to retire him. I just wanted him to stay in his own baliwick and stop extending himself beyond ins own capabilities. Rick just c a n ’t let loose of anything.” Burke said. 
A fight w ith the shipyards over costs is only the problem of the moment between Rickover and the Navy. 
The real reason the service aud the 
Pentagon hierarchy detest Rickover is that they cannot control him. 
Johnny-comelately 

They cannot control him because, compared to the adm iral, everybody else on the scene is a Johnny-com-la- tely. 
“ Ile raises the people around him like an old m o th e r hen with tier chicks,” said one official. 
Ever since the nuclear subm arine program became a going enterprise, 
Rickover has had lits choice of the best and brightest young officers iii the 
Navy. 
Ile has now handpicked and trained some 6.(MMI of them. As the years go by, more and more of the Navy's ranking officers have had their tickets punched by Rickover on the way up. 
Said Adm. Elmo Zumwult. a former chief of naval operations, “ It is going to be increasingly difficult in the years ahead to visualize a Navy in which m ost of the s e n io r people a re not 
Rickover graduates.” 
His survival 
Rickover has survived because lie had both understanding and contempt for the federal bureaucracy. 
He succeeded because lie was tough, because he was a veteran actor su r­ rounded by bit players, because lie mocked the rules 
He terrified young men like Jimmy 
I arter, who applied for his program 
When they reached the final elimin­ ation, the Navy's sharpest young men were called to his sp artan office to explain why they had not done belter. 
William lf. Anderson, later to be­ come famous for guiding the subm ar­ ine Nautilus beneath the North Pule, was so rattled by Rickover’s interro­ gation that he could not rem em ber a single book he had read 
He was later selected by Rtckover when he went home and wrote the ad­ miral a letter, attem pting to explain why his memory had abandoned hun. 
Veils at young 
Rickover yelled ut the young Navy men and threw them out ut Ins office. 
Ile m ade them wail for him for hours, then examined them like c ri­ m inal su sp e c ts us they sat in a straight-hacked chair wuh the sunlight streaming into their faces 
TIh* object was lo see them as they really were 
A survivor ut the interview , who later served for a dozen years as a nuclear su b m a rin e olficer, still re* 

 rn 

All Forever Foundation — has been spent for expenses and overhead. 
The New York State Attorney Gen­ eral's office, acting on an audit of the foundation made by the charities unit of the State Board of Social Welfare, has begun an in v e stig a tio n of the fund's expense claims. 
Called insulting 
Moreover, Rep. Edward I. Koch, D- 
N.Y., saying that the expenditures for one benefit concert are “ insulting to one’s sensibilities.” has asked the In­ ternal Revenue Service to look to the matter. 

Koch, who requested the state in­ vestigation. said he will also draft fe­ deral legislation to im pose tig h te r controls over fund-raising and provide for spot-checking of the expense re ­ cords of all charitable organizations. 

Referring to the Jan. 25. 1976. “ Night of the H urricane’’ benefit concert in 
Houston, which had box office receipts of $339,788 but claimed a net loss of 
$48,777 a fte r ex p en ses, Koch co m ­ plained. “ What arrogance. They list these expenditures, but nobody checks them. Who knows if they really paid out for those expenses? Who knows where that money really went?” 
Witch hunt’ 
The sponsors of the C a rter-A rtis benefits claim they are the victims of a 
"witch hunt” and say they can prove the legitimacy of their expenses. 
They also claim , in effect, that it takes money to raise money, and that the two defendants have benefitted from expert legal counsel they other­ wise could not have afforded. 

‘‘I don’t feel we have anything to hide. Our purpose went beyond just paying law yers’ fees. It was to call attention to the apparent abuse of civil liberties, and I think we succeeded." said John Webster, vice president and a director of Freedom for All Forever. 

The origin of the Carter and Artis media campaign was “ The Sixteenth 
Round," Carter’s autobiography, pub­ lished in 1974. 
It is an emotional account of growing 

 up in a Paterson ghetto, becoming a contender for the middleweight boxing crown and then being arrested for a triple murder in a local bar. 
C arter and Artis were accused of walking into a bar at 2:3o a.m. on June 
17, 1966. and opening fire with a shot­ gun and a revolver, randomly killing th ree w hite persons and serio u sly wounding another. 
The case, tried in the atmosphere of racial unrest, hinged on the testimony of a convicted burglar. Alfred Bello. who said he saw C a rte r and A rtis walking around the corner from the bar. waving guns and laughing. 
Bello, according to his own account, was a lookout for a burglary of a sheet metal company across the street. 
But in 
1974 he re c a n te d his eyewitness version in conversations with defense lawyers and in interviews with Selvvyn Raab, an investigative repo rter for The New York T im es. 
Raab is noted for a book on which the 
TV series “ Kojak” is based. 
Amidst charges that the recantation was elicited with promises of money aud plea-b arg ain in g deals. Bellow later reversed Ids stance and offered testim ony at the second tria l that helped re-convict Carter and Artis. 
Major difference 
The m ajor difference between the two trials was that the prosecution suggested no motive for m urder in the 
1966 proceedings; Kl years later, the prosecution seemed to draw heavily upon the racial assertions contained in 
C arter’s autobiography, and claimed that the whites in the Paterson bar were killed in revenge for the earlier slaying of a black man. 
Against this backdrop. C arter’s au­ tobiography became an instant best­ seller among the causists, and the plight of Carter and Artis was brought to the attention of George Lois, an unconven­ tional Manhattan advertising man who has helped sell off-track betting. Cutty 
Sark Scotch, Esquire magazine and 
Robert F. Kennedy as a candidate for the Senate from New York. 
Luis heads a 
F ifth 
A venue advertising firm Lois. Holland. Cal­ laway — with $32 million a year in accounts. 
‘T m on this com m ittee because I believe Rubin Carter is innocent and I happen to be an advertising guy who happened to get involved,” Lois said when Freedom for AU F orever was established. 
Luis now re p e a te d ly re fu se s to answer telephone inquiries.

“ It is a pleasant task for me to present the preacher for our noon service,” says the large black man standing be­ hind the pulpit at New Mount 
Pleasant Baptist Church. 
“ We have known for some time his ability to preach, and w e’ve been blessed by the words that have fallen from his lips. 
“ So without long preliminaries. I give you our evangelist and our frien d , the p a sto r of St. Jo hn 
Baptist Church in Corpus Christi, the Rev. Dr. Harold T. Branch. 
“ Let's receive him with an A- men.” ’ 
“ A-men.” responds the congre­ gation as a sm iling m iddle-aged man steps to the microphone 
Church foyer 
He is dapperly dressed and looks somewhat younger than his picture on the poster in the church foyer — the one that says: “ City-wide Rev i­ val. sponsored by the Baptist Min­ isters Union — Services at noon daily, March 7-11.” 
He b eg in s by apo log izin g for keeping the congregation so long the day b efo re, and the people m urm ur appreciatively. 
“ I w asn ’t considerate of those who had a desire to hear the bene­ diction a little sooner,” he says, 
“ and I pray that Til do better to­ day." 
"A m e n ,” shouts a man on the second row, and everyone laughs. 
The good humor lusts for the next hour as the m in ister alternately entertains and exhorts the congre­ gation. aided by m em bers of the audience. 
My, my, my 
“ I read a newspaper article about a man writing a doctor and inquir­ ing about Hie change of life.” be says. 
“ My, m y, my,” re sp o n d s a member of the congregation. 
“ He had great apprehension...” 
“ Uh-huli. Tell us. pastor." 
“ He was afraid about the loss of his |lower....” 
The congregation is quiet for a 

 second. Then a woman shouts: “ Fix it doctor. Fix it.” 
The room rocks with la u g h ter while the preacher tries to make a point about God leading his people through times of fear. 
Ii is the first of a series of home­ spun theological aphorisms which keep the congregation buzzing with my-mv-mys, uh-huhs and amens.

“ T h ere w as a tim e when I thought the Lord couldn’t use me if 
I d id n ’t have long u n d e rw e a r, a white shirt and suspenders,” says the preacher. “ But Eve com e to re a lize God d o e sn ’t depen d on things like that."

“ When I was in s e m in a ry , there were these twin g irls who were lovely creatures. And all the seminarians desired them. 
Blit whenever you saw these two girls, their m am a and their aunt and their uncle and their cousins were always there. So you never had a chance to be alone with them.

Baptists 

• “ We Baptists say we don't have any litu rg y , but you ju st try to change the order of the w orship service. O ur liturg y is so fixed w e’ve p ro g ra m m e d w here God comes in.” 
The c o n g re g a tio n la u g h s and there is a smattering of spontaneous applause at the thought of the Al­ m ighty being e sc o rte d into the church between the offertory and the special music. 
The preacher smiles and nods his head, acknowledging the crow d’s response. Then he continues his virtuoso perform ance for several more minutes before finally calling for a closing hymn.

Jehovah” echo through the sanc­ tuary, a woman sitting n e a r the hack of the auditorium leans over and asks her companion if she has eaten yet.
