ADM. H Y M A N RICKOVER 
. . . draw s com plaints 

 members how he guessed and missed the population of his hom etow n of 
Vallejo, ( alif. 
After he guessed, Rickover’s secre­ tary looked ut) the precise answer and quickly recited it to the admiral. 
Rickover looked across Hie desk and shouted in his reedy voice, “ I told you I just wanted the truth. Don’t answer me unless you know what you are talking about." 
The same young man subsequently was given early pro m o tio ns, la ter commended by Rickover for his en­ gineering skills. 
When he left the Navy, he poured out 
Ins heart to the adm iral in a letter. saying that serving under him had been the most important experience of his life. 
The only reply he ever received was a one liner — “ You are out of your mind." 
The next time he saw Rickover, it was on Capitol Hill. 
IU* hold out his hand in greeting and all Rickover said was. “ Get out of my way.” 
While Rickover is tough on subm ar­ ine officers at sea, he is tougher on the technical men who work more closely with him. 
Engineer 
An engineer associated with Rick­ over for years — and speaks of him with reverence lung after leaving his organization — recalls that in his first 
IU years of m arriage he spent more nights working with Rickover than he did at home with his wife, 
Rickover has driven his subordin­ ates, but he has also driven himself 
A congressional investigator who used to travel from one shipyard to another, recalls 
“ Everywhere I went Rickover had just been there 
“ lie d go out of W ashington on a 
Friday afternoon, travel m u s t of the night, work a shipyard on Saturday and Sunday, travel through the night on Sunday night, then la* in Ins office first thing Monday morning.” 
Found yelling 
Shipyard presidents often arrived al their offices to answer their first cull of the week and to find Rickover yelling about things he had found wrong over the weekend rile new P re sid e n t of the United 
Slates tells with admiration how Rick­ over, at 77. still walks four miles each day, huw after a minor hernia opera­ tion. he was up within hours to walk two mile- 
"At one p o in t,” President C a rte r said, * he was not able to lake Ins ex e ro se according to Ins routine of lour miles a day. 
"When he recovered, he had missed 
2U da.vs. so he walked an extra 8U miles to m ak e up for the day s he had missed1 tit ii o f aeries 

 has a magic ring to Kurds 

MANCHtSTER GUARDIAN StRVlCt 
HAJ OMRAN, Iraq — Haj Omran is a p rim itive, w ind-sw ept ham let of mud- walled huts and largely illiterate inhabitants. 
It is in one of the wilder corners of the Middle 
East. 
For most Kurds, Raj Omran has u magic ring. 
It is Hie last outpost on the Iraqi side of what was once the Burzuni Trail, the winding mountain pass that kept the Kurdish rebellion, in its lust great struggle with the central government in Baghdad, supplied with arm s and am m unition from neigh­ boring Iran. 
Little traffic 
Very little traffic comes that way now. since the collapse a year ago of the Kurdish revolt and the 

Some Kurds, warily taking ad­ vantage o f an Iratji amnesty offer, are returning to a situa­ tion o f mixed disappointment and improvements. 

 self-exile of the Kurdish rebel leader. Gen Mustafa 
Barzuni. 
But some Kurds, warily taking advantage of an 
Iraqi amnesty offer, are returning to a situation of mixed disappointment and improvements. 
At Raj Omran the stone buildings were once a stronghold of the guerrilla chieftain. 
Now an Iraqi colonel has converted them into his local headquarters, a showpiece of vigorous saluting and regimental discipline, where once the rebel 
Pesh Merga soldiers nulled about iii the tree and easy manner of irregular armies. 
Slogans 
Buuthibt slogans greet you at every turn of the 
British-built road; so do pictures of President Rimed 
Bassan Bakr and \ ice President Sidduiu. 
Prospects for a renewal of the rebellion, and the fulfillment of Kurdish yalioual aspirations, look bleak, although some local militants have resumed small-scale, hit-and-run raids on police posts and vehicles. 
As far us Iraq is concerned, the future of this vital oil-rich urea has been settled once aud for all: It is irrevocably Arab. 
Freshly painted signs proclaim the procincus new name: 
T a m e e m . m e a n in g n a tio n a liz a tio n ; predominantly Kurdish districts of it have been detached to join other regions 
Autonomy 
The Kurds who are re tu rn in g here are being granted some autonomy, but it is a strictly rationed autonomy under the unm istakable control of the central government in Baghdad. 
The government has ceded certain cultural rights such as the teaching of Kurdish iii schools, and 
Kurdish-ianguage unbound television programs 
Nevertheless, for Kurds who have returned, the situation is latter than before. 
Government officials never lire of repeating what appears to U* true; Iraq has done more. in principle aud limited practice, to recognize Kurdish national rights than either of its neighbors. Iran and Turkey, whose Kurdish minorities are much larger.

SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS— Thursday March IO 1977 
Calvert to receive 
B ’nai B ’rith honor 

SENIOR tech n ician L eo n ard A c k e rm a n checks special research com bustion cham ber 

SPECIAL TO THE EXPRESS 

WASHINGTON — San Antonian Richard 
W. Calvert is to be honored by B ’nai B rith with its coveted Humanitarian Award. 

Calvert, chairman of the board of National Bank of 
Commerce, w ill be cited for outstanding community service at a testimonial dinner May 5 at San Anton­ io’s Turtle Creek Country Club. 

The tribute was announced, here by David M 
B lu m b e rg , in te rn a tio n a l president of the 
5oo,ooo-member Jewish service organization. 
Dinner chairman 

M artin Goland, president of Southwest Research 
Institute in San Antonio, will serve as general dinner chairman. 

The dinner in C alvert’s honor will help support 
B ’nai B rith Youth Services. W ith a $111 m illion annual budget, the organization supports a wide range of cultural, civie and brotherhood actu bes for 

 young people. 
The B’nai B’rith Hillel Foundations serve students on more than 3oo campuses, including the Universi­ ty of Texas, San Antonio College. Texas A&M Uni­ versity. University of Houston and Rice University. 

The B ’nai B ’rith Youth Organization conducts programs for teenagers in communities throughout 
Texas, and the B’nai B’rith Career and Counseling 
Services assist thousands of young people and their parents every year. 
Branch director 

Calvert, who is active in many civie and philanth­ ropic activities, is a director of the Sun Antonio 
Branch of the Federal Reserve bank of Dallas and a director of Southwest Research Assn. 

He is past chairman of the United Way Campaign, director of the San Antonio M edical Foundation, trustee of Trinity University, a director of the Sym­ phony Society of San Antonio and chairman of Cen­ tro 21. San A ntonio’s Downtown Redevelopm ent 
Committee.

Eight C onvenient W ays To Boy 

Express-News Want Ads 225-1666 

Alternate fuels studied at SwRl 

Alternate fuels and reduction of emissions from m ilita ry turbine engines are being studied at 
Southwest Research Institute. 
Researchers are using a highly adaptable turbine combustor research apparatus. 
■ 
The set-up makes it possible to es ablate fuels from such sources as oil shale and tar sand as well as emergency fuels, including m ixtures of various nonstandard fuels which might be available at a time of need. 
The facility is located iii the U.S. Army Fuels and 
Lubricants 
Research 
Laboratory on the 
SwRI grounds and is operated by members of the institute staff for the Army Mobility Equipment Research and Development Command 
“ This is a flexible research tool for evaluating the combustion of turbine fuels," said Alan A. .Johnston, director of m ilitary fuel projects for the laboratory. 
The combustor facility is not lim ited to a particu­ lar fuel system and set of operating conditions, as would be the ease if a complete turbine engine were placed on a dynomometer for such testing, he said. 
Instead, the set-up can provide appropriate con­ ditions for whatever combustor and fuel system is under study, within the lim its of its air flow capa­ bilities. 
For the sake of sim plicity, the facility represents only the combustor of a turbine engine, and does not include other components such us compressor and expander stages. 
Combustion chambers of various configurations can be inserted and removed according to test re­ quirements 
Importance of turbines 
Turbine fuels research is receiving emphasis be­ cause of the importance of turbines in aircraft and other m ilita ry ap plicatio n s, and prospects for changes in quality of available fuels. 
Flexibility of the combustor facility is particularly advantageous in current investigations of two cate­ gories of alternate fuels. 
One category involves fuels produced from un­ conventional sources, such as tar sand and oil shale. 
The jet engine burning characteristics of appro­ priate fractions of these materials are under study as part of a large, multi-agency federal investigation of these fuels. . 
The other category is concerned with emergency fuels, many t.vpes of hydrocarbon materials outside normal fuels specifications winch might Ik* pressed into service when conventional fuel is not available. 
What happens, for instance, when a blend of diesel aud jet fuels is used in a turbine engine? These studies require evaluation of both jxisitive and ne­ gative effects on turbine engine performance. 
In a different type of study, the combustor facility is being used to help a m ilitary engine overhaul center in California meet requirements for reduced smoke emissions. 
The combustor supports fuel modification studies bv providing a laboratory means of evaluating ex­ haust emissions. 
This Army facility is available tor use in other government programs when they don’t interfere with A rm y activities. Where circum stances w ar­ rant. arrangements may also be made for use iii 
I nongovernmental research programs. 
’77 proclaimed friendship year 

Texas mayors have proclaimed 1977 a new year of friendship between Texas and Mexico, boosting trade, tourism and cultural exchange I m * twee ii the neightkoring countries 
The proclamations resulted from talks tie tween 
Raul Gonzalez Galarza. consul general of Mexico in 
San Antonio, and mayors of several Texas cities. 
" I had private talks with all the mayors on how to improve relations between Texas and M exico,” 
Gonzalez Galarza said 
“ These proclamations were one of the immediate results of the meeting." 
Gonzalez Galarza toured Texas i i i February. 
Shaking to mayors of San Antonio. Austin. Dallas. 
Fort Worth. Corpus Christi, Galveston, Del Rio. 
Eagle Pass. Hidalgo and McAllen. 
“ TIU1 action taken by tin* mayors of Texas has received a tremendous welcome by the new presi­ dent of Mexico, Jose Lopez Portillo, and the Mexican 
|M*ople,” Gonzalez Galarza said 

Mayor Lila Cockrell said efforts to diversify San 
Antonio’s economic base w ill be boosted by the renewed triendship between Texas and Mexico. 
"The City of San Antonio bas recognized the im- jsirtance of increasing economic and cultural ties with our friends in the Republic of Mexico and has taken action to implement these cordial relations," 
Mayor Cockrell said 
I’he new era for Texas and Mexico follows the friendship | Mil icy set last mouth when the new pre­ sidents of both countries conferred iii Washington. 
D C , Gonzalez Galarza said 
"President Lopez Portillo returned lo Mexico very pleased with Ins meeting with President C arter." 
Gonzalez (ia la r/a said 
"They are going to do their best to keep m touch constantly and try to resolve m utual problem s quickly and to the tkcnefit ot both countries," lie said

Raza Unida plans multi-party suit 

By JERRY DEAL 
Raza Unida party is preparing to file a mas­ sive lawsuit against Gov. 
Dolph Briscoe, Atty. Gen. 
John Hill and several s ta te and federal agencies. 
The suit probably will be filed next month in 

 federal district court by 
New York lawyers of the 
American Civil Liberties 
Union. John D uncan, president of the Texas 
Civil Liberties Union, said Wednesday. 
He said p relim in ary plans are to sue Briscoe, 
Hill, the Texas Rangers. 

D rug 
E n f o r c e m e n t 
Agency, FBI, CIA, Inter­ nal Revenue Service and the Immigration and Na­ turalization Service. 
Zavala County Judgt^ 
Jose Angel Gutierrez, founder of Raza Unida party, said grounds for the lawsuit will be a 

 compilation of incidents. 
He said the incidents r a n g e from 
Gov. 
Briscoe’s stoppage of a 
$1.5 million federal grant, awarded to set up, among other things, a cooperative farm in Za­ vala 
County, to monitoring by the CIA. 

He said that by last 
August the party or peo­ ple in the party had been targets of a major probe about every two weeks. 
“The attorney general was in Crystal City with five staff members for a y ear and the 
T exas 
Rangers have been there 

 since IWW,” he said. 
Only three indictments have resulted involving any governmental people from probes by three state grand juries, one federal grand jury and a 
Congressional su b c o m ­ mittee. Gutierrez said. 
Duncan said the only 

 part the TCLU is playing is to let New York know it has no objections to such a suit. 
He said the national office is much better prepared financially and staff-wise to handle a lawsuit on such a large scale. 

He said attorneys from an organization known as the Chicano Legal De­ fense Fund in Austin, approached the ACLU about the possibility of taking on such a suit. 

“ It is expected to be a massive case," he said.

. . . likes her role 
S hell lobby fo r the 
ERA 

WASHINGTON (AP)I 
— Rosalynn C a rte r in­ tends to keep right on lobbying for ratification of the Equal 
Rights 
Amendment and she isn t bothered by the “ stacks of letters" that criticize her efforts. 
While siding with 
Women s rights activists on that issue, she said she agrees with the 
President in opposing abortion 
“ I feel very strongly about abortion," she said iii her first interview since becom ing First 
Lady. "I feel the same as 
Jimmy does. There are alternatives, educational ones, and learning about adoptive p roced u res, things you can offer women in place of abor­ tion.” 
What alternatives can you offer an im p o v e r ­ ished pregnant woman? 
Mrs. Carter hesitated. 
“ I don t know," sin' said after a moment, conced­ ing that that problem is a tough one. “ But do you know how many a b o r ­ tions are repeat ones? A large n u m b e r. A very large number. I think we should stress the preven­ tion of pregnancy rather than say. ‘Go ahead and get pregnant and you can have an abortion.’” 

Education

(‘dilation. Asked where

I h a v e n t thought about it.” 

After seven weeks in the White House, Mrs. 
Carter conveys the im­ age of a woman eager to get to work, a woman vv ho confers regularly and often with her husband on some of the c o u n tr y 's toughest questions, a woman who knows she has power and wants to use it

“ I don't know thatl we ll In* able to get three more states this y ear,” ' she said "lf ifs not ra­ ti fed. I guess we can get it introduced again aud start all over. Bul it is discouraging.”

I'm opposed to your po­ sition, and I take iheirl word for it.

SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS— Thursday March IO 1977 

'OU CAN T CHANGE 
THE WORLD. 
THINGS JUST KEEP 
GETTING WORSE 
AND WORSE. THERE'S NO 
ONE YOU CAN TRUST 
ANYMORE. NOTHING YOU 
CAN BELIEVE IN. AND 
WORST OF ALL, NOTHING 
YOU CAN DO ABOUT IT. 
NO MATTER WHAT YOU 
ACHIEVE, LIFE SEEMS 
EMPTY AND MEANINGLESS. 
AND THAT MAKES IT 
TOUGH TO KEEP GOING." 

If you feel that way you're not alone. Thousands of people do. And with good reason. Just look around. 
Listen to the news. Chaos, corruption and irresponsibil­ ity seem to be everywhere. 
Maybe you're right. 
Maybe you can't change the world overnight. But there is a place to start. You can learn to live in this world by first learning to live with yourself. 
You can better understand others by first understanding who you are, what you can be and what you can't. 
Only one person makes this possible. His name 

 is Jesus Christ. For two thousand years He's been telling us we can start over— we can become new persons 
— through a personal relationship with Him. We can acknowledge our faults because He forgives us. 
We can love ourselves be­ cause He loves us. 
J 

ESUS said He came 
"so we could have life, and have it more abundantly." And countless Christians today are living proof that He does have the power to change lives. 
Executives and store clerks. 
Singers and homemakers. 
Sports figures, teenagers, actors and government officials. People you know. 
People you don't know. 
They've all found that Jesus 
Christ is the one person you can trust and believe in. That 
He gives your life meaning, purpose and direction. That 
He gives you peace of mind. 
They are living proof that Jesus Christ is real in 
1977. That people can be changed. And enough changed people can change the world. 

I 

F you would like to know more about people who are living proof, if you need more information, or have made a decision to accept Jesus Christ, there are people nearby ready to share that with you. Please let them know. 
What's the use? 
Find out. 

More information is available through a Southern 
Baptist Church near you. Or, write Living Proof, 
Box 1ooo, Dallas, Texas 75221. 

□ Please tell me more about people who are living proof that Jesus Christ is a real person, with real solutions for today's problems 

U I am now trusting Jesus Christ to change my life. 

U I would like to reaffirm a prior com m itm ent I m ade to Jesus Christ. 

I need more information. Please get back to me. 

Name 

Address 

City 

Age 

State 

A m e n ag e from Southern Baptists, in texas. 

Southwestern Bell chief says rate hike needed 

SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS— Thursdoy March IO 1977 

By ALAN BAILLY 

Telephone service is u good buy, but Southwes­ tern Bell needs a rate increase in Texas, the company president said 
Wednesday. 
Southwestern Bell Pre­ 

 sident Zane E. Barnes also said the company's return on capital invest­ ment in T exas is the lowest of any state it serves. 
Barnes talked to the downtown Rotary Club at the St. Anthony Hotel and

B a rn e s, who is h e a d q u a r t e re d in St. 
Louis. Mo.

PUC’s approval of direc­ tory assistance charges. 
$1 billion

Southwestern Bell’s par­ ent. American Telephone 
& Telegraph, posted a $1 billion net income in the past th ree m o n th s of 
1976.

System's earnings amount to less than 9 per cent.

Guilty

Bell executive J a m e s 
Ashley.

“ We don’t accept guilt 

 for something we didn't do. Because even at IO cents, the price is too high. 

Pledge

“ conversations remain strictly private.’’ 
During the press con­ ference, Barnes said the phone co m p an y “ wel­ comed stro n g r e g u l a ­ tions" by PUC, but if the courts did not provide a rate increase then the company would have to go back to PUC. 
On the directory assis­ tance charges, the presi­ dent said if the legisla­ ture overturns the PUC decision, then the in­ creased cost of some $26 million would be spread over all the customers, costing som e $1.5(1 a month per customer.

SASO trustees approve

By L IZ S W E E T 
San Antonio School Dis­ trict trustees Wednesday night voted to increase the district tax rate approxi­ mately 2ft per cent. 

The present rate of $1.52 per 
SKH! of assessed valuation will increase to $1.82 per $1oo. 

The motion passed 4-2 with trustees Oscar Hernandez and 
Grace Ann Durr voting no. 

In o th er action a fte r a lengthy executive session, the board agreed to increase Supt. 
Harold Hitt’s salary. The new salary figure is an increase of 
$4,o25 to $5o,ooo a year. 

L e a d e rsh ip 

Board president William Eli­ zondo said Dr. Hitt’s adminis­ trative leadership had played a large role in the success of the district. 

"In spite of the anonymous reports, Dr. Harold Hitt’s con­ tract will be continued and he will work with the board of trustees to m ake the San An­ tonio School District tops in tin1 country," Dr. Elizondo said. 
Also in executive session, the 

 board voted not to renew the co ntract of Area III Deputy 
Supt. Henry Rodriguez. 

T rustee Hernandez said he wanted to go on record as bas ­ ing re c o m m e n d e d the co n ­ tract’s renewal for Rodriguez. 
The motion failed, he said, at the recommendation of the su­ perintendent. 

Mrs. D urr also expressed opposition to the dismissal. 

Service cited 

"M r. Henry Rodriguez has re n d e re d loyal, co m p e te n t, faithful service to the school district for many years. His service record on file in the personnel office will confirm this fact,” Mrs. Durr said. 

“ When the board of educa­ tion fails to appoint a staff m e m b e r of Mr. R o d rig u e z ’ stature, then the board has to admit it is engaging in political action that should not have any part in this school system ,’’ she said. 

Trustees also voted to certify the results of the bond election and to accept re c o m m e n d a ­ tions of the district textbook committee. 

Lots of smiles are evident W ednesday night at the Theater for the 
Performing Arts as M ary Helen Guerrero, center, is named M iss 
Recreation 1 9 7 7 in the pageant sponsored by the City Parks and 
Recreation Department. O n the left is Kathy Medina, the 197 6 
Recreation queen and on the right is Kitty Fraley, M iss Congenia­ lity. — Staff Photo by H.M. Dean Jr. 

McAllister’s ex-wife’s son dies 

The son of form er San Antonio 
Mayor W W. McAllister’s ex-wife was killed in an accident on the Buffalo 
River near Ponca, Ark., Sunday. 
Walter Craig Sterne. 24. of Fayette­ ville. Ark., died from a 4o11-5oo foot tall from a bluff while on a canoe and hiking trip with friends. 
Memorial services will be held at St. 
Martin's Episcopal University Chapel at the U niversity of A rk an sas in 
Fayetteville March 16 at 4:3o p.m. 
Sterne was born in Texarkana. Tex . and attended St. Ja m e s Episcopal 
School there. lh* graduated with honors and a commission as a lieutenant in the 
ROTE from Texas Military Institute here. 
Sterne earned a degree in economics from Trinity University. 
His studies included a year at the 
Institute of European Studies in Vien­ na. A ustria, as well as g ra d u a te studies in international business at 
George W ashington U niversity in 
Washington. D.C. 
At the time of his death. Sterne was in business with his mother in Eureka 
Springs. Ark., while studying for a law degree at the university in Fayette­ ville. 
He is survived by his father. Roy W. 
Sterile of Fayetteville; his mother. 
Mrs. Louis 7 . 
Ambon of E ureka 
Springs; and his maternal grandpar­ ents. Lloyd Tollett of Idabel, Okla.. and 
Mrs. Jane Tollett of Eureka Springs. 
Donations to the Craig Sterile Me­ morial Fund are being handled by the 
Rev. Fredrick Jones at St. Martin's 
.Episcopal Chapel in Fayetteville.

There was no suppor­ tive shoring in the trench that collapsed burying and sm o th e rin g th re e d ite h d ig g e rs T uesday, according to Ed YValtman su perviso r for F a rre ll 
Construction Co. 
F a rre ll Construction, based in 
M em p h is, 
Tenn., holds the m ulti­ million dollar contract with the city for building 
'the d r a in a g e ditch th rou gh B ra c k e n rid g e 
Park where the accident occurred. 
Walt man said Wednes­ day the shoring had been up. but it was removed p rio r to the acc id e n t which killed the men 
Tuesday morning. 
He said he couldn’t go into further detail with­ out naming names.

Court space hunted 

Comm issioners Court 
Wednesday failed — de­ spite more debate — to find a place for the fourth new district court under the 
B exar 
County 
Courthouse roof. 
A final decision in the court office expansion debate was put off to 
F rid a y ’s regular court session. 
Space for three courts has been identified but not finally designated. 
J u d g e B lair R eeves and all four co m m is, stoners indicated, how­ ever, they would prefer lo be able to start now on a proposed new county office building. 
Any move to house the new courts is to Im* con­ sidered purely tem p o r­ ary, they indicated. 
Ultimately, a c c o rd in g to Reeves, the old County 
Courthouse w ill Im* used to house courts alone. 
Other administrative of­ fices within the county b u re a u c ra c y w i l l be shifted into the suggested new q u a r te r s , he e x ­ plained 

2 acquitted o f plotting 

CHICAGO (A P) - A federal court jury Wed­ nesday acquitted two of seven defendant firm s charged with conspiring to set potash production and price levels and said it was unable to reach a verdict on the remaining defendants. 

The six-m an, six- woman jury acq uitted 
Freeport Minerals Co., 
New York City, and 
National 
Potash Co., 
Carlsbad, N M , and was ordered to continue deliberations Thursday by Ju d g e P re n tic e Ii, 
Marshall. 

 couldn’t tell you the truth about exactly what hap­ pened. I w asn’t there. 
I’m only te llin g you w hat’s been related to me. 
Witnesses 
“ There were two wit­ nesses there and they’ve given s ta te m e n ts to everyone and they’re not totally su re w hat h a p ­ pened." 
Waltman said Wednes­ day he was u p set by publicity alleg in g con ­ tractors didn t care about killing Mexicans. 
“ We didn’t come over here to kill people. We’re a safety minded group.” the supervisor said. He said F arrell had won a national award last year 

 for being the safest con­ stru c tio n g rou p in the 
U.S. 
He said he didn't know the three men who were killed were Mexican na­ tionals. 
“ They had (U.S.) so­ cial security numbers . . . whether they were valid or not I have no way of knowing." 
Federal Occupational 
Safety and H ealth A d­ ministration officials and city officials were still in v estig atin g the a c c i­ dent Wednesday. 
Some local le a d e rs have blamed the deaths of the three men and a similar death Monday on the city's failure to see that safety regulations are followed.

LEGS OR THIGHS 

 ir,. There’s three big ways to save on meat... 

I 
First, ya save because we offer you low, low discount prices every-

Second, ya save because we pass along the Savings for buying meat in larger size packages. That’s a nickel a pound difference jes’ by lookin’ for the Magna Pak tag when you go to buy meat.  l l schools set board elections 

By LIZ SW EET 

Bexar County voters will go to the polls April 2 to elect 27 trustees for ll public school districts. 

The filing deadline for candidates was March 2. 
Trustees' terms are three years in must cases. 
The San Antonio School District, 
Edgewood School District and San An­ tonio Union Junior College District are not holding elections this year. 
Absentee voting in all elections is scheduled for March 14 through March 
2h Patrons may vote during regular business hours Monday through F ri­ day. 
Absentee voting is in each district's central office with the following ex­ ceptions: North East School District, the Tax Office. 1(1214 Sommers Dr.; 
South San School District, South San 
West campus, 5522 Ray Ellison Blvd or the administration building, 2515 
Sioux St. according to the precinct numbers; and Southside School Dis­ trict. the superintendent’s office locat­ ed in the Southside Junior High School.

E x-S .A . m ayor suit defendant 

Former Mayor John Gatti, his former employer. Rauseher-Pieree 
Securities Corp., and three other former Rauseher-Pieree employes have been hit with a 14.3 million civil suit in Austin federal court. 
One «»f the plaintiffs iii the ease. 
Patrick L. Searcy, and one defendant, 
George C. Haskell, are scheduled to be sentenced Friday in a related federal criminal ease here. 
Hitt says charge is untrue 

San Antonio School District Supt. 
Harold Mitt Wednesday denied know­ ledge of charges of a spy system in the district’s mailroom made by the San 
Antonio Federation of Teachers, 
A F U IO 
In a press conference Tuesday. Paul 
(Ramona. SAFT president, charged that mailroom employes were directed to open the persona! mail of teachers in six select schools bi determine whether they were receiving SAFT literature. rile SAF I’ spokesman said the group plans to sue Hie district's board of education, 
Dr, Mitt said SAFT teachers, as individuals, have the right to use the in-house distribution system the same as any other employe of the district. 
“ I did not authorize any material to be opened by anybody,” Dr. Hitt said. 
The superintendent also said the union group had failed to qualify for an election to decide which organization would represent district teachers be- cause they refused to give up the right lo strike, which is illegal. 
The SAFT representative also ac­ cused board representatives of apply­ ing pressure to encourage support for the district’s $49 million bond election. 
(ftamona claimed a SASO attorney told the organization harassment of lls member* would Im* relaxed if the group would guarantee union support for the 
Ixind issue. 
"As co-chairman of the committee, 

(C itizens for Better Schools Committee which worked for the bond issue s passage) I know of no agreement to secure the support of any group in return for any alleged favors,” Dr said.

 m m * 

— 
- iii king 

Hut 

Searcy, his mother Katherine W. 
Searcy, and his wife Lois M. Searcy, have charged Rauseher-Pieree and its employes with violation of the federal 
Securities Act. 
Haskell, while working for the securities firm, advised Scarey til apply for loans and pledge as collateral corporate bonds he ordered through 
Haskell, the suit alleges. 
Searcy and Haskell would cancel the orders after the loans were received, according to Searcy’s suit. 

Haskell then invested the money, according til the suit. 
When the hank officers called Has-} kell to confirm the loans. Searcy a1- i leged, (iaskell would send a letter of guarantee ti) the bank. 
Although the arrangement began in 
August 1975. Searcy charged, he did not learn of the fraudulent aspects until May 197H. 
Ruaseher-Pieree officials Haiti, 
George C. Frank Hebhardt and Ralph 
M. Yates did not tell Searcy of the fraud, nor did they attempt to investi­ gate the ease or discipline Haskell, 
Searcy alleges, 
Searcy charged Haskell did not tell him the truth about the scheme until the proceeds from the loans were gone and it was too lute to salvage any money. 
Amounts sought 

Searcy and his mother are asking for 
»25b.UOO they had to pay to make resti­ tution on the loans plus treble da­ mages of 1788,ooo under the federal 
Securities Aet. 
Searcy's wtfe wants $5oo,oo1) da­ mages for physical impairment and mental anguish suffered as a result of the alleged scheme. 
The plaintiffs also ask for exemplary damages of $3 million. 
Haskell pleaded guilty to conspiracy to falsify loan applications in the ease. 
Searcy, who was also named in an eight-count federal grand jury indict­ ment, pleased guilty only ti) making a false statement on a single loan application. 
Six banks 

According to the indictment, Searcy obtained $425,ooo worth of loans from six hanks, 
U S. Dist. Judge D. VV Suttle is scheduled to sentence Scarey and 
(iaskell Friday. 
Former Mayor Haiti now lives in 
Houston. Yates is also a Houston resi­ dent. the suit states.

SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS— Thursday March IO 1977 

AFTER six m onths w e a rin g a surgical m ask, H ector 
M artinez can smile in public 
STAFF PH O TO BY TARRY TARSHIS 
S.A. man has smile unveiled 

By MIC II AKL QUINTANILLA 

At I p.m. Wednesday Hector 
Martinez, 2o-year-old San An­ tonian who underwent a rare and s u c c e s s f u l $3o,ooo bone marrow transplant half-a-year a^o, came out of hiding. 
Hiding his smile that is. 
His San Antonio doctors allowed him to remove a light blue surgical mask he had been wearing over half his face for the past six months. 
Meeter and his brother. Roger. 21, d o n o r in t h e 4*2-hour t r a n s p l a n t , underwent the operation at the Fred 
Hutchinson Cancer Research Center in 
Seattle Sept. IO. 197H. 
Released 

Roger was released from tin* hospi­ tal Sept. 21 and retu rn ed to San An­ tonio on Oct. 15. Hector's homecoming was IO days before Christmas. 
“ I r e m e m b e r getting off the plane wearing the mask, hiding my smile — 
I won t have to hide it anym ore.” he said. 
Hector had been wearing the mask for health protection, especially while in p u b lic , to g u a r d h i m s e l f fro m inhaling ‘‘any sickness in the air — to keep myself from any type of bodily infection” he said. 
The rem oval of the surg ical linen c lo th , w h ich c o v e r e d his nose and mouth, is just the first step toward a complete and total recovery, he said. 
“ It feels great to know I don't have to wear this lit th* thing when I’m around my friends an y m o re," he said, holding the m a sk , wadded like paper, in his hand. 
"Of course this m eans 1 11 have to be m ore careful with myself and I will wear the m ask if I’m around someone w h o ’s s n e e z i n g or c o u g h i n g — my common sense will tell m e that," he said, smiling from ea r to ear. 
Not cured yet 

" I ’m not cured yet. It s hard to say when exactly I will be. but the doctors tell m e it will p r o b a b l y ta k e five years.” 

Meanwhile, every two months. Hec­ tor visits the Green Hospital for a bone m arrow biopsy, a spinal tap. blood counts and chest X-rays 
So far Hector prides himself in hav­ ing about 32 bone marrow biopsies — a painful eig h t-m in u te p ro ced u re that requires a needle injection in the pel­ vic bone to withdraw bone marrow for a study and a count. 
The spinal tap treatm ents deal with replacing spinal fluid with nethotrex- ate (a d ru g which preve nts internal infection), through a needle injection. 
“ I’m hoping that I'll be off the spinal taps in August. I’ve had about 3o of them p erfo rm ed and each tap takes about 15 m inutes,” he said, pointing to the place of insertion on his back. 
Delay treatments 

Iii the m e a n t i m e . Hector p la ns to delay his April I treatm ents to attend the Starving Artists Show on April 3. 
"M y application has been accepted for the show and I’m too excited to take th e t r e a t m e n t s — I ’m s e a r e d th e t r e a t m e n t s will be too close to the show .” he said 

"I ve been working on hits of art since I was in the hospital back in 
Washington. I have rock sta rs , chil­ d r e n . s p o r t s f i g u r e s , a b s t r a c t d e ­ signs." he continued, pointing out the various colorful canvases. 
"I d sell kool-aid also, if I could." he said. laughing. " I ’m saving the money from the show to pay for my tuition at 
SAC in the fall.” 
‘‘I ’m busy right now working im roe singers. I’m really looking forward to having a good tim e at the show and seeing people.” 
One day at a time 

” 1 g u e s s s in c e m y o p e r a tio n and since I’ve been home. I'm taking one day at a time, living life as joyful as I can — and re s p e c ti n g i t, ’’ he said, nodding Ins head. 
"I just thank God for another day — u s e today — an o th e r beautiful day. 
When you're as close to death like I was, you le arn to a p p r e c i a t e every day.”

By 
M VBK

Pharm acy advertising law is overruled 

AUSTIN’ 
(A P ) 
- 
The 
Texas 
Supreme Court struck down W ednes­ day a 1973 state law forbidding phar­ m a cies to advertise their prices for prescription drugs 
An Austin district court and the 3rd, 
Court of Civil Appeals had declared the law unconstitutional, and the Supreme 
Court agreed Wilhoit writing a new 
Opinion of its own. 
'T he law violated the Texas constitu­ tional prohibition ag ain st d ep riv in g ope of property without due course of law. the lower courts had ruled. 

Conclusion 

; “ We conclude that the interest of the strate in the professionalism of p har­ macists is not greatly served bv le g is­ lation which keeps the public ignorant oh prescription drug p rices." the a p ­ peals court said 
P a rtie s to the suit w ere the State 
Board of Pharmacy and Gibson s D is­ count Centers. 
Iii another decision, the court ruled that ju d g e s have no pow er to order resumption of child support pa> merits after a child reaches 18. 
It overruled Alice Bed's attempt to reopen proceedings in her 19H3 divorce from George Bed to obtain continued support for their m en ta lly retard ed daughter. 

Cain claimed he thought the pistol was' unloaded when he held it to the head of 
Santos Rodriguez and tried to scare the handcuffed boy while questioning him about a service station robbery. 
Cain sa id he p u lle d th e t r i g g e r thinking the click would frighten Bo- d r ig u e z . T h e s la y in g to u c h e d o ff violent street protests iii Dallas. 

Trial 

The trial w a s m o v e d to A u s tin . where Cain s attorneys claim ed his life would be in jeopardy if sent to prison. 
D elia s been working and living under an assumed name since his conv iction. lawyers say. 

File trial was marked by a tearful re-enactment of the incident by Cain. 
On appeal. Cain s lawyers protested the decision of trial .Judge Ed Gossett to exclude psychiatric testim ony co n ­ cerning statem ents made by Cain after an injection of truth serum 

With the jury out. Dr. John Holbrook said Cain told him he honestly believed he had removed all the bullets from his pistol before pointing it at Rodriguez. 

The Cain attorneys also objected to the p r o s e c u t o r 's w a v in g a p o lic e badge, which had not been introduced in evidence, before the jury as he ar­ gued that Cain had tarnished it “ with tin* blood of Santos Rodriguez."

 washington post service 

WASHINGTON — Two palatial Em­ bassy Rom homes, three luxury cars md other personal property belonging to South Korean businessman Tongsun 
Park have been seized by U.S. Internal 
Revenue Service agents here in an apparent effort to keep the assets from 

 being sold or moved out of the country

 m oved in 
M onday 
IRS said it was acting

1972 through 1975.

H otel tax bill ready to pass 

I X P B t S S C A P I T O L B U R t A U 
AUSTIN — Tin* Bexar County House delegation split 7-5 
Wednesday in a preliminary vote on a bill raising the local option 
*1 occupancy tax n om me pi 

SB333 won tentative House approval by an K2-5H margin and now goes ti! third reading aud probable passage to the governor on Thursday. 
Voting against the bill were Sun An­ tonio Reps. Matt Garcia. Joe L. Her­ nandez, Frank Madly. Abe Ribuk. Lou 
Nolle Sutton. Frank Tujeda and Bob 
Vale. 
Favoring the bill were Reps. Ron 
Bird. Al Brown, Don C artw right. 
James Nowlin and Don Rains. 
Under the current law. the first .5 per cent of the 3 per cent local option hotel occupancy tax is reserved for advertising and promotion of the city's hotel and convention and tourism business. 
SB333 proposes to raise the maxi­ mum permissable local occupancy tax to 4 per cent, with the first .5 per cent of I per cent still earmarked for ad­ vertising and promotion. 
Promotional 
The net effect, for a city adopting the 
4 per cent, will be a mu.ior increase in the funds available for advertising and promotion. 
Proponents of the bill argued Texas now has the lowest hotel occupancy tax of any major convention and tourism 
. state — the 3 per cent local and 3 per 
• cent state tax. 
They also pointed out tourism is a major industry producing more than 
$3.5 billion into tile state’s economy annually, and generating more that* 
$31o million in various state taxes. 
Opponents argued Wednesday the best way to attract tourists to Texas is to keep the occupancy tax low. not raise it. 
Testifying against the bill when it was heard in committee wert* two San 
Antonians — John Boswell of the San 
Antonio Motel Assn., and ETI. denning 
Jr.. Texas Hotel and Mute! Accounts 
Assn. 

6 per coni to 4 per ct*

Presently, dental hygeimts are prohibited from practicing under any oilier form than as indiv iduals

Both San Antonio State Sens. Glenn Kothmann aud Prank Lninbardinn voted for Traeger's bill.

 ftake-or-pay’ limits on gas 

 express c a p it o l bureau 

AUSTIN — The House passed and sent to the Senate Wednesday a bill limiting “ take-or-pay” clauses in na­ tural gas contracts by which consumers sometimes pay for gas they don’t use. 
HB873 by Reps. .James Nowlin of San 
Antonio, and Tom Schieffcr of Fort 
Worth, won final approval by a 112-26 margin. 
The Bexar county House delegation voted unanimously for its passage. 
Tfu* bill goes to the Senate with three amendments added Tuesday during lively floor debate. 
The first amendment prohibits con­ tracts requiring the buyer to take more than Ha per cent of the sellers deliverable gas 
The original bill had proposed an St* per cent limit. 
The second amendment gives th' 

 buyers three years to make up short­ falls in their purchases. 
A third amendment calls for pro­ perty and royalty owners to share in the revenues obtained by producers under the take-or-pay for gas not ac­ tually sold. 

During 1975, Lo-Vaca Gathering Co 
— San Antonio’s sole supplier of na­ tural gas — paid out an additional $22.7 million in take-or-pay contracts. 
Since this cost is passed directly to 
Lo-Yaca’s customers, ifs estimated 
San Antonio’s 17 per cent share of this was approximately $3.9 million. 

In 1976, from .January through Sep­ tember, the additional cost to Lo-Vaca customers for take-or-pay was $8.5 m illion of which 
San 
Antonio customers contributed $1.4 million 
In tin1 case of Lo-Vaca and .San An­ tonio, all gas paid for was taken.

COMING THAT YOU 
WON'T WANT TO MISSI 

Raymond a philosopher and physician. delving deeply into the question in the lorelront of m a n s mind since his existence, analyzes case histories of persons who have been pronounced clinically dead. 
He finds an amazing coincidence in their accounts of leaving their physical bodies with an awareness of at­ tempts to keep them alive, encounters with a being of light" who reviews their lives in a panoramic montage, and their "coming back" to the mortal world . . .

ANTIQUES TOMORROW? 

From Steuben glass and Art Deco to beer cans and baseball cards, just about anything that can be carried off is being collected today. This series not only tells beginners what they can collect but suggests where to look for it, how to determine its value and what pitfalls and possibilities the collection may have!

S A N A N T O N IO EXPRESS — Thursday M arch 1o I 97.7

Del Rio recall drive possible 

S P E C IA I T O THE E X P R ! S S 
DEL RIO — Controversy over relocating a fire station and building a flood control dam here threatened Wednesday to bring on a City Council recall drive. 
Mayor Alfredo G utierrez Jr. has been under h e a v y attack in every re­ cent council m eeting — including 
Tuesday night’s — for alleged arbi­ trary actions on the city's fire protec­ tion. 
Insurance authorities have required the city's fire plan to be expanded to cover new city development under a complicated set of guidelines. 
The mayor Tuesday won 5-2 council approval of existing city plans to close a fire station in a northern section of the city and build another station on’ newly purchased land. 
The move was vociferously opposed by Citizens Organized to Keep the Fire 
Station ((’OKS), which had gathered 

Legislation to be discussed 

Legislative measures pending or to be introduced into the state Senate or 
House of Representatives will be dis­ cussed by the Insurance Women of San 
Antonio. 
The group w ill meet with state representatives and senators at 6:45 p.m. Friday in Villa Espanola, San 
Antonio International Airport. 

2.2o(1 petition signatures supporting their position. 
Gutierrez has repeatedly been ac­ cused of manipulating parliamentary procedure and controlling a “ rubber­ stamp” council which always votes the same 5-2 margin. 
COES leader Kathleen Conners could not be reached for comment Wednes­ day. but sources insisted at least one council member was targeted for re­ call and others including the mayor were being considered for recall as a result of the fire station vote. 
The overflow audience also disa­ greed loudly with council positions on building a flood control dam across 
San Felipe Creek, which bisects the city. 
Floodwuters from the- creek have of­ ten damaged homes in the area. San 
Felipe Springs, source of the water, is the only water supply for the city, however. 
Opponents of the dam have cited ob­ ject ions ranging from possible pollu­ tion of the springs to a possible disas­ trous collapse of the proposed earthen dam. 
Representatives of land owners where the dam would be built also challenged outside appraisals of the land, which amount to some $5oo.(MM1. 
They contended local appraisers set the land values closer to $1.5 million, a figure the dam opponents said the city and county combined could not afford. 
While the council postponed a vote on the land acquisition, opponents of the dam expressed dissatisfaction with the lack of action. 
Area municipalities gear up for balloting 

By DAVID MCLEMORE 
Live Oak voters will face plenty of choices April 2 when they cast ballots in their muni­ cipal elections. 
Live Oak has the largest number of candidates among local suburban communities, with l l persons trying for four city council positions. 
There were a total of 1o5 persons seeking city offices in the 2o arca su­ burbs. There are only OH positions o|M*n. 
Controversy over the local water district and the new city charter high­ light the Live Oak elections. Those running for office in Live Oak are:

ONE PERFORMANCE ONLY 

By M ARY ANN 
BENGTSON 
ASSISTANT W O M EN s EDITOR 
The memories of 
General 
“ Black­ jack" himself echo through the high­ balled rooms of 
Pershing House—a reminder of its his­ toric past. 
Now occupied by Ll. 
Gen. Allen Burdett Jr .. and his family. Pershing 
House will be part of the doth annual Home and 
Garden 
P ilg rim rn age sponsored by 
Christ 
Episcopal 
Church. 
March 26 and 27. 
Burdett is command­ ing general of the 3th C. 
S. Army. 
Located at No. ii Staff 
Post Kd.. Et Sam Hous­ ton. the home of hew ii li­ mestone was designed by the late Alfred Giles in 
ISSI. Giles was the a r­ chitect of many homes in ilu* King William area 
Visitors to Pershing 
House will Im* greeted by a portrait of Gen Persh­ ing which hangs above the curving stairway of 
Cherrywood and walnut burl. 
The beautiful living room of the home is highlighted by an etched slate fireplace with mar­ ble mantle. Treasured antiques belonging to the 
Burdett family are dis­ played in this room. 
Piano 
A seven-octave maho­ gany piano, built in Eng­ land during 1832. be­ longed to Gen. Burden s great-grandmother. 
A portrait of this lady hangs above the piano. 
To the left is a massive carved oak chair bclong- ing to the General s grandfather and atop the mantle is a family heir­ loom clock in porcelain. 
The dining room hosts a magnificent mahogany silver chest containing the wedding silver pre­ sented to the General's grandm other by her groom on the occasion of their marriage. 
The Louis XV pat­ terned silver by Whiting was presented to Gen. and Mrs. Burdett when they were married. 
The dining table will be formally set with gold bordered Limoges ser­ vice plates and Erench bouillon cups. Crystal 

 glassware is from Cze­ choslovakia. 

Beautiful French doors open from each room of 
Pershing House on to wide verandas giving the home a gracious indoor- outdoor feeling. 
Port rait 
Iii the hallway hangs a portrait of Gen. Burdett and at one end of the hall is an antique marble top pier table, an ornate brass lamp with cran­ berry glass shad*' and a burled mahogany mirror, all from Mrs. Burdett'* family. 
The home's solarium was once an open air ver­ anda 
The room, with its ex- posed limestone walls, is now used for entertain- jlltr 
On the left wall of the sitting room is un oil landscape by Mrs. John 

 hor additional photograph* 
Sin* I hi ge 8’I) 

Bowls The daughter of 
Gen. John P. Lucas. Mrs. 
Bowls lived in Pershing 
House in 1844-43. 
On a step table in this room arc displayed Delft candlesticks presented to the Burdens by the Chief of Staff of the Nether­ lands Army. Above hangs a small |>ortrait of Gen. 
Burdett’s father, also a military man. 
IliM o rir 
Pershing House is one of 13 historic old homes on Staff Post Kd, de­ signed by Giles and built 

 iii the 18811s. All are maintained bv the C S 
Army. and all are iii need of historical preserva­ tion. 

Other homes on the 
Pilgrimage belong to Mr. and Mrs. Jam es P. Ro­ binson IL .3435 Twist eh! 
Oaks; Don Morris, 245 
Boxball; Mr. and Mrs. 
Walter B Brown, 213 Sir 
Arthur; and Robert Dan- l>erl, 215 \\ Kings High­ way. 

Pilgrimage hours are from noon to H p.m. each day aud tickets are priced at #2.5o. They may 
Ik* purchased at Joskes, 
Handy Andy Superm ar­ kets. H FB Food Stores, the Witte Museum, Mun­ 

 icipal Auditorium, local flower shops and at gar­ den gates during the Pil­ grimage. 
Benefitting from the 
Home and Garden Pilgri­ mage will be the Jersig 
School of Communication 
Disorders and Brighton 
School, the Bridge (Peu- cock Center), San Anton­ io Council of Churches and the Childrens Hospi­ tal Foundation. 
Buses for the tour will leave Municipal Auditor­ ium between the hours of 
11:3o a.m. and 2 p.m. on tour days as loaded Bus tickets are $2 for adults and SI for children.

Red Cross is good neighbor in San Antonio

FOR PENDLETON 

6712 N. New Braunfels Ave. 
828-2876 
BankAmericord and Master Charge accepted. 

You missed the 
Red Cross Rally at 
North Star Mall last weekend? Don’t de­ spair, there's to be a repeat at Windsor 
Park M all, March 
18-19, IO a.ill. to 9 p.m. 
Three lied 
Cross 
Chapters in the United 
States have over 5o per cent military-connected clients and one of those is 
Bexar County Chapter. 
The others are San Diego and Norfolk. Va. 
One section of the rally is devoted to ways that 
Hod Cross helps service personnel. It doesn’t matter if you are in the military or if you are the parent, child, sister, brother, grandparent. 

Dropping 
.y In

Upholstery Fabric 

\» k about V n r » cred it plan* 

L 

 wife or husband of a ser­ vice person. 
Red Cross stands ready to help when there are family problems, a late check, a lost military ID, a sick child, homesick­ ness, no mail, a move to a new community or a need for information. The son u t * personnel or his family needs only to call. 
Almost every fam ily has their own experience of Red Cross help. Maybe a soldier finds out he’s a new father, or a wife finds out her husband was moved and his mail has been held up. Many veterans have found Red 
Cross to be the friend they need when they hit a snag in veterans benefits. 

Safety film 

Another part of the ral­ ly was a film of water safety. Schools and clubs should remember that the Red Cross is happy to furnish films, speakers and demonstrations in a number of areas. 
Disaster vans were dis­ played. These units are taken into sections hit by hurricanes, floods and other disasters. They also help in one family burn­ outs. 
The same vans serve as emergency first aid units at occasions such as 
Fiesta. Explorer Scouts. 
ROTC squads and adult volunteers man the vans at these times. 
Demonstrations of ear- dio-pulmonary resuscita­ tion were given by Red 
Cross Instructors. A life­ like infant figure and 
“ Res ii sci Anne" were re­ vived over and over w hile questions were answered from the public. 
Volunteers manned a booth listing the types of volunteers needed. The 

Red Cross needs accoun­ tants. bookkeepers, caseworkers, clerks, ty­ pists. d rivers, food handlers, first aid in­ structors. hospital aids, nurses and assistants, personnel specialists, in­ terviewers, public rela­ tion persons, photo­ graphers, printers, re­ ceptionists. stockroom. radio operators, youth workers, water safety in­ structors and others. 

A N D EE R S 

 special! Group of sexy sandals 

2o%off 

Classes 

On the drawing board are plans to offer Red 
Cross classes in various sections of the city. As these classes are lined up, neighborhood d is­ plays are given alerting citizens to local class op­ portunities. 
Sharon Coppula. assis­ tant public relations dir­ ector for the Red Cross, coordinated the mall rallies w hich also feature a musical program on the history of the Red Cross by the Edgewood High 
School Concert Choir and other Edgewood stu­ dents. Directors are Ste­ phanie Schwarz and Sis­ ter M uddyn Pape. Old­ fashioned Red Cross uni­ forms are being shown. 
The show on Saturday, 
M arch 19 at W indsor 
Park is at 2 p.m. 
Bob Graham , public relations director for the 
Bexar County Chapter says Red Cross is show­ ing the community how it is a good neighbor. Many departments such as the 
Junior Red Cross are be- ing rev italized 
“ Some companies are starting to insist that 
First Aid be part of em­ ploye training. Two local companies. 
C hurch’s 
Fried Chicken and Wha- taburger. are using Red 
Cross training for their people," Graham says. 
“ It makes you feel good to see people curing about people." 
Don’t miss the W indsor 
Park Red Cross Rally or you may have to wait a whole year to see the Red 
Cross in action.

SAN A N TO N IO EXPRESS— Thursday March 1o 19 

T hanks for th e 'favor’ 

Dear Ann Landers: My best friend and I are both 23 years of age. We were married about the same time (last year) to a couple of great guys. Will you please settle an argument? 
M yrtle says a wife should say 
“Thank you” to her husband after they have made love. I say “ no way." 
I'm perfectly willing to let my hus­ band know he pleased me and that I 

 appreciate him as a lover, but to say 
“ Thank y o u " for som ething that should be mutually satisfying seems ridiculous. 
After all, he is not doing me a favor when he makes love to mc, so why should I thank him? 
Myrtle says it never hurts to build up a man’s ego and this is a great way to make him feel special. What do YOU 

 say? Divided In Durham 
Dear Divided: To each his own. If 
Myrtle wants to thank her husband to build up his ego — that's her business. 
If you feel it would be degrading, don't do it. 
Dear Ann Landers: 
In answer to 
“ One With Two Tired E a rs.” the reader whose friend is a non-stop talker. I suggest she check friend's medicine cabinet. 

There is a better than even chance that this lady is turned tot bv some sort of medication. Sympathetic in NX. 
Dear Sym.: Thanks for suggesting the alternate possibility. It's a very real one. I hope my readers w ho are on medication will pay close attention to your letter and, if they recognize themselves, will make a special effort to stem the verbiage or reduce the dosage. 

Ann 

Landers

Camp 
Fi set to begin drive 

Alamo Council of Camp Fire is kicking off file national program's UTtll birthday and Hic local An­ nual Fund Drive simultaneously. 

Jimmy Hassloclier, a division manager of Fron­ tier Enterprises, is being honored as the 197H fund raising committee chairman. 

Bluebirds Heather Groves and Beth Meyer pre­ sented a certificate of appreciation to Hasslochor, one of many San Antonio businessmen who support 
Camp Fire financially. 
Birthday Week activities will Itegin Saturday with a Country Fair from IO a.rn. to 2 p.m. in MacArthur 
Park. The event is free and open to the public. 

Carnival-type booths, refreshments and crafts displays will be featured. 
The Swinging Singles square dancing club will perform at ll a.m. 
Camp Fire Girls was organized on March 17, 191o, by Dr. and Mrs. Luther Gulick as a sister organiza­ tion to the Boy Scouts of America. 
Such an idea was revolutionary for that time. 

Since then, thousands of girls have benefitted from Camp Fire experiences as they strive to fulfill the Camp Fire Law—Worship God, Seek Beauty, 
Give Service, Pursue Knowledge, Be Trustworthy, 
Hold on to Health. Glorify Work and Be Happy.

Your Best Tastes Better With 
S P E A S VIN EG AR 
HAMBURGER-UMA BEAN POT 
1 lb. dried lima beans 
6 cups water 
1 T. prepared mustard 
1 T. Worcestershire sauce 
1 tsp. salt 
1 tsp. chill powder 
1/3 cup SPEAS A pple Cider Vinegar 
1 can condensed tomato soup 
1 lb. hamburger 
1 medium onion, chopped 
2 T. cooking fat 
1/4 lb. bacon, sliced 
Soak beans In water; cook slowly. Add mustard, 
Worcestershire, salt, chill powder, vinegar, and soup to 1-1/2 cups bean liquid. Brown hamburger and chopped onion In cooking fat. Add to sauce. 
Alternate layers of drained beans and meat In a 3-qt. casserole. Top with bacon Bake 45 minutes at 4oo degrees. 8 servings 
FREE VINEGAR RECIPE BOOK. WriteSpeasCompany 
24oo Nicholson Ave . Kansas City. Missouri 6412o 

San Jacinto group to receive charter 

San Jacinto Descen­ dants will meet at noon 
Saturday in the 1836 Club and Restaurant for lun­ cheon. A board meeting at ll a m. will precede the meeting. 
The Rev. Albert C. 
Walling ll of Houston., founder-president, will preside. 
Guest speaker will be 
Miss Sue Flanagan, dir­ ector of the Sam Houston 
Memorial Museum in 
Huntsville. 
Miss Flanagan will speak on “ Houston after 
San Jacinto.” The author of “ Sam Houston’s Tex­ a s ' ’ and “ Trailing the 
Show a friend what makes a 
Whataburaer 

Longhorns” , she is a na­ tive of San Angelo and former administrative aid to the attorney gener­ al of Texas. 
Arming the honored guests at the meeting w ill he Mrs. Margaret Deck 
Everett of 
Houston, great-granddaughter of 
Sam Houston, and other 
Houston descendants liv­ ing in San Antonio. 
The Rev. Walling will present a charter to the 
San Antonio chapter. 
This is the fifth chapter to be created since the or­ ganization began in Fort 
Worth in 1963 
Elmer Collier has been appointed organizing chairman for the new chapter. Flans for the founding of a sixth chapter in Beaumont will also lie presented. 
Officers will be elected at the meeting. Collier w ill be in charge of the meeting and is receiv ing reservations. Checks for 
$5.15 made out to the San 
Jacinto Descendants Inc. should he sent to him at 
238 Montpelier Drive. San 
Antonio. 78228. 
After the meeting, the group will go for a boat ride and tour of down­ town San Antonio.

To a lot of people a fast food hamburger is a hamburger that s wrapped and waiting under a heat lamp. 
It you know some­ body who thinks so. you can do that somebody a big favor. 
You can introduce that person to a real, honest- ro-goodness, madc-especially for-them hamburger. 
A Whataburger 
It s a beautiful, fresh 1oor/ ground beef patty that doesn t go on the hot, sizzling grill until you say,' A Whataburger* please, w ith, . " 

Then you name it and we pile it on. 
Crispy lettuce. Thick slices of ripe tomatoes. 
Onions. Pickles. 
Mustard. Catsup. 
Salad dressing. 
All on a hot- toasted bun. 
And any­ body who does some­ thing as nice as introduce a friend to a 
Whataburger- deserves to be rewarded. 
So when you treat a friend to a Whataburger1, your Whataburger* will be on us. Just clip out the coupon below, and bring it in to your participating Whataburger* restaurant.

HAVE YOU 
WRITTEN A BOOK? 

A publisher* editorial representative will be interviewing local authors in a quest for finished manuscripts suitable for book 

 publication by Carlton Press, Inc., well-known New York subsidy 

 publishing firm. All subjects will be considered including fiction 

 and non fiction, poetry, drama, religion, philosophy, etc. 

He will be in San Antonio in April. 

 lf you hove completed a book length manuscript (or nearly so) 

 on any subject, and would like o professional appraisal (without 

 cost or obligation), please write immediately describing your 

 work. State which port of the day (a rn or p rn.) you would prefer 

 for on appointment and kindly mention your phone number. You 

 will receive o confirmation by moil for a definite time ond place. 

Authors with completed manuscripts unable to oppear moy 

 send them directly to the address below for a free reading and evaluation. Authors whose literary works are still in progress moy also write 
Alan P. Pater 
195 South Beverly Drive 
Beverly Hill*, California 9o21 2 
Tai. (213) 271.335o

Finnish student gets taste of Texas 

Inventory 

 tire population of her ho­ m e to w n , G r a n k u l l a , a suburb of Helsinki. 
“ Yep, things are pretty wild in T exas," she says in h e r soft F in n is h a c ­ cent. 
A n n ik a . a 
R o ta ry exchange student at Ala­ mo Heights High School, is s ta y in g w ith se v eral 
San Antonio families, in­ c lu d in g M r. an d M rs. 
J a m e s T. S c h u lte an d 
Mr. and Mrs. Hall Clark. 

Adopted 

In th e s h o r t m o n th s since the tall, trim Fin arrived, she has adopted things Texan. 
“ I t ’s not lik e th e m ovies.” she adm its. “ Of course I saw the oil wells and cowboys, which I ex­ pecte d to se e, b u t not everyone is rich .” 
T he Schultes -have gi­ ven her broad tastes of 
T ex as—c a m p in g in Big 
Bend over Thanksgiving, shopping trips to Laredo an d Houston, w eekends on th e ir B oerne ran ch , and lots of tacos. 
“ I love Mexican food.” says Annika. She may try her own brand of Mexi­ 

 can cuisine when she re­ turns to Finland. Instead of beef, s h e ’ll use re in ­ deer m e a t! 
Annika. who turned 18 
W ed n esd ay , c e le b ra te d her b irth d ay here w ith m ore than UM) friends. 
How does a Finnish girl cele b rate a b irthday in 
Texas? 
Merienda 

W ith a ta m a l e m erienda. of course 
H o sts for th e p a r ty w ere the S c h u lte s and their daughter, Janey, a so p h o m o re at 
A lam o 
Heights. 
Annika also has shared a taste of Finland with 
San Antonians. She has given lectures and slide sh o w s of h e r n a tiv e country to local clubs and to Alam o H eights P re s ­ byterian Church. 
She and J a n e y m a d e 
Swedish m eatballs. F in ­ nish sweet rolls and hot red wine spited with al­ monds, raisins, and vod­ ka for M rs. S c h u l t e ’s garden club m em bers. 
At Alamo Heights An­ nika is taking courses in 
G erm an, art. economics, 
Texas and U S. history. 

W hen sh e r e t u r n s t< 
F inland, th is s u m m e r she will have 18 m onths o g y m n a s iu m 
(h ig l school) to finish, and hei courses will be orjente< toward m athem atics am scie n c es. A fter g y m n a slum .-she plans to attent c o lle g e to s tu d y lan guageS. 
Before she leaves Sal 
Antonio, she intends t< sjiend every w arm da; basking in the sun. Sin wants to show off a Texa suntan to her family ii 
Finland.

Grow your own pineapples 

By ELVIN MCDONALD 
When Columbus m ade a voyage to the New World , he found the pineapple, tasted its exotic sweetness and re­ turned to Spain with plants for Queen Isabella. 
How Ananas com osu s, known otherwise as pineapple, cam e to be a lm o s t sy n o n y m o u s wi th 
Hawaii is a story for another time. 

The pineapple is only one m em ber of an enormous grouping of related plants we know as the 
Bromeliad Fam ily, which also in­ clu d es the S ou th 's p ictu resq u e 
(and som etim es pesky) Spanish moss. 
Between these two best-known, and perhaps extrem e exam p les, there are literally thousands of bromeliads that make great house plants. 
The first two to be widely dis­ 

 tributed were the dwarf pineapple and Silver King, a selected form of 
Aechmea (Ef h-m ee-uht. 
To understand bromeliads, it is important to know these two facts: 
( I ) They a re epip hytes or air plants, not parasites as Spanish moss is som ethim es accused of being. 
(2) 
All bromeliads are* classified botanically into many different genera or names such as 
Ananas (the Latin name for pin­ eapple). Aechmea ( S i l v e r i n g and 

F o s te r's F av o rite are two w ell­ known v arieties) and tillandsia 
(Spanish moss is one species, but countless others are far showier). 
H ere’s the ca re I give a pot- grown b rom eliad : L ight, som e direct sun. or directly beneath the tubes in a tluorescent-light g a r­ den. Tem perature, average house or apartment, ideally a range of 
6o-8o F. 
— 

Humidity. 4o per cent or more. 

 otherwise mist twice a day for best growth. Soil m o istu re: Drench twice a week with water of room temperature; allow’ to drain and pour off any excess remaining in the saucer after one hour. 
Once a week, turn the plant up­ side down over a sink and drain, any water that m ay have been standing in the vase formed by the leaf rosette, turn right side up and re-fill the cup with fresh, room- temperature water.

Simplify household chores 

SA N AN TO N IO EXPRESS— Thursday March 1o 1977 

D EA R * R E A D E R S : 
Around-the- house repairs have always been an ordeal for many people. Here are a few hints gathered over the years thai simplify many chores. 
DEAR POLLY — When I could not find a yardstick, I hit on the idea of thumbtacking my tape measure to the broom handle. 
. 

 tape. The bracket does not slip and it is 
DEAR POLLY 
— Instead of dis- just where you want it to be. carding old dish drainers, we save 
DEAR POLLY — Try using golf tees them to use in the winter. Place the to stop window rattles in the winter, drainer on several thicknesses of old 
The tees are easy to insert in the proper newspapers, then place wet boots in the places in the frame. They will not drainer until the water drains off of show . but certainly stop the noise. them. 
DEAR POLLY — Put several soft 
If plenty of newspapers are used 
I paper towels by the telephone before

To measure a half cup of butter, fill the measuring cup half full of water. 
Add the butter in pieces until the water is raised to the full cup line. 
M akes hardened butter easy to measure.

SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS— Thursday March IO 1977 
Brick shortage fails to halt w ork on hospital addition 

Construction of a six- story addition to Baptist 
Memorial Hospital con­ tinues, despite a short­ age of bricks caused by the natural gas shortage. 
Hospital officials said bricks used in the project were being m ade at a plant in .Arkansas. But the hard w in te r’s c u r­ tailment of natural gas sh ip m e n ts closed the plant. 
Spaw-Glass Co., gener­ al co n tra c to rs for the project, found another brick company in Austin that could supply the bricks, officials said. 
The new addition will provide expanded em er­ gency room se rv ic e , operating and recovery 

HOSPITAL 
HAPPENINGS 

 rooms and business of­ fice space. Completion is sched uled for 
S ep ­ tember, hospital officials said. 
While construction at 
Baptist continues, the start of a long-awaited 
South Side hospital will finally get under way this sum m er, according to 
David Rose, regional d ir e c to r of A m erican 
Medicorp, Inc., who will 

 m anage the com pleted hospital 
The lH6-bed Southwest 
Community Hospital will be located at SW Military 
Drive and Barlite Boule­ vard. 
Rose said the project, announced nearly two years ago, w^s delayed because of the national credit crunch. 
Financing for the $6 million project has been 

 obtained, he said, with construction set to begin in June. 
The hospital is expect­ ed to be ready for use in 
J a n is a r y 1979, 
Rose said. 
The new South Side hospital will be owned by a group of local doctors and businessmen, calling themselves 
Southwest 
H ospitals 
L im ited . 

Dr. 
David Ross, as­ sistant professor of phar­ macology and psychiatry at the U n iversity of 
Texas 
Health 
Science 
Center, has received the 
1977 Distinguished Ser­ vice Award from the Al­ coholism Council of Tex­ as.

SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS— Thursday Morch IO 1977 

Afro-Arab summit a success 

J COMPILED FROM WIPE SERVICES 
( AIKO — T he first joint sum m it conference of governm ent leaders from black Africa and the' Arab world ended here W ednesday with delegates from both re­ gions declaring that they had obtained more than they bad dared to hope. 

Egypt and Saudi Ara­ bia emerged as the prin­ cipal winners from the conference, each with its power and prestige en­ hanced. 

Other results included: 

• The beginning, for the first time, of an in­ stitutionalized political iftid econom ic coop era­ tion between black Africa and the Arab world. 

WORLD DIGEST 

• 
A joint condemna­ tion of “ imperialsim, co­ lon ialism , 
Z ionism , apartheid and all other forms of racial and reli­ gious d isc rim in a tio n especially in Africa. P a­ lestine and the occupied 
Arab territories.” 

• A pledge by the oil- rieh Arabs to give $1o 45 billion to black Africa for long-range economic development. 

• A statement defining the Palestinian guerrilla movement and the black guerrilla organizations in southern Africa as “ joint 
Afro-Arab causes” and 

 calling for total support. 
• 
A b re a k th ro u g h toward an eventual ac­ com m odation betw een 
Jordan and the Palestine 
Liberation Organization as King Hussein and Ya- sir 
A rafat, the 
PLO leader, held their first bilateral talks in more than seven y e a rs and discussed the need for an eventual link betw een 
Jordan and the proposed independent Palestinian slate. 

Bishops free 

NAIROBI - Five of the 

18 Anglican bishops who publicly criticized Presi­ dent Idi Amin's ruthless­ ness last month have fled 
Uganda for fear of their lives, c h u rch so u rc e s said Wednesday. 

These sources said the b ish o p s re m a in in g in 
U gan da a re v irtu a lly hostages, unable to fulfill their religious duties. “ It is safe to assume that the bishops are being m o­ lested.” one source said. 
Ile declined to elaborate on the grounds that the bishops are already en­ dangered. 

Sol devalued 

LIMA, Peru — Peru devalued its cu rren cy 
Wednesday, following a 

 similar move by Brazil the day before. 

For Peru, it was the 
37th devaluation in 25 weeks. The new value of its sol was fixed at 73.12 to the dollar. 

Brazil Tuesday deva­ lued its c r u z e ir o s its third devaluation in 1977. setting the exchange rate at 12.98 to the dollar. 

Red markets 

TOKYO — Japan will help the Soviet Union es­ tab lish m odern s u p e r ­ m ark ets in eastern Si­ berian cities, informed sources said Wednesday. 

The Soviet Union plans to set up modern super­ 

 m arket chains through­ out the co u n try in a 
“ distribution revolution” aim ed at d is tr ib u tin g consumer products and foods more effectively, the sources said 

I .S. offers help 

BUCHAREST - The 
U nited S tates offered 
Wednesday to help Ro­ mania monitor its geolo­ gical situation over the critical weeks that will follow F r id a y ’s e a r t h ­ quake. 

The offer was based on advice from se ism o lo ­ gists that aftershocks or even a second m a jo r earthquake might occur in a m atter of weeks or months.

SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS— Thursday March 1o 1977 
U N IQ U E G H O ST TOW N 

Do some of those w ho once lived at San Jose de P alafox lie buried here? The cem etery is on the tow n s site. G ravestones that can 

 be deciphered are of a later d ate but p lainly some o f the older graves d ate bock to an e arlier tim e. This above-ground burial vault 

 could well go back to the days w hen this w as a Spanish frontier tow n. 

No ghost town quite m atches one that died a violent death 15o years ago. 

The town is San Jose de Palafox — on the banks of the Rio Grande above 
Laredo. Raiding Comanches finally caused its abandonment. 

The Comanches burned it but the buildings were made of stone and many ruins remain today. 

George and Bonnie Carmack have visited the site and also talked with 
Carmen Perry, San Antonio historian and archivist, who has published a book. “San Jose de Palafox.” based on documonts found in Saint Mary’s Uni­ versity library in 1969. 

The Carmacks’ story will be in Sa- lurday’s Express-News. 

All photos are by Bonnie Carmack. 

Joy Smith steps through the d o o rw a y o f an old ranchhouse near the San Jose 

 de P alafox site. This typ e o f construction — large stones chinked with hundreds of smaller stones 
— w as used throughout the San Jose de Palafox site. Jay s 

 father has I 3 ,o o o acres o f ranchland under lease here on the Rio G ra n d e . The lease contains the site o f San Jose de P alafox.

Cooperation betw een state and federal officials is the goal of a committee which m et Tuesday in 
Austin. 

The Federal-State Law 
Enforcement Coordinat­ ing Committee includes in its membership the four Texas U.S. Attor­ neys, Texas Atty. Gen. 
John 
Hill, prosecutors from the large metropo­ litan areas and others. 

Hill and U.S. Atty. 
John E. Clark were co­ chairm en of the panel during 1976. Hill will re­ tain his slot, but another 
U.S. A ttorney will r e ­ place Clark soon. 

The panel meets occa­ sionally to discuse prob­ lems of mutual interest to the prosecutor and of­ ficers, Clark explained. 
“ We discuss problems of concurrent jurisdic­ tion — such as drug cases 
— and share information and intelligence when we can,” he said. 

(lark's days on the committee — and on the 
U.S. Attorney General’s advisory com m ittee — 
•are numbered since he announced his re sig n a ­ tion. 

Much U.S. Courthouse coffee chatter centers ar­ ound potential rep lace­ ments for 
Clark and 
U.S. Marshal 
James V. 
Johnson. 

U.S. M agistrate 
Jo­ seph F. Leonard has re-

Al ll a.m. Archbishop

BEAT 

Bv BUX Nlim 
Renovation, preservation in practice 

Concern over preserv­ ing and renovating older buildings is not only be­ ing preached in som e quarters of City Halt. It is being practiced. 
Boh Fischer, an ad­ ministrative aide to City 
Mgr. Tom lluebnrr, has finished renovating an older house at 1o6 Shad- well Drive. He, wife 
Mary and new baby moving in this weekend 
And Marx returning to 
Work Monday at 
Robert 
Hunter’s 
Planning De­ partment. 

Speaking of the city manager s office, llueb- ner makes a startling observation about the. cities he worked for in 
California, before com­ ing here two months ago. 

No ehugholes ui the streets out there, even after heavy rains that leave San Antonio streets 
(lotted. “ We have a lot of chuckholes, but this is the first city I ve been in that has ehugholes, lie chuglcd 

W hat about c o m p ro ­ mising on potholes? Or would someone get the 

Around 
City Hall 

Bx IIM w o rn fits Hall Reporter 

 wrong im pression and raid the streets or try tu sell them. 

All systems go fur the 
April 2 City Council elec­ tion. At lea st City Clerk 
Garland Jackson hopes

Sears highway passenger tire warranty 

Full warranty during first 2 5 % of usable treadles lf the tire faits apparently due to a defect in material or workm anship during the first 25% of the original usable tread (original tread less 2/32 ), Sears will replace the tire. free of charge, or refund the purchase price. 
Limited warranty 
Tire failure lf the tire fails apparently due to a defect in material or workm anship after 2 5 % of the tread is worn, and for the remaining 7 5 % of the original usable tread, Sears will replace the tire or give you a refund, charging you only the proportion of the current price plus f ederal In c ise Ta* that represents the portion of the usable tread used. 

Tread wearout- It the tread w ears out (2 / 3 2 ' or less remaining) before you receive the m iles specified. 
S e a rs will, at its option, either replace the tire or give a refund, cha rging in either ca se the proportion of the current price piu s Federal E x cise Tax that represents the ratio of m iles of us ige actually re­ ceived to the miles specified This does not apply to wearout caused by improper inflation, m isalign- went, or ta lure to use and maintain (he tire as recom m ended 
To obtain warranty service, simply return the tire to the nearest Sears store throughout the United States,

SO UTH T E X A S 

Snow belt gets warm weather 

ASSOCIATED W ESS 
Unusually high temperatures, in some cases record highs, were registered in the Midwest and 
East Wednesday, and except for the far West the weather was pleasant almost nation-wide. Skies were clear or partly cloudy. 
The Plains states were somewhat cooler than on 
Tuesday, but still warmer than usual. 
Scattered showers, with snow in the mountains, reached from the northern half of the Pacific coast to the northern Rocky Mountains Wednesday. With the precipitation came a cold front, spreading across the West. 
Heavy snow warnings were in effect for the Cas­ cade Mountains in Washington and Oregon. 
The forcast for Thursday included showers and thundershowers from east Kansas, Oklahoma and 
Texas through the southwest Great Lakes region to 
Alabama and Georgia.

Bv Norman V invent Beale and Ruth 

Father an alcoholic 

Q. I d like your advice on something. My father is an alcoholic and I would like to help him overcome this. My mother and I went to Alcoholics Anonymous to talk to them and they told us we couldn't do anything, he would have to realize it for himself. I lust don’t believe this. 
There has to he an answer to this problem. I’m saying this because ifs causing so many problems and unhappiness in our family. I would like my father to care about us and his home. It would make my brothers so happy if he did things with them. 
Please help us. 

SA N AN T O N IO 
P R E C IP IT A T IO N 
W I 
197* 
o 54 
A vt 
Rte 
Jon.

A. The principle ut Al­ coholics Anonymous, as we understand it, is that the alcoholic must realize he can no longer handle alcohol and turns to A.A. for help. IIowe\er. >ou might ask ir an A.A. member could invite him to come to meetings where he may hear the testimonies of those who have overcome the prob­ lem. This might motivate him to take action. In the meantime, >ou and your family can attend Alanon meetings, which are held tor families of alcoholics. 
We have seen many 

 people freed of alcoho­ lism through prayer and 

 faith. Why not set up in the family a prayer program? But do this quietly. And don’t get discouraged; God can perform miracles. So picture your father as one of those miracles. 
We have written a 

 booklet. W’h afs Vour 
Trouble?, which has a section on “ There Is an 
Alcoholic in 
Our 

Family.** It has helped others with questions such as yours and anyone reading this column who wishes a free copy may write to us for one. Ad­ dress your request to Dr. and Mrs. Peale, Box iii, 
Pawling, N Y. I25tt.

Divorced twice and living with a man 

Q I'm years old and base been married aud divorced twice Both husbands said they lox tnt me but needed more than one woman. I have found a man I love and want to marry but I’m terrified of another failure. He seems different than the others except he is overly good-hearted to the point of financial problems. 
Logically, the match seems bad He isn t making enough money to support Ion and my children. He isn t handy around the house or with cars Ile likes city. I like country. He only goes to church because I said I wouldn't marry a man again that wouldn't go to church with me. Because of all these obstacles I asked him to live with me. I keep telling myself God will forgive me because I truly love him and want to marry him 
I feel terrible, yet I don’t want to separate. What is vour advice'* 

A In all kindness we 

 must say that you are really mixed up and need mental untangling. By all means do not get in­ volved in another 

 marriage until you get organized. And you will never get straightened out living with this man. 
Our suggestion is that 

 you go to your pastor, tell 

 him the whole story and ask for his guidance. Ile should direct vou to psi- chological treatment that will help you rewolve your personality conflicts and failures. 
As we see it, you are 

 your own problem. But you can change from a failure to a success pat­ tern ol living. 

^ ant* to become a performer

Instruction Second sing or act at every possible opportunity, always 

 seeking to perfect your­ 

 self.
