Mart in sharp setback 

SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS— Thursday March Io 1977 
Page 

N EW YO R K (A P ) - 
The stock market's ear* ly-March rally gave way 
Wednesday to selling that dealt the Dow Jones in­ dustrial average its sharpest setback in nearly seven weeks. 
The Dow average of 3o blue chip industrials fell 
9.14 to 942.9o. for its lar­ gest loss since it took a 
9.o4-point drop on Jan. 
2o. 
Losers outnumbered gainers by about a 9-4 margin on the New York 
Stock Exchange. 
Big Board volume to­ talled 
19.o8 m illion shares, against 19.52 million on Tuesday. 
Skepticism 

The Dow climbed more than 2o points from the start of last week through 
Monday, but a good 

 many W all Streeters viewed the upturn with skepticism because it came on sluggish volume. 
When prices turned downward toward the close on Tuesday, an­ alysts said, traders seemed to concede that the rally had run its course. 
Brokers also noted that the market had to con­ tend with an adverse news background. 
For one thing, they cit­ ed Wall Street’s percep­ tion of an unfavorable climate in Congress for business. 
The 
House passed a lax bill Tuesday- leaving out an added investment tax credit that President Carter has proposed. 
Walter Wriston, chair­ man of New Y ork’s Ci­ 

 ticorp. predicted Tues­ day afternoon that short term interest rates would rise by I to 1.5 percen­ tage points this year. 
Analysts also observed that more unpleasant news was expected 
Thursday in the govern­ ment’s report on wholesale price trends for February. 
Standard & Poor’s in­ dex of 4oo industrials fell 
.91 to 111.3o, and S & P ’s 
5oo-stodk composite in­ dex gave up .77 to 1oo.1o. 
Retail stocks took a beating amid disappoint­ ment over the earnings reports for the quarter ended in January issued by several major com­ panies in the industry over the past two days. 
J.C. Penney and FAV. 
Woolworth posted lower quarterly profits. S.S. 

Kresge recorded an earnings gain, but its data also showed a de­ cline in its pre-tax profit margin. 
Kresge shares led the active list as of the 4 p.m. close of the N YSE, down 
I at 32% after a l7s-point loss Tuesday. Selling of the stock by some of the company’s many institu­ tional followers was evident in four block trades, totalling more than 4oo.ooo shares, in the two sessions. 

DOW JONES INDUSTRIAL AVERAGE 
'•loin. 

Slumped 

Woolworth slumped 1% to 24% and Penney was down I at 4o%. 
IBM slipped % to 279% with the company’s offer for 4 million of its shares at §28o apiece due to ex­ pire at the end of the day. 
Aguirre Co. was one of the day’s strongest per­ formers, up 2% at 14 on word that the company’s trustees planned to 

'Y 
M ARCH 

 liquidate it. 
Patrick 
Petroleum rose I to 15%. The com­ pany reported Tuesday on a 
Louisiana exploratory well. 
The N Y SE’s composite index fell .41 to 54.42.

Am erican 
Stock 
E x ­ change market value in­ dex was down .o4 at 
111 38. and the NASDAQ composite index of over- the-counter stocks posted a .48 loss to 95.75. 
Capital spending hike expected 

WASHINGTON (A P ) - Businesses plan an 117 per cent increase iii capi­ tal spending this year over 197o. the 
Commerce Departm ent reported 
Wednesday. 

The latest estim ate was little changed from a January report on projected investments iii new plants and equipment. 
Tilt1 department said a survey of business sentiment in January and 
February showed expected capital 

 spending to total §134.58 billion this year. 
The survey in January, which was based on November and December reports, estimated 1977 capital spend­ ing at $134.95 billion. 

Tile January report had estimated capital spending for last year at $121.2 billion but the latest survey showed spending of $12o.5 billion. 
Capital spending constitutes the ba­ sic underpinning of economic growth 

 since such investment expands job opportunities and permits tin1 greater efficiencies necessary to hold down price increases. 

John VV. Kendrick, the Commerce 
Department’s chief economist, said the increase in capital spending, if taken alone, would not be enough to generate the 6 per cent total economic growth targeted by the Carter administration. 
But Kendrick said the stimulus pack­ age proposed by Carter should be 

 enough lo provide the extra push needed. 
He also said he expects the stimulus and a general pickup in economic activity to boost capital spending in the second half of this year above projec­ tions. 
The survey had projected spending at seasonally adjusted annual rates of 
$129.2 billion in the current quarter, 
$132.7 billion in the second quarter and 
$137.9 billion in the final six months of the year.

M iam i to Paris flight approved 

C O M PILED PRO M W IRE SERVICES 

WASHINGTON — The Civil Aeronautics Board 
Wednesday granted National Airlines authority to fix* between Miami and Paris for 9o days starting 
June 22. giving the airline an alternate tour to 
Europe in case ( ’.rat Britain terminates a U.S.-U.K. air service transport agreement. 
Loan decision pends 

NEW YORK — Kenneth Axeleon, who has been designated deputy secretary of the U.S. Treasury, said Wednesday despite optimism among various officials, no decision has been made by Washington to grant a loan to help New York City out of its fiscal jam. 
2 join exch anges 

N EW YORK — The number of women s t o c k ­ brokers at the nation’s two largest exchanges will swell by 5o per cent Friday. 
That’s when Lynne Greenberg and Ellen Lee start work. Ms. Greenberg bought a seat at the American 
Stock Exchange, and Mrs. Lee, representing a brokerage house, will be on the trading floor of the 
New York Stock Exchange. 

Oil imports still climb 

NEW YORK (A P ) - 
The Fluted States con­ tinues to import crude oil and refilled petroleum products at a record lev­ 

 el, the American Petro­ leum 
Institute said 
Wednesday. 
In the week ended 
March 4, im ports of 

 crude and products totaled 1o.3 million bar­ rels a day. the third straight week of record totals. 
Iowans in S .A. to promote pork 

Ail Iowa delegation checked into 
San Antonio Wednesday to promote the sale of Iowa pork at Handy Andy 
Supermarkets Wednesday through 
Friday. 
Included in the delegation is Lin­ da Harper, a 19-year-old freshman at Iowa State University who was crowned Iowa Pork Queen in Jan- uar>. 
The 5-foot-4 beauty is from Colo, 
Iowa, and is majoring in child development. 
The trip was arranged through 
Handy Andy Supermarkets and the 
Iowa Development Commission. 
Norman Smith of Van Meter. 
Iowa. said Iowa currently is in the grip of a severe drought. Ile said his 

 area has received only 1% inches of rain since last June and said he was afraid of w ind erosion. 
Others in the delegation include 
Mr. and Mrs. Ted Benshoof of Ma­ dison County, Mr. and Mrs. R A. 
Howe. Don and Sylvia Konopasek of 
Ramson, M r. and Mrs. G ary 
Schendel of Merrill. Mrs. Karen 
McC’reedy of Ainsworth and M ar­ shall Richards and Russ Sanders of the development commission. 
Howe is president of the Iowa 
Pork 
Producers and 
Mrs. 
McCreedy is president of the Iowa 
Bor kelt es. 
The Iowa visitors were honored at a reception and dinner Wednesday night at the Hilton Palacio Del Rio. 

A year ago, combined imports of oil and pro­ ducts were only 7.7 mil­ lion barrels a day. 
D istillate fuels, p ri­ marily home heating oil, accounted for 1.2 million of the 3.7 million barrels 
(tf products imported each day. the A PI said. 
Reflecting the much m ilder weather last 
.winter, distillate imports in the comparable w;eek a year ago amounted to only 185,(MMI barrels a day and total refined product imports totaled 2.3 m il­ lion barrels a day. 
Inventories of distil­ lates are thought to be at a safe level. They stood at 135.2 million barrels in the .week ended March 4. 
That is almost 4 million barrels more than the previous week. 

Gasoline stocks stood at 252.2 million barrels in the latest week. 4.5 mil­ lion than the previous week and HI H million more than a year ago.

"It won t be long until w e'll be looking for tain .” John Walch of 
Quill) said Wednesday morning after unloading a trailerfu l of black calves at the Union Stock 
Yards. 
W alch ‘ agreed the winter had been one of the wettest in this area 
W ith the clearing weather of the last two weeks, he is about to fin­ ish up planting maize at the place.

Walch sa al Last year at this time the creek oil his 

 place was d-y. This year it still is running. 
Last week the place got a little rain and a little hail, he said.

Firm denies part in Korean scandal 

DALLAS (A P ) — E-Systems Inc. denied Wednes­ day any connection to the Korean scandal — reports of alleged bribes to Korean officials — ami said payments of commissions to a group of Koreans were business transactions. 
In a letter to stockholders, chairman of the I iou rd 
John W. Dixon said recent published reports linking 
E-Systems to alleged b rilie s had "unjustifiably put into question iii the n e w s media” the superior reputation of the company. 
Dixon acknowledged that two I S. residents through whom the company paid commissions to a 
Korean group had been sued by the Securities and 
Exchange Commission to compel their testimony in res|x»nse to an SEC subpoena. 
"But E-Systems was not a party to, and has not participated in the lawsuit despite the inference given in the news reports that E-Systems lias been 
•accused’ of something in that lawsuit.” 
The two residents had acted a s collection agents for a group of "distinguished individuals” in Korea who had acted us E-Systems representatives in the negotiation of contracts to sell m ilitary radio equipment to the Korean government. Dixon said. 

Dixon said the distinguished individuals were checked with tile U.S. Embassy tor integrity and later decided to call themselves tile "Korean Re­ search Institute” iii their dealings with E-Systems. 

Tile group was to receive a commission not to exceed 5 per cent of the total sales of military radios aud related products to Korea The company lia s paid $1 4 million out of nearly $32.7 m illion of business with the Korean government. 

Dixon said the Korean citizen resident of the Los 
Angeles area whom E-Systems did not know as its representative and also opened an account in a Los 
Angeles bank. 
The Korean group later appointed a second agent, 
Dixon said that in response to SEC inquires the company had furnished all pertinent information in 
197H reait related iii the commission payments to tile 
Korean group

DAN 
COOK: 
A Man tor 
All Seasons 

Whatever the season . . , 
Football, basketball, baseball.. . ii it has to do with sports, Dan is on top of it. 

Thats why he's San Antonio's mosMalked-about sports writer. He's on the inside looking out. . . and reporting to his readers 

Awards'' Sure He's won plenty. His work has been recognized as the very best and he s proud of it. But Dan doesn't rest on his laurels He just keeps on reporting, going beyond the headlines to the in-depth stories. 

That's why Dan is Mr. Sports in San Antonio. 

Dan Cook . . . 
Every Day in tne 
San Antonio News 

 and Sunday in the 
EXPRESS NEWS

W e d n e s d a y a fte r an e ig h t-y e a r a b ­ sence. 
“ I ’m looking forw ard to this,” Kissinger said with a smile, seated with a handful of students in a room at the Georgetown

S e c r e t 
S e rv ic e m e n . seem ed relaxed and sub­ dued at welcoming cere­ m o n ies on th e G e o rg e ­ town cam pus, where he h a s a c e c e p t e d a six- m o n th p o sitio n as a visiting professor.

Gap told in child services 

A huge gap in m ental health services exists for em o t io n a lly d i s t u r b e d children in B exar Coun­ ty. 
According to Kathy In­ gle. chairperson of the 
C hild A d v o cacy T a s k 
F o rc e of th e 
M e n ta l 
H e a lth 
A s s n ., 
“ O nly one-fifth of the children who need m ental health services on an outpatient basis are being served. 
“ W e ’ve c o n f ir m e d through a survey that the problem is crucial in our com m unity.” 
The m ost serious gap in services is in alternate residental care facilities, she said. 
“ In the last two m onths w e ’ve had 38 c h ild re n with emotional problem s who have needed place­ m ent and there are just not enough facilities to care for th e m ," reported 
Dorothy LePere, director of protective services for children for the D epart­ ment of Public Welfare. 
Speakers are available on the subject through the Mental Health Assn. speakers bureau. 
For booking a speaker or for further information call the MUA office, 222-1571.

Deputy Secretary of the T reasury De- part m en t, the agency’s second highest post.

Carter Administration was inform ed of a pending New York T im es article describing a num ber of serious ques. lions that had been raised about Axel* son’s business conduct during a feder­ al grand jury inquiry in Brooklyn.

President C arter of hts request. t e lle r

Penney Co who also served as Deputy 
Mayor for Fm unee for New York city, said he had beedi exonerated u! any impropriety stem m ing from an exten­ sive federal investigation oi alleged kickback schem es inside I t 
Penney,

By JAM ES MCCRORY 

Mayor Lila Cockrell led the city into a budget deficit in the sam e y ear the city raked in $37.7 m illion in City 
P u b lic 
S e rv ic e o v e r c h a r g e s to c o n s u m e rs. Jo h n M onfrey ch a rg ed 
Wednesday. 
The deficit was first estim ated ut $3 million, Monfrey claim ed, but it now appears som e funds m ay have to tie shifted to m ak e up a deficit of $4 million. 
“ What the deficit will be tomorrow or next week is anybody’s guess.” the candidate for m ayor asserted. 
“ W hatever the deficit ends up being, 
I would like to point out that it takes some kind of m isleadership and m is­ m anagem ent to accom plish a financial blunder of that proportion." 
Monfrey was speaking out at a fund­ raiser at Villita Assembly Hall which drew un audience of m ore than BDD supporters. 
If the throng on hand consisted of paying custom ers. Monfrey gave his cam paign a financial shot in the arm . with tickets going for $25 a head. 
F ro m the cheers of the crowd when 
Monfrey announced he is totally dedi­ cated to getting m ore sports a ttra c ­ tions for Sun Antonio, the crowd a p ­ peared to be sports oriented. 
Ricci W are se rv ed as m a s te r of cerem onies, and entertainers included 
Johnny Bush and Darrell McCall. 
Moneymaker 
“ Sports is the biggest m oneym aker a city can have, and it ru b s off on everybody,” Monfrey said. 
“ As m ayor, one of m y top priorities will be to m ake a m ajor sports co m ­ plex a reality an d to keep it full 32 weeks a y ear.” 
Under Mayor Cockrell’s leadership, 
Monfrey charged, the city accepted a gas settlem ent which won t benefit the utility ratepayers. 
Totally ignoring form er Mayor Pro 
Tem Jose San Martin and other candi­ d ates •in the m a y o ra l race. M onfrey said th e city u n d e r M rs. C o c k re ll’s leadership accepted the budget deficit in the face of the $37.7 million “ CPS b o n a n z a .“ an d $17 m illio n in c o m ­ munity development funds. 
That, he said, com es on top of re­ g u la r p ro p e rty ta x es and city sales taxes. 
“ T h e city c a n 't affo rd two m o re y e a rs of th a t k in d of l e a d e r s h i p . ’’ 
Monfrey assessed. 

A l t e r n a t i v e 
Monfrey said he is offering the citi­ zens an alternative, fresh leadership from a successful businessm an who believes that hooks should balance, aud the citizens should get their m on­ ey s worth out of tax dollars. 
O bserving that the city is ru n n in g short on o p p o rtu n ity , M onfrey said that the city m u st offer people m ore than a shrine and a river. 
“ We m ust offer them opportunity, jobs, and. m ost of all. grow th.’’ Mon­ frey said. 
Awk how would Monfrey do all that? 
Well, he said districting will require a stronger m ayor, one who can work with people and deal with m anagem ent problem s. 
He said he would approach the utility 

*Sports in the biggent m oneym aker a city can hare am i it rubs o ff on everybody' 

 question from the consum ers’ point of view. 

Charging that in Ran Antonio "blue ribbon com m ittees talk everything to 
•d eath ," Monfrey said the city m ust be sold to new business and industry. 
“ We m u st a g g re s s iv e ly seek new business out and this req u ires m ore positive le ad e rsh ip ut city hall, and action instead of ta lk ,” M onfrey r e ­ ported. 
Urging stim ulation of the downtown economy by bringing people back into the core of the city to live, shop and be entertained, Monfrey said now citizens come downtown for a m ajor attraction and are run off by having their cars towed away. 
“ Who w a n ts to c o m e b ack tinder c irc u m s ta n c e s like t h a t ? " M onfrey asked. 
T rad e relations can 't be a one-way 

 street. Monfrey asserted. He term ed the Mexican T ra d e F a ir “ a good ex­ ample of bud m an ag e m en t." Ile noted the city has spent m illions of dollars enlarging the convention exhibit hall for that one event. 
“ And now tin* Mexican government wants us to pay them to com e here and sell their goods.*’ Monfrey said. 
Monfrey said he would open up the trade fair to C entral and South A m eri­ ca. and work on setting up a p erm a n ­ ent trade center in a free trade zone open the year around. 
“ I want to offer all areas of the city growth generators, so that we can pull d ev e lo p m e n t to o u r c i ty ,” M onfrey wound up his platform. 
“ L et’s m ake it m ore economical to build everyw here and w here there is no d a n g e r of c o n t a m i n a t i n g th e aquifer.”

By VICKIE DAVIDSON 
Nearly all District 4 City 
Council candidates gave across the board support to Commun­ ities Organized for Public Ser­ vice (COPS) issues Wednesday. 
But. COPS Accountability Night was no Sunday School social, COPS had a surprise question: “ Who’s giving you money to run for office?" 
“ We need to know if interest groups with m oney are bucking th ese ca n d i­ d ate s." said d r e g P astran o . “ C ontri­ b u to rs w ill w an t a r e t u r n on th e ir money." 
Tells of hacking 
Candidate Johnny Mata said he had backing from 3(1 South Side businesses. 
He also said he had the support of West 
Side produce m agnate F ran k Sepulve­ da. 
COPS m em b ers asked if he bad any backing from ABC; In* said no. They asked him about Red McCombs, board m em ber of Alliance for a B etter City. 
“ Red M cCom bs is my b o ss.’’ said 
Mata. “ He bas not supported m e yet. lie said . . . if you need any help let m e know.” 
The crowd of some 175 people react­ ed with boos 
They also disapproved when c an d i­ date F ran k Wing said his biggest con­ tributor was Edm undo Zaragosa 
Gift and loan 
Zaragosa, director of the Econom ic 
O p p o rtu n itie s D e v e lo p m e n t C o rp ., gave him $3oo and loaned him $2oo. he said. 
Asked if that would cre ate a poten­ tial conflict of interest for him if Zar- agosa’s interests and COPS’ interests differed, he said no. 
Candidate Willie Meyer said she re ­ ceived $187 in contributions from her friends. 
T h e o th e r c a n d i d a t e s — J i m m y 
F lo res S r.. Bill L effler, C A. Kelly, 
Manuel Flores. Rani Perez and John 
M ach ad o — said th e y w e re p a y in g most or all ol their expenses. 
Other questions 

To COPS six other questions, all the c a n d id a te s — w ith th e ex cep tio n of 
Manuel Flores — said they supported 
COPS on everything. 
The q u estio n s dealt w ith d ra in a g e funding, funding for streets, an indus­ trial park for junkyards and other c a ­ pital im provm ent questions. 
Manuel Flores voted no on th ree of the questions. 
After all the questions, COPS P re s i­ dent Beatrice Gallego said, “ T here are too m any yeses.” 
"W e are not ignorant, and we do not believe every yes, yes, yes th a t’s up there.” 
Mrs. Gallego said COPS was looking for council m em b ers who w ill fight for 
COPS 
District 4 is one of the four council d istric ts in which COPS has a large num ber of m em bers 
Account a billy nights for candidates are also sch ed u le d in the o th e r d is ­ tricts

Way com m ittee.

3o-nieinber vo lu n teer c o m m itte e is just one step iii the long-range process of contributors deciding w here their m o n ey sh o u ld be m ost effectiv ely spent,” said Mrs. David Reedy. ch a ir­ man of the P ro g ram and search Deve­ lopment com m ittee

Karotkin's Pool and Patio Shop Spring Opening 
GREAT OUTDOOR FURNITURE SALE 

B a rry ; 
R obinson 

An alarming story 

 about two Spurs 

The evening of Dec. 21, 1976 is a night two m em bers of the 
Spurs will never forget. Their pro careers could have been severely scarred because of what happened — or what did not happen — on that night. 

It should be remembered from the very beginning that the players did absolutely nothing wrong. They were simply victims of circum stances, in­ nocent b y stan d ers in a frightening system that is often cruel to people with fame. 

The two players were questioned by the FBI because an informant claimed they were in a local restaurant at the same time as a known bookmaker. 
There is no way of learning exactly what the inform ant reported. But it d o e sn 't m a tte r b e c a u se th e re was nothing to report. 

M atter of fact, one of the players denied being at the restau ran t that evening. Presum ably, the informant saw someone who looked like him. The other player was there, having dinner with relatives. 

Somewhere else in the restaurant, far away at another table, a bookie was eating dinner. The player did not know the bookie. He probably didn’t even see the man. 

But the FBI was told that two pro athletes were seen at the sam e place and at the same time as a bookie so a routine investigation followed. 

For obvious reasons. I am not going to reveal the nam es of the players. 
Anytime a pro athlete is connected to an FBI investigation, dam age to his image and career is possible. 

That is the frightening part of this story. Simply by dining with relatives. a pro athlete flirted with d isaster. 
Even scarier is the case of the other player. Because someone presumably looks like him, he was subjected to FBI questioning. 

Must be careful 

When you think about the dangers involved, it s amazing that most ath­ letes are so friendly with fans. 

Over 9(1 per cent of the people who ask for autographs are strangers. The athlete has no w ay of know ing if the fan is a plu m b er, p re a c h e r, b an ker or bookie. 

Pro athletes realize that it is wise to stay fa r aw ay from g a m b le rs and bookies but stran g ers constantly de­ mand and plead for their time. 
Stick around the Arena following a gam e some night and notice all the fans stand in g outside the dressin g room door. These fans are there to met! the players, to shake hands and talk about the game. 

In most eases, players have no Idea who they are chatting with. Probably a season ticket holder but who knows? 
Maybe the fan happens to be the God­ father. Maybe even an FBI agent. 

The point is that pro athletes are easy targets for serious, touchy inves­ tigations. 

Also, this should make us appreciate the tim e and courtesy given by pro athletes. 
And maybe it explains why some of them refuse to sign autographs or talk to strange writers and fans. 
Maybe the ones who avoid people were once the subject of a similar in­ vestigation. simply because they were dining in the sam e re sta u ra n t as a stranger w ho happened to lie a bookie. 
Maybe they were questioned because they shook the hand of a stranger, who happened to Ik* a bookie. 

Scary part 

The scary part of this incident is how easily it could have been blown out of proportion. 

 lf I used the players’ names here, another paper elsewhere iii the nation might pick it up but not go into the necessary details. Most of the nation might end up reading only that two 
Spurs were investigated for their al­ leged relationship with bookmakers. 

That statement might nut be totally wrong but it obviously does not tell the whole — or true — story. Some people would then associate the Spurs with bookies. 

The im age and rep u tatio n of the players and the franchise could be drastically damaged. And all because the 
HH questioned players about something so meaningless aud ridicu­ lous. 
Maybe the FBI was just doing its job, maybe it has lo check out any and all reports from informants, lf so, I certainly hope they employ better in­ formants than the one who tried to link* the players to the bookie. 
A few days ago I was in the same room with a person who claims to be a 
Communist. Hope an FBI informant wasn’t peaking around the corner. By now I might bt* considered a potential 
Russian spy in the eyes of the FBI. 

You or I pro b ab ly would not be bothered or damaged by such a silly incident as this, but if handled poorly it could ruin the future of an athlete. 
Luckily, this time it didn t. 

From Houston to Washington it’s only a matter of points 

San Antonio 
E x p re s s

1977 State Golden Gloves tour­ nam ent opened 
W ednesday night.

Beaumont.

Trussell of Dallas in a bantamweight bout. 
Other winners

Tyler in a light m iddleweight bout, while Rodriguez, a state semifinalist last year, deeisioned Je rry Smith of

Cougars advance with 83-82 victory 

HOUSTON (AP) - Houston’s Mike 
Shultz hit a free throw with 37 seconds to play and Indiana State's Larry Bird missed a shot at the buzzer to give the 
Cougars an 83-82 victory Wednesday night in a first round game of the 
National Invitation Tournament. 
The Cougars, who had led by as much as IO jioints in the second half, were outscored 1*2-2 over a three min­ ute span late in the game. 
Indiana State climaxed lls rally with one minute left on a shot by Bird that tied the game at 82-82. 
With 37 seconds remaining. Indiana 
State's Dan Rutledge fouled Shultz. wIhi made his first shot but missed the second. 
Bird grabbed the rebound and the 
Sycamores plaited for the last shot. 
Bird got the ball under the basket as time ran out but hts forced jump shot 

 bounded off the ru n as the I m al buzzer sounded. 
The victory advances the Cougars to the NIT quarterfinals Sunday against 
Illinois State, which defeated Creight­ on 65-58 Tuesday night. 
Bird, the nation’s No.3 scorer, led all scorers with 44 points while Houston's 
Otis Birdsong, the country’s No. 4 scorer, finished with 3o points. 
Houston, now 27-7, led by us much us 
13 points iii tile first halt when the 
Cougars used their iull-court press and pulled to a 4o-27 lead. 
Houston managed only a six point lead. 52-46 at halftime, when the Syca­ mores hit the last three baskets of the half.

Replays slow 
NFL games, study shows 

By DAVE BRADY 
W A S H IN G T O N ROST SERVICE 
WASHINGTON - Art McNal­ ly, supervisor of National Foot­ ball League officials, had a game at Dallas Nov. 15 filmed with instant-replay cameras. 

U nder cover of H ow ard C o se ll’s tongue. McNally’s agents slipped four cam eras into the stadium for a Mon­ day-night surveillance of a game with the Buffalo Bills. 
“ I d o n ’t want to tak e s id e s ,’’ 
McNally said. “ because it is possible when the club ow n ers have th e ir m eeting later this month, that they will discuss whether instant replays could In* used in the future to supple­ ment officiating. My role is merely to report the results of studies.” lie said nothing was made public so that the test could be judged without controversy. 
Camera positions 
T he c a m e ra s w ere positioned to cover the four corners of the field 
There were recorders in a broadcast booth picking up the feed from Hit cameras. 
"We did not have slow-motion capa­ bility receivers," McNally said, “ and the cam eras did not adequately blan­ ket the field. Quite ob\ tousle, we would need 12 and possibles 16 or is cameras 
“ We held stop watches on plays we might want to sec again, say on a sideline catch I remember there was interference with a fair catch when a player on the punting team got Int on tin* bead with tile hall. 
“ We were trying to look again at some of those plays while the other plays continued to go on. We found out that it took from 27 seconds up to two m inutes to search for such a play, while, as I said. other plays went on 
Time-consuming 
“ That gave us an idea of how long it would take with two cam eras (at cither end of the field). What it we had to look at the pictures taken by three cameras, or maybe six. seven or eight? 
“ We had four cam e ra s at the ex­ trem e corners, in line with the side­ lines. |M»inting at the corners and down the sidelines. 
“ You would also need two on the end line on the end zones po inting in toward each other . . . two on the goal lilies pointing in toward each other , .. one behind the goal posts, dead center, looking down field 
"There should Ik* a moving camera on e ith e r side of the field looking

Houston moved a little closer to 
W ashington 
W ednesday night. 
Now this was done without an earth tremor or any other geo­ logical phenom enons. There were no mirrors. There was no trick photography. 

You see, th is m ove c a m e in the 
NBA s Central Division race, the clo­ sest contest since Tom Dewey and 
Harry T rum an’s presidential battle in 
1948. 
The second-place Houston Rockets defeated the slumping Phoenix Suns, 
1o5-1oo. in Houston, while Milwaukee su rp rise d the W ashington B ullets, 
1o9-1o7, in the Beer City. 
Following Wednesday’s games, the 
Bullets wore 39-26 and the Rockets 
38-26, just six percentage joints be­ hind. The Spurs, idle W ednesday night, are now just two games behind 
Washington.

SAN ANTO NIO EXPRESS— Thursday March 1o 1977 
East Texas St., 
TSU triumph in NAI A play 

ASSOCIATED PRESS 
KANSAS 
CITY 
- 
Texas 
Southern and East Texas State both won W ednesday in the 
NAIA basketball tournament and will collide head-on in 
Thursday's quarterfinals. 

Guard Lawrence W illiam s hit a 
2o-footer with three seconds left to give 
Texas Southern un 82-8o victory over 
Wisconsin-Parkside early Wednesday. 
In the next-to-last game on the day's card. East Texas State nipped Empor­ ia, Kan., 92-89. 
Grand Valley, Mich., stopped Clar­ ion. Pa., 79-85. and Campbell, N. C., chalked up a 71-58 nod over Southwes­ tern, Okla. 
Alcorn wins 
Central, Wash., squeezed by New­ berry, S.C., 58-57. while Alcorn, Miss., edged Alabama-Huntsville, 78-75, in a couple of thrillers. 
Another game went into overtime but Illinois Wesleyan pulled away to an 
85-74 vcictory over Hawaii-Hilo. 
In the last game on Wednesday s eight-game slate. Henderson. Ark.. was playing Dowling, N. V. 
W illiam s and 
Alonzo 
Bradley pumped in 25 points apiece as TSU boosted its record to 28-5. 
Learthu Scott of Parkside also had 25 points. 
The Wisconsin club overcame a 
13-point deficit in the second half to tie 

 the score at 88-88 with 32 seconds to play. Southern then played for the final shot and the strategy worked out per­ fectly. 

Texas Southern's Jim Butler was ejected in the last half for slugging opponent Marvin Chones after an ap­ parent bumping incident in the corner. 
Phones later returned to action. 

Nate Granger and Larry McGhee scored a combined 55 points for East 
Texas State. 

Central Washington ended New­ berry’s 36-game unbeaten streak on a bizarre play with five seconds left. 

An inbounds pass hit the back of the backboard and the ball dropped straight to the floor, where Alfonso 
Roberts picked it up and put in the deciding basket.

Reed named to succeed 
Red Holzman 

ASSOCIATED PRESS 
NEW YORK - “ My heart lies in New York,” Willis Reed said firmly. “ It’s good to come back. I only hope I can be as successful as a coach as I was as a player.” 

RED H O L Z M A N , le ft, outgoing coach o f the N ew Y o rk 
Knicks, passes the ball to W illis Reed, who will succeed 
Holzm an at beginning of 1977-78 season ap w ire p h o to 

In the official Environmental Protection Agency 1977 Gas Mileage Guide, the 
Rose leaves camp 

The VW Rabbit has better fuel economy than: 
The VW Rabbit has more trunk space than: 
The VW Rabbit has more interior space than: 

TAMPA. Fla. (A P ) - 
The attorney fur Pete 
Ruse left the Cincinnati 
Reds' spring training camp Wednesday, saying the third baseman “ will nut sign." 
Rose is involved in the most bitter salary dis­ pute of his 17-year career and has threatened to play out his option. 
“ He feels he's one of the top few players in baseball and he ought to get one of the top few salaries. It's not princi­ ple anymore, it s pride,’’ said Reuven Katz, a Cin­ cinnati attorney. 
Katz spent two days this week meeting with 
Reds General Manager 
Dick Wagner. 
Rose is one of five un­ signed members of the world champions and is reportedly seeking a million-dollar contract. 
Wagner said the Reds automatically will renew the contracts of any un­ signed players Thursday afternoon. 

Reed, the burly center who cap­ tained the New York Knicks’ cham­ pionship teams in 1978 and 1973, 
Wednesday was named lo succeed Red 
Holzman as coach of the National Bas­ ketball Association team. 

Reed signed a three-year contract to begin with the 1977-78 season. 

“ The captain w ill become the coach,” said Mike Burke, president of the Knicks, “ and we are very happy to have him. He has meant a lot to the tradition of this team and we’re glad he’ll be rejoining us." 
29-36 record 
The Knicks, heading for their third straight losing season with a 29-38 re­ cord. announced Saturday that Holz­ man would move to the front office at the end of this season. 

"It was the end of an era when Red announced he was retiring," said the 
34-year-old Reed, whose playing career was cut short in 1974 by chronic knee problems, “ but I hope I'll be able to continue in that tradition. I was a player on the Knicks’ two champion­ ship teams, and my ultimate goal is to be part of another championship team as a coach " 

Reed, who averaged 18.7 points and 
12.9 rebounds per game us a player, recognizes that coaching the Knicks won t be easy. 
Philosophy 

“ Basically the game is defense,’’ 
Reed told a Madison Square Garden news conference, “ and that’s what I ’m going to spend a lot of time and effort on. S ou can’t just buy players and ex­ pect to win—you have to spend the time in the gym.” 

In the past couple of years the 
Knicks have spent much money on players like Bob McAdoo, Spencer 
Haywood and Jim McMillian, but the team still hasn’t reversed its down­ ward slide. 

“ The present personnel is great, bul it s tough to change habits in the mid­ dle of a season.” said Reed. “ We're going to start with that personnel and hopefully add to it over the summer. 
But basically the personnel is there—it's just a matter of spending the time.” 
Improve basics 

Reed feels the Knicks have to im­ prove their basics in order to win. particularly their defensive play. 

And the players have to learn to sa­ crifice parts of their individual games for the good of the team. 

“ We have to go hack to some of the basic things, and hopefully we’ll have a different kind of ballclub," said the 
6-foot-1o Reed, who is now somewhat heavier than his playing weight of 248 pounds. 

“ Defense is what wins games lur you. and this year’s team is not helping each other out enough on defense.”

Dill will be new WTS A.D. 

CANYON (A P ) — Richard Ditl. cur­ rently the sports information director- at Drake University, will become ath­ letic director at West Texas State, a member of the selection committee said Wednesday. 
Ditl will replace Gene Mayfield, who resigned last Jan. 8. according to John 
M. Shelton of Am arillo, the past chairman of the West Texas Board ol 
Regents. 
The 46-year-old Ditl has been at 
Drake in Des Moines. Iowa, since 1978.

Home-court advantage is dropping off 

S A N A N T O N IO EXPRESS— Thursday March I O 19/7 

ASSOCIATED PRESS 
NEW YORK — Notes from around the National Basketball 
Association: 
R e m e m b e r the in c r e a s e d hom e- court advantage which was the subject of so much talk earlier this season? 
Well, i f s coming down. 
The latest figures show home teams winning 489 gam es and losing 219, a 
.H9o percentage. 
E arlier this Season, home team s had been winning as many as 74 per cent of the gam es, and players, coaches and execu tiv es alik e had 
.............. ■■■. been groping for rea- 
'’V I I A sons to explain the in- crease over last year’s level of 65.9 per cent. 
- ............ 
Now, with the downward trend, they can stop groping. 
“ The stronger teams are com ing on strong,” observed John Nucatola, the 
N BA’s Supervisor of Officials. “ Also, team s are now m aking their second swing around the league. There are no more new courts or new arenas to get used to. The travel and the crowds always give the home team an edge, but Til bet dollars to donuts that by the end of the year the figures will be right down where they were last y e ar.” 
Nucatola also disputed the allegation the d o m in a n ce of hom e te a m s had been influenced by referees who were fa v o rin g the hom e te a m s w ith a significant amount of close calls. 
“ Through the middle of F eb ru a ry , only 1.3 more fouls were called against tin1 visiting team per gam e, and only 
2.3 more shooting fouls,” he said 
“ I wouldn't call that an overw helm ing difference.” 
★ ★ ★ 
“ You ca n ’t live and die with every g am e,” says Red Holzman, who will be retiring at the end of the year after It) sea so n s as co ach of the New Y ork 
Knicks. “ There are 82 gam es in a sea­ son, and that's an awful lot of living and dying.” 
★ * . ★ 
More from Holzman: 
“ If coaching was just a m atter of drawing X s and Os, I’d be great. I can make the X s score every time. Lock me in a room with a blackboard and chalk and 1 11 win every g a m e .” 
•to it It 
Injuries are becoming a telling fac­ tor as the National B a sk etb a ll A sso­ ciation season heads towards its final month. 
Most seriously crippled has been the 

Phoenix Suns, who have hardly ever had their front line of Alvan Adams. 
G a rfie ld H eard and C u rtis P e r r y together. 
Both forwards. Heard and P erry, are currently sidelined as the Suns have fallen out of the playoff picture after reaching the finals last year. 
In the E astern Conference, Boston leads the New Y o rk K n ick s by four gam es in their fight for the last playoff berth. Both have had their injuries— 
Spencer Haywood’s left leg problems forcing him out of 23 g am es for the 
Knicks, Charlie S co tt’s broken hand sidelining him since midseason for the 
Celtics. 
P o rtla n d and D e tro it, two te a m s which arc assured of playoff berths, will not go far in post-season play un­ less their centers are fully recovered. 
Bill Walton has been in and out of the 
Portland lineup lately, while Bob Lan­ ier suffered a fractured bone in his right hand last week and will be lost lo the Pistons for at least a month. it lr lr 
Nets Coach Kevin Loughery picked up his 34th technical foul on Friday, referee D arrel G arretso n dishing it out. A fte r w a r d s , G a r r e ts o n sp ok e about the ru n n in g feud b etw ee n 
Loughery and gam e officials. 
"When Kevin is coaching, there are tim es when you will see him six or eight feet from the bench,” said G ar­ retson. “ He hollers all their defensive plays and most of their offensive plays, lie 's so wound up in his coach ing I honestly think he forgets where he is.” lr it lr 
On the o th er hand, D en v er Coach 
L a rry B row n fe e ls so m e lo n g -tim e 
NBA officials go out of their way to make things rough on the team s which joined the league this year from the 
American Basketball Association. 
“ W e’ve been second -class citizens for so long,” Brown said, “ that I ’m getting tired of it. Some of the older 
NBA officials run by the bench and point fin g e r s at m e and shou t one-liners—and I don’t appreciate it.” it lr lr 
San Antonio Coach Dong Moe isn t exactly an impartial observer, but his opinion of Spurs guard George Gervin is worth noting. 
“ G ervin is the best guard in the league,” says Moe. “ He’s constantly being double-teamed, but he never has a bad gam e for us. He never even takes a bad shot." 
Gervin has scored in double figures in each of his last 64 gam es.

Exhibit Hall at the Convention Center. The show will run through 
Sunday. Hours Thursday and Friday are 5 to IO p.m. Hours Saturday will be I to IO p.m. and Sunday, I to 7 p.m.

Grote signs 

 with Mets 

ST. P E T E R S B U R G . 
Fla. (A P) — V eteran c a tc h e r 
J e r r y 
G rote signed a one-year con­ f a c t for a rep o rted 
$125,ooo with the New 
York Mets Wednesday. 

Grote, of San Antonio, had considered r e tir e ­ ment following the 1976 season but changed his mind and will rem ain with the club as a player for one m ore season. 
After that, he will serve as a sp rin g tra in in g coach and minor league instructor for two years. 

 each had eight points in that period. 
Houston, winners of four straight, led 98-83 with 2:18 rem aining in the g am e, but Phoenix went on a 17-7 streak, moving to 1o3-1oo with seven seconds left. 
Moses Malone, w ho had 2o rebounds, sank two free throws to end the night's scoring. Alvan Adams’ 26 points paced the Suns. Rick Sobers had 24 for 
Phoenix, which lost its fifth straight on the road. 
Slick Watts, the man with the gold headband ringing his shaved skull, scored 26 points to pace the Sonic vic­ tory. Fred Brown added 14. 
Seattle, in the midst of a long road trip, took the lead at 1o-8 after four minutes of the first quarter, and never trailed. 
Sidney Wicks, playing his 65th game with the Celtics, broke the 1,ooo-point mark for the sixth consecutive season with a basket at the start of the third period. 
Erving and Thompson both notched season-high point totals rn the double ov ertim e m a tc h at P h ila d e lp h ia ’s

SAN MARCOS — Southwest Texas State will begin interviewing applicants for its vacant head basketball position next week. 
Athletic Director Bill Miller said.

Express sports writer honored 

John Hines, left, of the Express sports staff, was honored by 
Southside High School W ednesday for “ Outstanding coverage of athletic events." Presenting the plaque is M aige M. Rodriguez, 
Southside principal. Hines covers high school athletics for the Express. 
U SF’s Galliard is coach of the year 

SAN FRANCISCO (AP) - Bob Gall­ iard says his public image of a free- and-easy basketball coach at the Uni­ versity of San Francisco is inaccurate. 
“ I’m much more conservative than the average coach," insists Gaillard, named Wednesday as The Associated 
Prese College Coach of the Year. “ I just try to put everything in perspec­ tive. 
“ That free and easy image is so­ mething the media prefers." said 
Gaillard. who received 12o votes from sports writers and broadcasters ar­ ound the country. Runner-up Eddie 
Sutton of Arkansas got 52. 
“ It .just makes better copy to throw a free-spirit attitude on myself and the players." added Gaillard. who has decried what he calls the type of coach who acts like a ‘‘Marine sergeant." 
Gaillard, 36, in his fifth full year as the Dons’ head coach, has guided the 
Jesuit school's team to a 29-1 mark heading into 
Saturday’s 
NCAA 

 playoffs. 
Hopes for a perfect season were derailed by last weekend’s loss at 
Notre Dame, and San Francisco opens the NCAA playoffs Saturday against strong Nevada-Las Vegas. 
Gaillard says a loss won’t kill him. 
“ There are 32 teams in the playoffs and I don’t think 31 teams will have failed if they don’t win," he said. 
"Ninety per cent of the coaches in their entire careers are not able to go to jxist-season play." 
Coaching, even with a nationally ranked power, was not Gaillard’s goal when he was a business major in college. 
He had hoped for a pro playing career after graduation from San 
Francisco, where he held the single­ game scoring record of 41 points until it was broken by Bill Cartwright this year. 
But “ all of a sudden a knee injury forced me into reality.”

Oilers waive 
Mc Yea 

 y r t C I A l T O t h e e x p r e s s 

HUNTSVILLE - Run­ ning back Warren Mc Yea was among four players waived by the Houston 
Oilers Wednesday. 
The Oilers also accept* cd the resignation of ve­ teran tight end W illie 
Frazier. 
McVeu. trying to comeback after knee surgery sidelined him during the exhibition season last year, was a standout with San Anton­ io Brackenridge, the 
University of Houston and the Kansas City 
Chiefs. 
Wide receiver Jim 
Bernie and defensive end 
Bubba Smith, both N FL veterans, and linebacker 
( lins Zaragoza were also waived. 
Frazier, a 13-year ve­ teran, played with the 
San Antonio Wings, lbs career included seusmis with Sun Diego. Kansas 
( ny. Houston of the NFL. and Houston-Shrevepurt of the defunct \\ FL. 
Houston opens it pre­ season play against the 
Oakland Raiders on Aug. 
8. and close out of Sept. 
Iii against the New Or­ leans Saints in the Su- 
IH-rdome. 

KCOR, the only 

Spanish language station with a full time 

Community Service Director 

135o on the Dial 

Miller is chairman of a nine-person committee named to screen appli­ cants for the position. 
Miller said the selec­ tion process for finding a successor for Vernon 
McDonald has been 
"slow because we've gi­ ven time for all the ap­ plications to be screened and there has been a lot of interest in the job. 
"W e’ve contacted a lot of people to get their re- eomendations," he said, but right now we have no name for you." 
Health 
McDonald announced his retirement in F e ­ bruary after 16 seasons as head basketball coach because of his health. He did not coach the team in its final five games after complaining of chest pains. 
"We hope to start nar­ rowing it down and begin interviewing people for tilt* positon about March 
21 (next Monday) when school resumes after the spring break." M iller said. 
The committee will submit its recommenda­ tions to Dr. Allan Wat­ son. vice president for university affairs, for further consideration and final selection. 
Members 
Also on the committee art* Dr. Bobby Patton, a member of the health and physical education department and presi­ dent of the Bobcat Club; 
Dr. 
Leland 
WH son. chairman of SW T’s ath­ letic committee; athletic committee member Ger­ ald Champagne of the agriculture department and McDonald. 
Also, Karen Freden* burg, coordinator of wo­ men's athletics; Paul 
Phillips, a senior football player from Fredericks­ burg; John Fasclcr, a 
San Marcos administra­ tor; and Dr. Lewis O il­ er e a s e, a San Marcos dentist and Bobcat Club officer. 
Miller said Assistant 
Coach Mike Garner is not being considered for the head coaching positon. 
Garner is in his first year as an assistant at SWT. 
Miller said McDonald will handle recruiting chores until a new coach is hired. 
McDonald took over the Bobcat helm in 1961 and coached more games 
(418) than any head coach in SW T history. 
His teams won 225 and lost 193 
Rams get rights to 
Young 

LOS AN G ELES (A P) 
— The Los Angeles Rams have traded the rights to quarterback lion 
Jaworski to the Philadel­ phia Eagles for the rights to tight end Charles 
Young, the Rams an­ nounced Wednesday. 
The rights, under the ii new National Football 
,| League collective bargaining, means the team involved has first refusal aud compensa­ tion rights to free agents. 
Both Jaw orski and 
Young had played out their options and are free agents. 
Young, the former 
University of Southern 
California All-American, caught 197 passes for 
2,583 yards during his four >ears with the Ea­ gles. and was the Na­ tional Football Confer­ ence rookie til* the year in 
1973. 
Tile tt-foot-4, 
238-pounder from Fres­ no. Calif., also led the conference with 
83 catches in 1974, when he was chosen to play iii the 
Pro Bowl. 
Jaworski, a iour*yeur 
NFL veteran out of 
Youngstown State, was used sparingly for the 
Ranis this season after 
Ile bruke Ills shoulder ill the first game of the sea­ son. 
The 
(J* foot *2, 
185-pounder started two games for the Ruins and appeared in five, com­ pleting 26 of 52 pusses for 
273 yards, will) one touchdown

LUBBOCK 
(AP) 
- 
All-American Otis Bird­ song of Houston was the top vote-getter on the 
National Association of 
Basketball 
Coaches 
All-District 6 team an­ nounced Wednesday. 
Birdsong tallied 
8o points in the voting. 
Joining 
Birdsong on the first team were Mar­ vin Delph. Sidney Mon- erief and Ron Brewer of 
Arkansas and Mike Rus­ sell of Texas Tech. 
Delph, 
Brewer and 
Russell are juniors and 
Moncrief is a sophomore. 
Named to the second team were Steve Jones, 
Texas 
A&M; 
Grant 
Dukes. 
Texas 
Tech; 
Larry 
Spicer. 
Baylor; 
Dan Henderson, Arkan­ sas 
State; and 
Mike 
McConathy, 
Louisiana 
Tech. 
Average 

Birdsong finished the regular season ranked fourth In the nation in scoring with a 3o.4 aver­ age and led the Cougars to a 26-7 record and a spot in the National Invi­ tational Tournament. 
Russell led the 
Southwest Conference in rebounding averaging 9.9 rebounds a game and was second in the con­ ference in scoring with a 
22.2 average. He helped lead Tech to Its second straight 2o-win season. 
The Arkansas trio of 
Brewer. Delph and Mon­ crief were the catalysts for the Razorbucks, lead­ ing Arkansas to a 26-1 record and the Southwest 
Conference 
Champion­ ship.

BIG OUTS ARE COMING 
DOWN TO VOWS 
SIZE...NoT UP TO 
VOWS STANDARDS. 

Have you noticed how some of the fat cars have reduced to almost Volvo-esque proportions? It^ true. One major manufacturer has cut the size of his oversize models by an average of 7oo pounds. 
But try as they might to copy our lines, they haven't managed to duplicate our features. 
Standard equipment like four-wheel power-assisted disc brakes. 
And a dual braking system in which each circuit operates on three— not two—wheels. Plus ort hoped ically-designed bucket seats. And a 
12-outlet heating/ventilation system.They’re on every Volvo we sell. 
(Or lease.;.an alternate way to finance your Volvo.) But conspicuously absent from Detroit'sslimmed-down models. 
Then there are the little things Volvo owners have come to expect which other car buyers expect to pay extra for. Like stereo door speakers. Steel-belted whitewall radials. And tinted glass all around. 
All of which suggests it doesn't make much sense to buy a 
* sensible-size car unless theres a Voivo inside it. 
See us for both.

WHITE LETTERS 
6 o & 7o 

 overwhelm ing dom in­ ance of the pro golf tour by younger, emerging stars comes as no sur­ prise to Jack Nicolaus. 
“ The public may be a little surprised about the way the young players have been perform ing this year, but we know them," Nicklaus said as a spokesman for the game's more established stars. 
“ W e’re not surprised. 
We are paired with them in tournaments, see them on the practice tee. 
“ We know what they can do. We know they can play." 
And the play of the youngsters, many of them relative unknowns until the sudden turnar­ ound of the game this season, has been the overriding trend in golf. 
Average age 
Of the older players, only Nicklaus has been able to win. With the ex­ ception of his victory two weeks ago at Inverrary, the average age of the winners this year is 25.7. 
And the leader of that youth movement, Bruce 
Lietzke. is back in action this week in the $2oo.oo11 
Doral Open that gets under way Thursday on the 7,o65-yard, par-72 
Blue Monster course at the Doral Country Club. 
The powerful Lietzke won two 1977 titles, along with finishes of second, fourth and 12th in five starts. Ile won a leading 
$123,35o before missing the last three events be­ cause of the death of his father. 

Ile has an unbroken string if 2o consecutive rounds of par or better. 

“ It ’s gone on longer than I thought it would." 
Lietzke said. “ I have no idea how long I might be able to keep it going. I really don’t know what s happening. I know it's got to end sometime." 

It hasn't ended yet. however, and Lietzke, along with N icklaus. ranked as the top two choices in the 72-hole chase for a $4o,o(H) first prize.

EVERY DAY IS DISCOUNT DAY AT 
THE TIRE STORE 

VISIT US BEFORE YOU BUY TIRES

THE TIRE STORE 

19o6 S. FLORES 
CORNER LONE STAR 
AND FLORES 

The U.S. Corps of Engineers project to create a port for super tankers at Port Aransas is on the move again since the com­ pletion of an engineering feasi­ bility study. 
The three-phase project would change the face of the area around 
Port Aransas, and according to con­ servationists who had rather see an offshore facility, the changes wouldn't be beneficial. 
The first phase of the project would include deeping the existing entrance channel in the Gulf from the present 45 feet to a depth of SO feet. 
Tankers up to about 8o.ooo dead weight tons now enter the channel. The new depth would permit entrance of tankers up to 47o.ooo dead weight tons. 

Phase one also calls for moving the 

 north jetty about a thousand feet to the north to widen the jettied channel and relocating the channel to Aransas Pass across 
Harbor 
Island near the 

 lighthouse. 

A docking basin would be dredged in 
Harbor Island to offload oil. It would handle three super tankers at a time, and a turning basin with a diameter of 
2.3oo feet would be dredged opposite the docking basin in Lydia Ann Chan­ nel. 
Dredging for the project, which would require approximately three years, would yield about 98.2 million cubic yards of spoil ( sand and mud), two-thirds of which would be disposed of in the Gulf with the remainder de­ posited in Red fish Bay, on Mustang 
Island and on the southern end of St. 
Joseph Island. 
Opponents of the* super port main­ tain the channel dredging and deposit­ ing of spoil would destroy valuable estuary areas used by marine life iii the area. 
The Corps has announced that com­ ments on the project should be sub­ mitted in writing by March 24. Com­ ments should be addressed to the Dis­ trict En g in eer, P. O. Box 1229, Gal­ veston, 77553. 
According to tin* Corps, all factors relevant to the proposal, including conservation, economics, aesthetics, general environmental concerns, his­ toric values, fish and wildlife values. 

 flood damage prevention, land use classification, navigation, recreation. water supply, water quality and the needs and welfare of the people in general, will be considered. 

State and federal agencies — Texas 

Parks and Wildlife and U.S. Fish and 
Wildlife — are expected to comment on the project. The stale agency has re­ quested more time to study the proposal before commenting. 

“ We need more information before we can assess the impact of the pro­ ject,’’ B. I). King of the department s biological environmental staff said this week. He pointed out there is some 
“ extremely productive” fish and wa­ terfowl habitat in the area which would be affected by the super port. 
King added that the Corps has ten­ tatively scheduled a meeting next wet'k with concerned agencies to discuss the project in more de* 'ii. 
Phases two iree concern the widening of i channels. Under phase two. ti lannel from Port 
Aransas to Ingleside would be dee­ pened to HI) feet. Under phase three, the La Quinta channel would be dredged to the same depth. 

Redfish bill gets boost 
The Texas Red Drum Conservation 
Act was approved by the natural re­ sources committee in the senate by a vote of 9 to I Wednesday, but the mea­ sure, S.B. 624. has been altered consi­ derably. 
The section to require larger mesh sizes in nets was deleted entirely, and the daily bag limit, which would be­ come effective Sept. I, would be re­ quired only for 1977. 

The bill would require that the Parks 

 and Wildlife Department establish a quota system for the commercial har­ vest of redfish for 1978. 

 lf the bill, which still has a long way to go in the Legislature, becomes law, bag limits from Sept. I through De­ cember of this year would be IO fish per day for sport fishermen and 2oo pounds per day per boat for commer­ cials. 
The only no vote on the bill in the senate committee was registered by 
Walter IL Mengden Jr. of Austin.

Ducks slip past OKU 

TULSA, Okla. (A F ) — Forward 
Greg Ballard scored 43 points, helping 
Oregon offset a 65-point effort bv 
Anthony Roberts and gain a 9o-89 win over Oral Roberts in a first-round 
National Invitation Tournment basket­ ball game Wednesday night. 
Roberts, an OHL senior forward hit 
25 field goals and 15 free throws for an all-time single-game NIT record. 
The record had been the 53 points that George Mikan of DePaul scored in a 1945 NIT game against Rhode Island. 
Oregon moved from a 16-8 deficit at 
12:46 in the first half to a 4o-4o tie at halftime and then led thrughout the second half.

G eorgetow n 

BLACKSBURG. Va. (A P) — Mar- shall Ashford’s layup with 14:o4 left sent Virginia Tech in front for good and the Gobblers beat Georgetown’s 
Hoyas 83-79 Wednesday night in a 
National Invitation Basketball Tour­ nament opening-round game. 
Ashford crammed 16 of his 24 points into the second half as the Gobblers, who won the NTT in 1973. rallied from a 
4o-37 deficit at intermission to earn a 
Madison Square Garden shot next 
Monday at the winner of Thursday night’s Alabama-Memphis State game. 
After Ashford's layup, the Gobblers built their lead to 55-5o on a drive by 
Hon Bell and two free throws by Phil 
Thieneman.

Old D om inion 
NORFOLK. Va. (AP) - Keith and 
Larry Herron rallied Villenova Wild­ cats from an early 12-point deficit to a 
71-68 overtime victory Wednesday night over Old Dominion in an opening round National Invitation Tournament basketball game. 
The Wildcats, down 14-4 after Old 
Dominion hit seven of its first eight shots from the floor, never caught up until 9:o8 remained in the game.

Introducing Samovar 
868 proof vodka. 
What makes it different is what makes itbetten 

Just like the world’s finest Scotch and Canadian whiskies. Samovar comes to you at 86.8 proof. The International Proof. 
86.8, however, is more than just the International Proof. When it comes to vodka, it’s the perfect proof. 
Perfect for drinking straight and ice cold—the ultimate test of a vodka. Just as perfect for adding a touch of perfection to your favorite mixed drinks. 
But proof isn’t the only thing that makes Samovar different. How we get it to that very special proof is different, too. 
No other vodka is quite like Samovar because no other vodka is distilled like Samovar. Through a costly and painstakingly precise method. 
Resulting in a vodka that s Ultra Dry. And exceptionally smooth. Yet, with a lively quality that’s unique and consistently rewarding. 
If you want a better vodka, look for proof 
Not promises. 
Look for International 
Proof Samovar.

Vodka 
Samovar iii enjoyed in over 8o countries on every 
Continent, including France, 
England, German v, Greece. and Australia

Hamm enters tourney 

Trinity alum Mary 
Hamm is among the players scheduled to compete in the Lionel- 
McFarlin Cup women's tennis tournament begin­ ning March 21 at McFar­ lin Tennis Center. 
Hamm, a finalist in singles at the USTzX na­ tional championships last summer, will Ik * joined by Marcie Louie, Mona 
Guerrant. 
Belinda 
Thompson Renee R i­ chards and 
Karen 
Krantzcke. 
Also slated for the tourney are Isabel Fer­ nandez, Florenta Mihai, 
Kate 
Latham, 
.lane 
Stratton and Sue Stap, sister of current Trinity player Sandy. 
The four-week tourna­ ment. which has its first stop in S.A., will award 
$3,IHM) to the singles win­ ner and $2,ooo to the runnerup. The victorious doubles team gets $1,ooo. 
Qualifying for the tourney will begin March 
16. 
Stockton named top seed 

H ARTFO RD , 
Conn. 
(A P) — Dick Stockton, who upset Jimmy Con­ nors at the L'.S. Pro In­ door tennis tournament last January, has been chosen top seed for the 
United States in its World 
Cup matches this week against Australia. 
Dannis Ralston, cap­ tain of the I .S. team in the four-day event begin­ ning Thursday night, said he chose Stockton because of his upset vic­ tory over Connors in 
Philadelphia. Stockton and Tony Roche, Austra­ lia’s lop seed, will open the best-of-seven World 
Cup battle Thursday with a singles match. 
Australia has a 5-2 edge in the tournament which began in 197o in 
Boston and moved to 
Hartford in 1972 
Other American team members are 
Brian 
Gottfried. Marty Rlessen and Roscoe Tanner. Also playing for the Austra­ lians will be John Alex­ ander, Ross Case, Mark 
Edmondson and 
Roy 
Emerson 
The Stockton-Roehe match will In* preceded b> a mixed doubles exhi­ bition pitting Fred Stolle and liana Kloss against 
Ralston and Linky Ro­ sholt.

SA N A N T O N IO EXPRESS— Thursday March 1o I 977 
Scallion comes o f age in the pros 

BILL SCANLON 

By KEVIN O K EE FFE 
OF THE EXPRESS STAFF 
He still has that boyish look, com ­ plete with the Ipana smile and dark, curly locks. 
But Bill Scanlon is no longer the boy tennis hero at Trinity University. He is now one of the young lions on the pro circuit, choosing to go that route last summer. 
He was on top of the collegiate tennis world in June, downing UCLA’s Peter 
Fleming for the NCAA singles cham ­ pionship And even as lit* denied any impending move into the pros, seeds of doubt were being planted in his mind. 
The thought of re tu rn in g for his junior year in college and trying to successfully defend his NCAA title — something which had not been done since Dennis Ralston’s back-to-back triumphs in 19H3-H4 — began to get to him. 

“ I just felt the timing was right to go pro,” Scanlon said of his decision, which he revealed exclusively in the 
Express on June 9th. “ I wanted to use the title to get into a few tournaments. 
“ Then, once in the tournam ent, I knew I would do okay. Going into the pros is just like moving into another age group.” 

Scanlon, a 2o-year-old Dallas resi­ dent. is in Austin, p reparing for a 
Thursday 2 p.m. WFT match against 
Hit* Nastase at Lakeway. 
Sea/., that was his Trinity nickname, has beaten the volatile Nastase twice. 
Does he have Nasty’s number!* 
“ I would not call two wins having his number,” Scanlon smiled, still relish­ ing his two trium phs. -I have done okay against him. But he is still Nas- tase.” 
Scanlon, who was just the second TU 

 player to win the NCAA singles title — 
Dick Stockton won in 1972 — has been doing more than just okay since be­ coming a professional. 
Following fair performances in three 
Southern to u rn a m e n ts 
Scanlon knocked off biggies Harold Solomon and Eri;k Van Dillon at Cincinnati in 
July. 
“ I really worked my tail off last sum m er.” Scallion said. “ I practiced a lot. you know. Then, beating Solomon and Van Dillon, gave me confidence. I knew I could play with them. 
“ The biggest thing in the pros is there are no easy matches. You can never let up. All these guys can play.” 
After his victories in C incinnati, 
Scanlon took some time off, getting completely away from tennis for a few weeks. “ I was tired,” he stated simp­ ly. 
That relaxation has been a good ton­ 

 ic. He reached the finals in Birmingh­ am (he lost to Jim m y Connors), the round of IB at the U.S. Indoors in 
Phialdelphia, the semifinals in Palm 
Springs and the semifinals in Monter­ rey. 
“ It was a good feeling to go u long way two weeks in a row,” Scanlon said of Palm Springs and Monterrey 

Scanlon, who has no in te re s t In playing team te n n is, says the *., players on the tour get along well. “ I don’t really have any close friends,” he admitted. “ Unless you are in the same city together, it is hard to get buddy* buddy with a guy. 
“ I have enjoyed the travel. It was great to go to Asia, for instance. I like meeting different people. I have gotten around to see each place, rather than sit in a hotel.” 
Scanlon, who competes on the WCT 
Replays slow games, study shows 

Continued from Page IF 

 across the line of scrimmage. There should be a moving cam era pointing up and down each sideline, because the stationary cameras at the four extreme corners would not be sufficient. 

“The person iii the monitoring booth would have to be a miracle man. You would have to slop the game and per­ haps let the coaches ask to see a cer­ tain number of plays; let the officials 

 see them , let the m an in the booth judge the replays. ' 
“ You would have to stop the game because there might be a chance of changing the original official’s d e­ cision." 
Was there anything encouraging in the experiment? 
“ Well, there may be tim es when none of tin* six officials could set* a play satisfactorily. Then they could see the replays. 

“ What the experiment did was verify questions we had before like, what about the tremendous amount of time it would take? 
“ What would happen if defensive pass interference were called? Maybe the coach of tin* offending team might 
■ask to see the blocking at every posi­ tion on the team with the ball, in hopes of seeing an infraction to offset the interference call 
“ The obvious draw backs are the 

 tremendous amount of equipment re­ quired and the break in the continuity of the game. How would the fans feel about waiting around for a considera­ bly longer game? 
“ People say that only a few plays would be involved, but how much is a few? 
“ Instant replays have been proposed by coaches, the television and by fans. 
The league has taken the position it always will look at suggestions.

 and staying back myself most of the time to guard against the fastbreak ’’

Lambert occupied at this time a year ago, although Leonard started a great deal last year, too . . .

“ Maybe electronic devices of the fu­ ture will make it plausible. We did not have equipment to freeze one frame at a time and run it back, like coaches can with their film projectors. But the film has to be processed. 
“ Television recorders do have the capability but it s more time-consum­ ing than the regular TV camera, and the picture is not clear enough. TV does have that fast capability, but the cost is astronomical. 

“ Most of the tim e, TV has six to eight c a m e ra s at a n o rm a l g a m e , maybe IS or more for a playoff or the 
Super Bowl. 
“ lf there is a use for instant replay to help officiating in the futu re, who would be responsible to make the final decision — the official on the field or the person in the booth?” 
McNally takes solace from 1975 sta­ tistics that showed there were 27.ooo plays run off and according to the league, only six important plays called wrong.

“The courts at Trinity were so fast that I used to serve and volley a lot,” he explained. “ I still serve and volley but it is improved from three weeks ago.”

Janu ary . He will get $5,ooo for his match at Lakeway.

UA must stop 
Wake Forest’s running game 

ASSOCIATED PRESS 
FAYETTEVILLE, Ark. - The Arkansas basketball team can relate to Wake Forest s run and gun tactics. Relating to the Dea­ cons' personnel may be more difficult. 
. im u it 
Midwest 
Regional 

The Razorbacks meet 
Wake Forest S aturday night in the first round of the NCAA Midwest Re­ gional at Norman, Okla. 
“Their philosophy is a lot like Southern Metho­ dist U niversity's,” said 
UA coach Eddie Sutton, when asked about the 
Deacons. “ But. of course, they’re much better than 
SMU. They depend on th eir runnin g g am e to score a lot of points. 
“ We h a v e n ’t played anybody as tough as 
Wake F o r e s t.” Sutton said “ We’ll have to play a perfect gam e to beat them They beat North 
Carolina twice. That s an indication of what type team they have.” 

26-1 m a rk 
A rkansas is 2B-1 and rank»*d No. 8 in the cou ntry . Wake F o rest was riding high at 2o-3 a few weeks ago. but lost its last four games and is no longer ranked. 
Wake F o re st coach

“ The disappointm ent we had felt disappeared quickly and was replaced by a really gmtd feeling.” he said “ This is a new season.”

“ A nytim e a running team shoots bettor than 
5o per cent from the field, th e y ’re a good shooting te a m ,” Sutton said He meant that of­ ten, a running team will take low p e rc e n tag e shots. 
Ile s u n s the fact that 
Wake Forest is shooting 
74.5 per cent from the free throw line is another indication of the D ea­ cons shooting ability, 
Key

Tindall has 3 

Tindall and Son Motor Homos, -WOO San Pedro, carries three of the finest motor homes available in the recreational field, according to W. F. “ Wes" 
Fdens, manager. 
The homes include the Itasca, constructed by 
Winnebago; the Executive and the Explorer. 
“ All three are beautiful units and they come in various sizes and equipped in various ways, accord­ ing to what the customer might want in extras, but 

CLASSIFIED DI SPI A V 
CLASSIFIED DISPLAY 

 of finest R V ’s 

 original furnishings alone are something to behold,” 
Edens said. 
As an example, Edens points out some of the units come with microwave ovens, color television, stove, shower and self-contained holding tanks. 
“ In short, you have a complete, self-contained unit and can travel anywhen' in the country as if you were in your own apartment at home," the manager added.

B u rst eye vessels com m on 

Dear Dr. Thosteson: Please comment on blood vessels that rupture in the eyes. This has happened in both eyes. They are not painful and do not seem to affect my vision, although sometimes I get a slight headache and a little dizziness. I have regular checkups by an internist and an eye doctor, both of whom say I ani in excellent health. 
I am 55. Although I’m told not to worry, my eyes are very precious to me and I feel this is an abnor­ mal condition. Isn’t there something I can do to prevent these* ruptures? — Mrs. J.L D. 
This is a fairly com­ mon condition caused by fragile capillaries (tiny blood vessels) under the conjunctive of the eye. the delicate membranes lining the eyeball. 
A lack of vitam in C can be a factor. That is obtained from citrus fruits. Substances called 
“ bioflavinoids” are also used to treat this. It is obtained by grinding a whole orange, skin and all, in a blender. An in­ jury to the eye. even a severe sneezing or coughing episode, can provoke this. 
('old compresses to the eye at the first ap­ pearance of the hemorrhage will reduce the spread of the redness. 
Blood pressure 
Your comment about slight headache and dizzi­ ness raises a question of blood pressure, so that should be checked. 
Mild conjunctival hemorrhage should not affect your vision. 
Dear DK. Thosteson: ('an tonsil problems be a cause of headaches? — Mrs. T. lf there is chronic infection, yes, especially in adults. Any infection can be accompanied bv hea­ dache, and an unexplained headache can be a symptom of an infection. 
Anemia, as from excessive menstrual flow, can also cause headache, just one of a wide variety of possible causes. See my booklet on headache. For a copy, send 25 cents and a stamped, self-addressed envelope to me care of this newspaper. 
Dear Dr. Thosteson: We hear a lot about the ef­ fects of drugs and smoking, etc., by a pregnant woman on her baby. What about drinking? — Mrs. 
F (). 
Most substances taken bv the pregnant woman have some effect, good or bad, on the developing fetus. The fetus is nourished exclusively bv what the woman eats or drinks. Alcohol is no exception.

Squawk box 

I would like to write to 
Julie of "Welcome Back, 
Kotter." Can you tell me something about her? 
—Karen 

Ju lie is played by 
Marcia Strassman. Shi* was born in New York 
City and began singing and acting very early in her life. She replaced 
Liza Minnelli in the off- 
Broadway musical “ Best 
Foot Fo rw ard ." which started her professional career in good style. She has been in seven epi­ sodes of “ M*A*S*TI” and on "Ironside,” “ Marcus 
Welby, M .D.,” “ City of 
Angels” and “ Police 

Story” prior to her regular role as Mrs. Kot­ ter. She is single and stands 5 feet IO. W rite her at Komack Produc­ tions, NBG, Burbank.

Is the dog who played 
Benji one of the offspring of the little dog who played Toto in “ The 
Wizard of Oz"? —Frank 

There is no way of knowing since Benji was rescued from the dog pound. 
It ’s unlikely, however. Dogs who are actors seldom sire un­ wanted puppies.

Van is ri n ’ in 
S 

It is so in that it now has a name: Van-mania. lf you happen to have m issal out on the latest 
West Coast fad, there’s good news in San Anton­ io. 
J e rry .Mu rn a of the 
Hemphill 
- 
McCombs 
Good Times Center has issued an invitation for 
South Texans to visit the center right across from 
Hemphill 
- McCombs 
Ford, 1o1o San Pedro. 
Je rry can not only show the latest in Ford v an s, but also in 
C hevrolet and Dodge styles, all decked out in high fashion by the Good 
Times Van people. Hern- phill-McCombs is the ex­ clusive d istrib u to r for 
Good Time Vans within a 
5o-mile radius. 
So you won’t sound like you just cam e to town on a load of cabbage, here’s a little "van talk’’ to keep you from sounding like a hick. 
Don’t talk about the fat radial tires. Make a cool rem ark like, “ Those are sure wide weenies.*’ 
And, if you want, talk price, trade and delivery time. 
Good Tim e Vans are built by Ford. Dodge and 
Chevrolet, but the custo­ mized finishing is done right here in Texas, so if you want something not in stock, delivery tim e is normally less than two weeks. lf you barefoot out with 

 want to buy a van and start your own con­ version or you want to install a reg u la r Good 
Tim es kit a little at a tim e, Jerry will be glad to show you how easy it Is to do.

Super sales seen 

Veteran automan Bill 
Ponies, general manager of North Central Ford. 
OHIHI San Pedro, sees 1977 as a “super sales year.” 
And 
North 
C entral owner and president Don 
P lin kman has reason to he optimistic. 
With one of the finest lines of Fords ever to hit show room s across the country, North Central 
Ford has been enjoying m ajor traffic and in ­ creased purchases by happy customers. d o in g from the out­ standing all-new 1977 
.Thunderbird to the full- size. highly desired LT D to tin great intermediate 
Granada, North Central is disputing what Ponies feels are some of the fin­ est products ever in the long and prestigious his­ tory of Ford Motor Co. 
“ B usiness looks real good,” says the sm iling 
Poulos as he notes the other eye-catching cars such as Hie Torino, M us­ tang and Pinto also are 
‘'m oving right along” in sales. 
Ponies points out that in addition to a complete and varied line ut spank­ ing new Ford products, 
North Central Ford also features one of the most extensive lines of first class used cars. 
“ We only carry late models and extra clean used cars that have been thoroughly tested aud checked by our expert m echanics and test drivers.” Ponies sass 
North Central Ford, just north of Ump 419 on 
San Pedro, has am ple space for customers and a large showroom with a giant lot for its used cars 
The well known and 
* highly res|K*cted firm al­ so is considered one of the major Ford full ser­ vice Healers in Texas 
The firm also has u lim line of tru cks and re­ cre ational vehicles, a first class service and parts department and an o u tsta n d in g paint and 
InhIv shop. 
"W e are here to serve our customers, old and new, in the best way we know how, and that m eans only one thing strictly first class service tor one and a ll.” says 
Contos 

Antes Travel Center has one of the largest selections of vehicles and equipment for camping and traveling. 

Antes, 38o2 N U Loop 41o near 
Wonderland Shopping City, is m an­ aged by Cody Barron and assistant 
Paula Barnds. 

They invite all who are interested in getting outfitted for spring and sum ­ mer camping to visit the huge Antes lot. It is easily accessible from Loop 
41o and its large sign is an easily visible landmark. 

Floor 

Antes features light portable fold­ down c am p e rs for outdoor "roughing it" with the assurance of a solid floor beneath. 

There are also cabover campers and truck mounts which can be unhooked and left at the campsite. 

A com plete selection of travel trailers and fifth wheels is available from Antes. These, of course, are 

 homes away from home for the tra­ veler who wants to take his home and have it, too. 

Covers 
Are you into camper covers? 
Antes has more than HO covers for every model truck. Choose from the less expensive Imperial to a Winneba­ go. In the intermediate range. Pony 
Coach and Beard are available. 

First class 

May be you want to go first class. 
Antes can help you do that. too. with 
Country Squire and Brougham mini- motor homes which are completely self-contained. 
Parts, serv ice and accessories for all trailers and campers also are available at Antes. 

Rem em ber — when you think of camping, think first of Antes Travel 
Center, because whatever you need, that s where you can find it.
