Mama cooks with 'weeds’ 

SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS— Thursday March 1o 1977 

By JANE ULBRICH 
Express Food Editor 

That lady out in your front yard? 
She’s not a liberated female gardener come to mow the grass. 
That’s “ M am a” Fon­ tana, and she's there to pick your dandelions be­ fore you pull them up and toss them out. 
(D on’t w orry, she’ll knock on the door and ask before she cleans you out!) 
“ People are throwing the goodies out of their yards," laments the lady who describes herself as 
“ a typical 
Italian mother—doing everyth­ ing.’’ 
Her activities include everything from babysit­ ting the grandchildren to cooking and freezing the dandelion greens now in profusion so they won't go to waste. 
But 
“ Mama is also 
V ictoria Fontana, who was in the restaurant bu­ siness in San Antonio for 
25 years. 
She probably is best remembered for her 
Venice Italian Restaur­ ant on the R iver W alk 
(where Caffe Michelino is located now) during 
HemisFair. 
Finale 
The “ grand finale" of her career was in 1969, when Mrs. Fontana re­ tired to help her daughters with their babies. 
Now all caught lip with home and fam ily life. 
Mama Fontana is cook­ ing in smaller quantities and enjoying the me­ mories. 

 call me a 

M A M A ’ VICTORIA FONTANA MAKING SANDWICH PATTIES 
. . .one of m any w ays she cooks dandelion greens 

“ They legend." 

When I arrived at her house for a special lunch 
(dandelions cooked five different w ays!), Mrs. 
Fontana was dashing out to pick up her grandson from kindergarten. 

So I snooped around her kitchen for a few minutes, sniffing jars of dried home-grown ore­ gano, exploring the throe types of dandelions soak­ ing in the sink and occa­ sionally stirring those boiling on top of tile stoves. 

“ These an* wild." she explained, pointing out the small, tender dande­ lion shoots from her front yard that can be put into salads and the two larger varieties that can be boiled like greens. 
“ They’re wild weeds you can eat. and the Ita­ lians have always cooked them. 
“ In Texas they grow like bushes, but in Cali­ fornia they’re raised in greenhouses for the mar­ ket . 
A winter vegetable, dandelions are seasonal 
I rom October through 
March. 

“ T h ey’re good this year because of the cold weather and the rains." 
Mama Fontana told me. 
“ If you’re fastidious, you pull the leaves off the stems before you cook them. But I'm not. I like the cm neb mess." 
Dandelion greens are spring green in color and cook up to an even pret­ tier shade 
“ Wherever the Italian p a sse s, the grass dies," murmured her husband, 
Salvatore, translating an old Italian saying. 

“ The 
Italians pick everything.” Mrs. Fon­ tana added, serving our plates. 

Meatballs 
Lunch was a real ex­ perience. The only thing on the menu that didn't have dandelion greens in it was Mama Fontana’s famous meatballs with tomato sauce. 

Of course she doesn t usually serve more than one dandelion dish at any one .meal’ 
The tenderest dande­ lion shoots were tossed into a salad with other greens, wine vinegar and oil. 
The boiled dandelion greens were chopped up and flavored with garlic, lemon juice, olive oil. salt and pepper and a garnish of hard-boiled egg slices and lemon wedges. 
The plain greens also were added to boiled le­ gumes 
(sm all white beans, i i i this case), to boiled lentils, to the same skillet in which liver had been fried (to souk up the flavorful juices) and lo a 

 mixture of eggs, cheese, bread crumbs and sea­ sonings to make patties . 

Amazingly versatile, the greens take on a dif­ ferent and distinctive taste in each dish 

Sandwiches 
My favorite was the patties which can bi* used in place of expensive lun­ cheon meat to make hearty sandwiches 
— using fresh sliced Italian bread, of course. 

PHOTO «v l o s t b a r b u ?* 

Where did Mrs. Fon­ tana learn to cook this 
“ Italian soul food’’? 
From her own mama, naturally. 
“ I don t know where else. There was nothing to do in our day but cook and entertain each other with engagements, wed­ dings and baptisms. 
. 
“ You know. the good old days!" 
She also studied home economics iii Cleveland. 
Ohio, and worked iii the housewares department 

 of a store there. 
“ When all the (cook­ ing) experts came through town." she says. 
“ I was there to watch, and I got beautiful train­ ing in the food field.” 
V ictoria 
Fontana hasn’t forgotten her home et' background (you should see her scrape a bowl clean!) or her Ita­ lian instincts for frugali- t v. 
But she D O ES NOT cook from a recipe. 
Boce are her rather sketchy directions for cooking the greens and making the patties. 
Boiled 
Dandelion 
Greens 
Soak the greens to clean and 
“ de-bug” them. 
Bring a pan of water to a boil, add tin* greens and cook about IO minutes. 
Use the cooked greens in other dishes and save the cooking liquid to drink as a “ health food.” 
Dandelion 
Patties' 
2 cups boiled and chopped dandelion greens 
1 cup bread crumbs moistened with milk 
2 eggs 
« 
Cl cup grated Parm e­ san (or other) cheese 
Crumbled crisp-fried bacon, optional 
Salt and pepper 
Garlic 
Chopped onion 
Combine all ingre dicots and drop by the spoonful onto a generous 
Iv oiled griddle (also can be done in a Irving pan) 
Cook until brown and turn. 
Serve hot as a side dish or use patties to muki sandvv idles. 

One good break... 

Eggs ort* vv li.ii put the 
“real” in real mayonnaise. 
Kraft knows that. W h ich is why Kraft uses whole eggs 

 and extra egg volks to m ake real m ayonnaise 
(h a ts rich, thick, smooth, flavorful.. .and Kraft. 

And now you get a break on the price, too. 
C lip the coupon and save 
HK on your next jar. deserves another.

(or 2 pint jars or one 48-ounce jar) of KRAFT Real

Quick bread for snackin’ 

VV hen the amnia of flaking bread f i l l s your home, there s no better place to lie than in flu* kitchen with the cook. 

Share s o m e tea and chat while von wait for the sweet smelling bread to U* ba kid to perfect inn. 

The aromas of pineap­ ple and baked prunes, nutmeg and cinnamon and chopped pecans is especially tempting dur­ ing the winter when ap- l/elites are big 

Y o u 'll bt* flappy to share a slice of this bread with friends and family l/ccausc of its nutritious ingredients 

Nuritious 
(rush ed pineapple packed i i i tis own mice makes tilts bread moist aud nutritious 
Oilier got*ddor-v“ d ingredients im hide the prunes ami the chopped pecans 

Pineapple Prime Loa! is a versatile quick bread that makes a good snack, or a great breakfast treat, or after-dinner dessert. 

For extra convenience, you can bake it ahead and store it tit the refri­ gerator wrapped tighti> iii aluminum foil.

Combine undramed pineapple and prunes; sci aside. Cream sugar and butter until light and fluffy. Beat ii i eggs Stir 

 iii sour cream and vanil­ la Stir ii i pineapple mix­ ture 
Combine flour, baking powder, suit. baking so­ da, cinnamon and nut­ meg Gruduull.v add to pineapple mixture, stir­ ring lust until moistened. 

I old III pet a ils l urn into well greased 
9x5-inch loaf pan. Bakt* ii i a Till degree oven I hour 5 minutes until toothpick inserted comes out clean. 
Let stand 111 minutes iii pan. Turn onto wire rack to complete cooling. 
Makes I loaf.

We actually rejected over a million pounds of beans last year in order to get just the right rich blend.

A good beverage is usually welcomed at any occasion. It is a sure way to add to the festi­ vities, whether it’s a hearty feast or a light snack. 
The time is near to pull out the shamrocks and leprechauns in cele­ bration of Ireland s patron saint, St. 
Patrick. 
Shamrock Punch will add the right touch of green to this occasion. Most of the ingredients can be chilled ahead of time and blended shortly before serv­ ing. 
Shamrock Punch 
I package (3 ounce) lime gelatin 
I 1/2 cups pineapple juice 
1/4 cup lime juice 
1/2 cup lemon juice 
3 1/2 teaspoons almond flavoring 
1 3/4 cups sugar 
2 bottles (28 ounces each) gingerale 
Few drops green food coloring 
I Quart vanilla ice cream 
Prepare gelatin according to pack­ age directions. Add juices, flavoring and sugar; stir until dissolved. 
Add gingerale and food coloring. Stir until blended. 
Garnish with scoops of ice cream and serve. Makes 23 four-ounce servings. 

JEAN SONDLEY OF HOME SERVICE DEPARTMENT 
. . .making a bowl of Shamrock Punch 
Chianti bottles good to collect 

Don’t throw that bottle away — it may be a collector’s item! 
While our primary purpose in getting a wine bottle is to drink the contents, the fringe benefit of the bottle is worth thinking about. 
One in particular that we have taken for grant­ ed for years is disap­ pearing from the scene. 
It is the straw covered 
Chianti bottle, called the 
Fiasehi in Italian. 
The Chianti bottles have rounded bottoms not unlike the shape of a light bulb and the raffia covering made a base for the bottle to stand erect. 
The bottles were taken out into the villages and left house to house. The ladies of the town fa­ shioned the straw on the bottles. 
Those finished were picked up as the next load of bottles was deli­ vered. This was a way to 

Words on 
Wine 

By 
JOHN CASEY 

 earn additional money for the household and it was also an additional expense for the wine producer. 
Imitations 
Several shippers are using plastic imitations, some arc using machine fashioned straw on flat bottomed bottles. 
Most are going to a 
Bordeaux-type bottle or a flask-type bottle which is uniform in dimensions 

 and are stacking and shipping better. 
Chianti is a very un­ derrated wine made mostly of the Sangiovese grape and two or three other varieties blended along with, of all things, a white grape. 
A good Chianti can lust up to 3o years if properly cared for. 
On the other hand end of the spectrum, there have been many bad imi­ tation bottles of Chianti 

 dumped on the American market. 
If you see a straw co­ vered Fiasehi for sale, — buy it. Try the wine, if unpleasant, pour it out and put a candle in the bottle. This is the first step toward becoming a true Bohemian. 
Questions 
Send questions to 
Words on Wine, San An­ tonio Express. Box 2171. 
San Antonio, Tex. 78297. 
Make your own tartar sauce 

 lf you've forgotten the tartar sauce ready for fish, then make your own! You may even like better than the ready­ made variety because it contains only your favor-* ite flavors. 

To one cup of dairy sour cream or plain yo­ 

 gurt add the following ingredients; two table­ spoons, each, of chopped onion, chopped green pepper, chopped dill pickle, chopped parsley, one tablespoon lemon juice and one-half tea­ spoon of dry mustard, 
I plus salt and pepper to taste.

SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS— Thursday March 1o 1977 

Crepes suzettes—legend in our time 

By CRAIG CLAIBORNE with PIERRE FRANEY 

N EW YORK TIMES N EW S SERVICE 

NEW YORK — Some of the legends in the world of food are amusingly apocryphal. 
Some of the legends are irritatingly apocryphal, and that is how we react to the tedious, naive and much-repeated anecdote about the origins of crepes suzette. 
It is a ridiculous and foolishly ro­ m an ticized tale th a t would give 
Georges Auguste Escoffier acute indi­ gestion, if not a full-size case of crise de foie. 
It is suitable for a TV script, and to tell the tru th it was dram atized, if mem ory serves, about 13 years ago with Walter Slezak flaming the crepes as the alleged creator of the dessert. 
Legend 

The legend goes like this: 
Henri Charpentier, who became in his later years one of the best-known r e s ta u r a te u r s on A m e ric a ’s W est 
Coast, was at one time an assistant waiter at the Cafe de Paris in Monte 
Carlo. 
Edward, then Prince of Wales, a r ­ rived with a sweet young thing in tow- named Suzette. 
Some say that Suzette was a child, others that she was a demimondaine — to use a phrase appropriate to the age. 
In any event, at the end of the meal, 
Charpentier started to perpare a crepe dessert at tableside when all of a sud­ den, zut alors, the spirits in the dish burst into flame and voila, sucees fou. 

When Charpentier died in 19B1, Jo- ieph Donoti, who had maintained a liscreet silence until C harpentier's loath, lighted a match under the le­ gend and wrote what might be pre­ aimed to be the true gospel. 
For credentials, incidentally. Donon vas one of the last great private chefs n America (he was once the subject of i profile in The New Yorker), in the service of Mrs. Hate Twombly of the 
Vanderbilt family. 
On Charpentier’s death he wrote — and we translate — in France-Airier- 
Klue, a ‘French-ianguage newspapar published weekly in the United States: 
“ Many American newspapers have attributed to him the origin of crepes suzette, and the m atter takes looking into. 
“ In the first place, Charpentier was never a chef, as many people supposed, and it was, of course, an image that M. 
Charpentier took no pains to dispel. 
“ He did own the restaurant Henri on 
Long Island during Prohibition and later was on the staff of the Louis XIV at Rockefeller Plaza. 
“ Of M. Charpentier’s talents there 

C R A I G C L A I B O R N E 

 could be no doubt. He came to America when he was 23 years old and joined a pleiade of maitres d ’hotel who know­ how to talk cooking to th e ir customers.’’ 
But, the author adds, no one could seriously pretend that Charpentier in­ vented these crepes. 
Donon then quotes Raymond Bodet. a member of the Academie Oilinaire de 
F ra n c e and a u th o r of 
“ T oques 
Blanches et Habits Noirs.” published in 1939. 
Joseph 
Crepes suzette, according to Bodet.. were created by Joseph, director of the 
Restaurant Marivaux, in honor of the actress Suzanne Reichenberg. who was known professionally by the sim ple name of Suzette. 
The crepes named in her honor were served to her as part of the action on stage. Joseph was subsequently direc­ tor of the Paillard Restaurant in Paris and was later with the Savoy Hotel in 
London. 
Crepes suzette, as served tradition­ ally in a restaurant, are demanding of space and time. 
The m a itre d ’hotel, or w hoever, carefully adds the crepes to the crepe butter, turning and folding with fork and spoon. 
The version here is much simplified. 
The crepes are sm eared with crepe butter, arranged in quantity in a crepe pan or other dish and heated in the oven. 
They are then ready to be finished and served without fuss to numerous guests. 
Crepes Suzette 
The crepes: 
1 cup flour 
2 small eggs 
I 14 to I Hi cups milk l 2 tablespoon vanilla 
>2 tablespoon sugar 

2 tablespoons melted butter l 2 teaspoon salt 
The crepe butter: 
12 lumps of sugar (called “ hostess” cubes) 
I orange v2 pound sw eet b u tte r, at room temperature 
1/4 cup sugar 
I tablespoon lemon juice 
12 cup orange .juice 
I tablespoon G rand M arnier 
For flaming: 
I tablespoon sugar 
V2 to cup cognac (plus or includ­ ing, if desired, a little maraschino, kirsch and/or Grand Marnier) 
Prepare the crepes. Place the flour in a mixing bowl and make a well in the center. Add the eggs and. while stir­ ring with a wire whisk, add Hi cup of tile milk. 
Beat to make as smooth as possible. 
Add more milk to make the batter the consistency of heavy cream. 
Put the mixture through a fine sieve. 
Or it may be blended. lf it is blended, it must be left to stand for 2 hours or longer before proceeding. In any event, stir in the sugar, butter, vanilla and salt. 
Rub the bottom of a crepe pan ( 4, 5, 
6 or 7-inch bottom diam eter) with a piece of paper toweling that has been dipped in butter. 
This is necessary for the first crepe and probably unnecessary after the first crepe has been made — if the crepe pan is properly cured. 
Spoon 2 to 4 tablespoons of the crepe batter into the pan and quickly swirl the pan around this way and that until the bottom is evenly coated.* 

The crepe should be quite thin. Cook briefly until the crepe “ sets” and starts to brown lightly on the bottom. 
Using a spatula, turn the crepe iii the skillet and cook briefly on the other side without browning. Turn out onto wax paper. 
A properly made crepe, held up to the light, looks like lace. Continue cooking until all the batter is used. 
Preheat oven to 4oo degrees. 
When all the crepes are made, pre­ pare the crepe butter. Rub the lumps of sugar all over the skin of the orange, then squeeze the orange and save the juice. 
Place the lumps between sheets of wax paper and crush them with a rolling pin. 
Spoon or pour the sugar into a mixing bowl and add the butter, sugar, lemon juice, x2 cup orange juice and Grand 
Marnier. 
Beat to blend well, preferably with an electric mixer. 
Smear the top (the unbrowned side) of each crepe with a teaspoon or so of the crepe butter and fold once, then twice to make a triangle. 
Rub the bottom of a large skillet 
(there are special crepe skillets, which are convenient but not essential) with the remaining crepe butter. 
Arrange the crepes over till' skillet and sprinkle the tablespoon of sugar over all. Place in the oven and bake for 
15 minutes. 
Place the pan over an open flame such as a gas burner or the burner of a chafing dish. Sprinkle the cognac mix­ ture over the crepes and ignite. 
Ladle the sauce over the crepes until the flame dies. Yields 24 to 36 crepes. 
Olives will make a no-fuss dinner 

Try a quick and appealing supper casserole that will really satisfy even teen-age hunger. 
P re p a re d w ith in ex­ pensive m a c a ro n i and wit Ii a can of ripe olives to enrich the flavor and add a p p e tite ap p e a l. 
Super 
Olive 
S u pp er m ight well bi? Called a 
Super Pantry Shelf Sup­ per.

 you need a q u irk , s u b ­ stantial. no-fuss meal. 
Super < H i v e 
Supper 
I can pittM ripe olives 
3 cups (8 oz.) uncooked nostaccioli macaroni 
I can (ll oz.) Cheddar cheese soup 
1/4 teaspoon cumin 
1/8 teaspoon white pep­ per 
1/8 teaspoon onion powder 
1/4 teaspoon hot pepper sauce 
I package (4 oz.) sliced ham . cut iii strip s (or chipped beef) 
I can (IB oz.) whole kernel corn, drained 
Drain ripe olives: cut in

F u jiy a J a p a n e s e R e s­ taurant.

Bend electric wok. 
The audience will be invited to ta ste the 
Oriental specialities, and free recipes will be dis­ tributed

Park store. Pat Petty will be dem onstrating regu ­ lar woks from the

He will show techniques of stir-frying and g i\e m enu ideas fe a tu rin g 
Oriental specialities. 
Include eggs in your diet 

 lf you're considering a vegetarian diet, keep iii mind that proteins from plant sources are goner* ally deficient in one or m n r c e s s e n t i a l a m i n o acids 
Plant protein is more efficiently utilized by the body when anim al p ro ­ tein such as that found in eggs (containing all the essential -amino acids) is included iii the sam e

 half. Cook macaroni in 4 q u a rts boiling salted water according lo pack­ age d ire c tio n s until tender. Drain well. 
In large bowl combine soup, cumin, pepper on­ ion powder and lint pep­ per sauce. Add macaroni, ripe olives and most of ham; toss lightly to mix 
Turn into 1-quart but­ tered casserole Top with remaining ham; bake in

Handy Andy 

Actor wins battle of bulge 

By JOHNA BLINN 

BURBANK, Calif. 
Affable 
Eel 
McMahon suffers from the plague of many Americans. 

“ For years, I was overweight. 
Losing weight has been a con­ stant battle. I finally said. ‘I’m going to do something about it!"’ 
Tapering Ed wrote a book. 
“ Slimming 
Down." after he whittled his girth from 24a to 2oo pounds. 
The super pitchman of 
Tonight 
Show fame looked fit and rested iii his office here. 
The effort has been rewarding for the ener­ getic gent. "I feel good.” he said with a grin. lie looks good. too. playing the role of the lecherous company pre­ sident in his new moxie. 
“ Fun With Dick and 
Ja n e ,” for which he’s been getting rave re­ views. 
He thrives on being busy. One wall of his of­ fice is lined with a huge calendar that charts his constant xx birl of acti­ vities. 
As well as his regular stint with Johnny Carson. he makes TV commer­ cials, performs in night­ clubs and acts as spokes­ man and host for a com­ pany that builds shop­ ping malls. 
Recently, he set up his own company to make net xx nrk tx pc commer­ cials for local TV outlets across the country. 
Ed 
McMahon even finds time to cook! He does most of his cooking in the hideway home on 
Florida's West Coast he shares with his new mate. Victoria, a former airline public relations representative. 

Farting 
“ I can't cook as much as I'd like to, though, be­ cause we try and stay within the boundaries of the diet.” Occasionally he fasts to keep the weight off. 
“ When I cook, it s a leg of lamb, roast turkey or ham, even if it's not on the diet! I used to bake bread and cakes, but I had to quit that. 
“ Listen, I used to make the ‘Great Dinners' that appeared in Life maga­ zine. I'd get up early to go do my shopping and get all the fresh vegetables. ll would take me a whole day but it was worth all of the time and effort. 
“ Those were the days!" 
He blames his love for good food on his Irish pa­ ternal grandmother, 
Katie Fitzgerald McMa­ hon. 
“ The most arresting smell in this world is the aroma of fresh bread baking. That's how I woke up every morning I spent with my grand­ mother. 
“ She never heard of cereal. We’d have pork chops for breakfast. She was a wonderful cook and believed i i i serving po tatoos ut every meal!" 

 ing mix) plus herbs, pin­ eapple and lemon mar­ malade. 
Ed and Victoria are in the throes of moving after having suffered a fire in their Beverly Hills home. 
They are considering re­ modeling or buying a new house. 
Recipes from super pitchman, actor and cook 
Ed McMahon follow: 
Ed McMahon's 
French-style 
Leg of Lamb 
(Serves 3 to 6) 

1 bone-in leg of lamb, weighing about 6 lbs. 
2 or 3 cloves garlic, peeled, cut in slivers 
Toothpicks 
1-2 cup 
Dijon-type prepared mustard 
Handful chopped fresh parsley 
Salt, freshly ground black pepper 

12 bottle dry red w inc 
Wipe off roast with damp clean cloth. Insert garlic with sharp knife. 
Attach garlic to tooth­ picks (leave sticking out of meat). 
Rub mustard gener­ ously over entire outer surface of the lamb; place roast on rack. Place rack in bottom of large open roasting pan. 
Scatter parsley over top of roast; season out­ side lavishly with salt, pepper. 
Pour small amount of water into bot­ tom of pan. 
Roast leg of lamb in preheated 35o degree oxen I to I 1 1 hours for medium rare. or I 1 j to I i-j hours for well done. 
Baste roast liberally with wine as it cooks. 
During last half-hour of roasting time, pour off cooking juices into small plastic container. Place container in freezer until fat congeals on top. Re­ move and discard fat. 
Cook down juices to make sauce, season to taste. Let roast stand IO minutes to firm up before carving. Delicious with your favorite wine! 

Roast Turkey with Brandied 
Stuffing 

(Serves Bl 
I package (8 ozs.) herb 

PITCHMAN ED MC MAHON 
. now in ‘Fun with Dick and Jane* 

 seasoned stuffing mix 
I package (8 ozs.) cornbread stuffing mix 
I *2 **ups (15 to 16 ozs.) apple sauce 
12 cup drained, crushed pineapple 
Handful chopped fresh mushrooms 
I cup orange or lemon marmalade 
12 teaspoon sage 
I cup brandy 
12 cup cooked, crum­ bled pork sausage, op­ tional 
I cup butter, melted 
IO to 12 pound turkey 
6 strips bacon 
Combine stuffing mixes, apple sauce, pin­ eapple. mushrooms, marmalade. sage, brandy, sausage and but­ ler. 

Stuff turkey, truss 
Place on rack. breast side up. in roasting pan. Place bacon strips over breast. 
Bake iii preheated 325 degree oven for I hour; then cover loosely with a foil tent and continue baking until well- browned aud tender about 3* 2 hours, basting occasionally. 
Remove bacon when it is crisp, crumble it into dressing after it is re­ moved from the bird 
(omit if sausage has been added to dressing). 

AFTERTHOUGHTS: 
Additional brandy can be brushed on bird as if bakes to give it taste and color. 

I exam 

McMahon still has a crav ing for Irish stew. He recalled a recent trip to 
Texas, where a friend made him a pot from scratch. 
“ It was beautiful," he said with a dreamy smile. “ And it was even better the next day." 
One of his favorite eu hoary creations is roast leg of lamb, prepared 
French style by lathering the roasi completely with 
Dijon mustard and bast­ ing it often with a good, dry red w me. 

“ I stick slivers of gar lie attached to toothpicks into the meat. That way, can pull the garlic oui after ifs cooked. The se ere! to the roast is the gravy. 

“ I pour the pun juices into a plastic container and then I put it in the freezer. The fat congeals so I can skim off the top aud discard the fat aud the calories. 
“ The gravy becomes a beautiful red-brown wine sauce flavored with parsley, garlic aud mus turd." 
Every year he adds so 
(nettling new to his tut key stuffing “ This year it was fresh mushrooms and country sausage.” 
Ordinarily, he com bines several kinds olf prepared stuffing (corn bread and regular stuff

Record voter sign-up seen 

Manager Roger Berry 

 is claiming a record high of 395,ooo - still an esti­ mate, though — on the current voter registra­ tion total for Bexar 
County. 

Berry attributes the growth lo mushrooming public interest in poli­ tics, elections and what- have-you. 
On a slightly related subject, Judge Jam es E. 
Barlow says jury selection duties are most enjoyable for a judge w ho is, after all, an elected public official who dotes on people. Contact with jurors is contact with lots of people with lots of ideas, the judge noted. 
County Court at Law 
Judge 
Carolyn 
(you’ll note the spelling is cor­ rect this time) 
Spears felled briefly by a flu-like bug was back on the bench bv mid-week. 
Assistant UA 
Jim 

Lewis is the man whose office is sprouting avoca­ 

 do seeds wall to wall. His name line here last week was inadvertently omit­ ted. 
Space juggling is under way at Bexar County 
Courthouse to make way for the four new district courts. News persons and the Bexar County Histor­ ical Commission are the first to be evicted from their shared ground-floor quarters. 
Sheriff's Department staffers are to take over that space when two county-courts-at-law ease some of Sheriff 
Bill 

Hauck’s people out of the offices they now use right 

Ruling pends in death 

A ruling is pending in the death of a 58-year-old northwest San Antonio man who was found Wednes­ day with gunshot wounds to me enesi. 

Officers identified the victim as Charles F 
Jackson of 254 N. Northill Drive. 

He was found slumped on a sofa in his home at about 1:15 p.m. after police were summoned to the residence, officers said. 

A 38-caliber revolver was found on the sofa lying alongside the man’s thigh, police said. 

The victim was pronounced dead on arrival 2:43 p.m. at the Green Hospital. 

 next door. 
Historical Com. Chair­ man Maj. Gen. William 
A. Harris (ret.) and his research clerk JoAnnc 
Chaney still do not know where their next office will be. 
Promotions are in the wind for some District 
Clerk’s office staffers working on court busi­ ness. 
The four new judges and their courts need trained personnel. 
District Clerk 
Elton 

Cude is back on the job after last week’s Fifth 
Annual Seminar for Dis­ trict and County Clerks at Texas A&M. 
Mrs. 
Betty T rail, court reporter in the 45th 
District Court for Judge 
Robert R. Murray, is one of the few around the old 
Red Brick Building who still takes it all down the old-fashioned way, by hand. 
For sweet song, listen to staffer Delilah Devane in the District Clerk's office. 
.W ith her 
22-year-old daughter 

Gall, 
Mrs. 
Devane sings up a gospel storm for the Childress Me­ morial Church of God in 
Christ choir. 

DURELLE BLACK 
. . Miss AMEDD 1977 
Scouts to help 
Goodwill 

The Alamo Area Coun­ cil Scouts of America w ill distribute Good Turn Day bags Saturday to resi­ dences throughout San 
Antonio neighborhoods. 
Families are asked to fill the bags with usable clothing, shoes, small appliances and other small items in need of repair and then place the bags on doorsteps by 9 a.in. March 19. 
On that date, the scouts w ill return to pick up the filled bags and return them to Goodwill. 
The repairable items will be used to train the handicapped at Goodwill 
Industries for jobs in private industry. 
Scouts in each of the seven districts, plus members of the Explorer district, will take part in this year’s project. 

Ft. Sam beauty picked 

A petite, blue-eyed lieutenant bas been crowned 1977 Miss Army 
Medical 
Department 
(AMEDI)) in San Antonio 
Tuesday at Et. Sam 
Houston. 
Lt. Durelle Black, a nurse at Brooke Army 
Medical Center, was se­ lected from 17 military and civilian contestants vying for. the 
Miss 
AMEDI) title before a panel of five judges. 
She was crowned by 
Maj. 
Gen. 
Spurgeon 
Neel, commander of 
Health 
Services 
Command, and Specialist 
Pomposa Briones, Miss 
AMEDD 1976. 
Chosen Miss AMEDI) princesses were 
Ll. 
•Kathleen Franklin and 
Spec. 4 Patricia Shea. 
Tennessee 
The new Miss AMEDI) attended the University of Tennessee in her ho­ metown of Knoxville and received her bachelor of science degree in nursing' from the University of 
Maryland in 1976. 
She plays piano and tennis, likes to sew and cook and she is a student pilot. 
Lt. Franklin is from 
Chicago. She majored in zoology at the University of Vermont and is a unit executive officer at the 
Academy of 
Health 
Sciences. 
Specialist 
Shea, a 
21-year-old Wisconsin native, is assigned to 
BAMC headquarters. She is studying mathematics in the evening division of 
San Antonio College.

Clean-up coming? 

The owner of 128 VV. Magnolia Ave., has failed to make satisfactory arrangements to store and collect the garbage from this apartment building. 

Needless to say, he does not live there 

His property is helping make the whole area smell and look rundown. 

What can be done to make him stop behaving like this and have some respect for the residents of 
Laurel 
Heights who would like a clean neighborhood? 
W. IL 

The event, a tribute to the Irish before St. Pa­ trick’s Day. is sponsored by the St. Patrick's Day 
Commission of the Harp 
& Shamrock Society 
Texas and the Paseo del 
Rio Assn. 

The parade will start at 
I p.m. at Toohig’s Res­ taurant. 1o2 River Walk, and proceed to the Arne- son River Theater 
• 
The Central Catholic 
High School Band will provide music during the parade. 
COMMUNITY swimming pool at Green Springs subdivision won a design award for Gary Pools 

Pool firm wins awards 

Two swimming pools designer! by Gary 
Pools, Inc. have received awards of merit in the National Swimm ing Pool Institute's international design competition. 

“ We have won design awards in the past but this recent honor was especially appreciated because of the intense competition from all parts of the world," said Leif Zars, Gary president. 

Worldwide, entries in the contest totaled 48o from 
125 companies. Only BH entries received awards. 

Aquatech. Inc., an organization of top pool builders in Hie nation of which Gary is a member. won 34 awards. 

Winning entries submitted by Gary. Ill NE 1H41o, were at the home of a prominent North Side resident and a community pool at Green Springs subdivision on Wetmore Road. 

City health inspectors agree with vou. 
Warnings and other ef­ forts have been made to get the owner to clean up 
(he property. They have all been in vain. 
The city has now filed a complaint against the property owner in muni­ cipal court saying that the property has “ rub­ bish. that is trash, litter and empty cans” and that the owner is “ un­ lawfully allowing a pub­ lic nuisance to exist” at that location. 
The complaint then al­ leges the conditions at that address violate var­ ious sections of city code. 
A hearing on this com­ plaint (and two others against the same owner 

 for conditions at other property he owns) has been set for 9 a.m., F ri­ day, March 25, in Muni­ cipal Court No. I. Neigh­ bors are apparently go­ ing to appear and testify against the owner. 
Action-Express con­ tacted the owner and asked him about the con­ ditions. His reply was: 
“ Well, what do you want me to say?" We asked if he had made any im ­ provements since the complaint was filed, and he said he had no com­ ment and would see the people com plaining about him in court. 
And that is about where that stands until the hearing conies up in court. 

Phone repairs 

In order lo cut down on telephone service charges, many home owners have procured their own tele­ phones from various agencies to be utilized as extensions 

^Although Ma Bell will yell loudly this is an illegal practice — it is only against their own established policies and nothing else. 

< The public pays for communication services and from which room I choose to utilize that service should not be of any concern to Bell. 

The question is, however, where can one have lhese personal telephone instruments repaired? 

Surely, with the large number of private phones now iii use, various enterprising individuals must baw* taken on the phone repair business, 

( an you furnish the name and address or other whereabouts of such phone repair facilities? 
Thanks. 
RET IR ED ARMY 

Southwestern Bell offi­ cials hulled and puffed about “ then of services” aud other nefarious do­ ings when we explained 
(he problem to them. 
I hey were more con­ cerned about vou hooking up your own phone than thev were about the tnal- lunetioning equipment. 
However, we are not going to get involved in 
Ilia! dispute, that is between vou and your conscience and the en­ terprise ol Ma Bell in tracking you down, lf you get caught, you will have to pay. lo answer your ques­ tion. however, we could find no one locally who repairs telephone equip­ ment. lf there is someone oui there who does this sffviee. we will be glad to let our readers know. 
You might go back to the store where you pur­ chased the phone or you might write to the nianu- lac lurer for repair infor­ mation 
It all that tails and you still want the phone. 

Southwestern 
Bell will be more than happy to come out and install 
Western Electric equip­ ment inside your phone. 
Of course, that means they will also know you have the illegal extension and will charge you ac­ cordingly. 

Actually, the problem you have encountered is the reason why Bell has gone into the Design Line phones — offering spe­ cial design phones with 
Western Electric equip ment inside which the phone company m ain­ tains in good working order free of charge. The company had numerous calls lur help from people who had bought antique and other special phones from stores ;ind cata­ logues that experienced d ifficulties. But since they are not Bell equip­ ment, Bell could not lix them. 

That's about all we can do lur you unless we hear 
(rom some local phone fixer.
